content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
tl;dr -> Play as Batman an assassin agent of Good before the events of The Lord of the Rings. 11/10 orc-killing simulator.I got this game on launch and was so excited to play because I love the Middle Earth universe and Assassin's Creed/Arkham playstyle. I absolutely adored my gameplay experience - to the point that I gave SoM the #1 spot in my Top 5 games of 2014. The aesthetics are beautiful - the amount of detail in the characters and game world are very well-done. When it rains for the first time, you will be in for a nice treat - the raindrops flicking off of your feet and body have a nice effect. The blood and gore come in copious amounts, enough to satisfy anyone who enjoys mutilation and flying body parts (in slow-motion too). The sounds, music, and voice acting are superb and add to the immersion into the ME universe. The story is satisfactory - your typical quest for ultimate vengeance - but there definitely is a lot of lore to be found within (especially in the numerous side missions).The controls are not too difficult to familiarize yourself with, especially if you've played any games in the Assassin's Creed/Batman Arkham franchises. The keyboard and mouse combo work perfectly, but I personally prefer the controller. There is a helpful tutorial that will show you the beginning mechanics you need to know, and more are provided whenever a new element is introduced to the game. The learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your experience with open-world action RPGs. I would recommend anyone with experience to play on the hardest difficulty to increase immersion - I found that mid/late-game the game took a big dive in difficulty. The game has a certain way intended for you to play - interrogating enemies to find the weaknesses of stronger chiefs - however, I found that after ~10 or so hours of playing, I could just blitz through and go straight for the orc chiefs (brute-forcing them even if I was using an ineffective strategy). From what I've seen in the online community, many people will actually let themselves die to force enemy leaders to level up (even then it wasn't too challenging). I will admit, the journey to achieving a god-like character is fun and gruelling - in my first few hours, I would run away if I ever encountered 2 or more leaders simultaneously, now, I will purposely run into as many level 15+ (20 is the max) chieftains as possible (and still barely break a sweat).Gameplay consists of you doing a variety of different missions throughout the kingdom of Mordor. There are  two main map locations you will be frequenting, the second typically providing higher level enemies. Like most open-world RPGs, there are a large variety of side quests available, each having a bit of text flavor explaining something to do with your player character (ex: how he snuck into an encampment and assassinated everyone; the flavor for a stealth-oriented mission). If you are familiar with any of the Assassin's Creed/Batman Arkham games, then gameplay will feel very similar. You can usually choose to use violence or stealth when traversing through areas/missions, but be aware that you will face a sea of enemies should the alarm be raised. To avoid this, a good strategy is to move toward the alarm and kill anyone attempting to raise it (even hitting them will stop the alarm process). Combat is very, very fluid and looks fantastic. You have a heavy and quick attack, counter, dodge, and can use a bow and arrow. Later, you will be able to unlock new abilities when you gain enough experience to level up. Abilities include throwing a set of daggers, phase rushing (can upgrade to phase insta-kills that you can chain), and mounting special creatures. Combat while mounted is also a lot of fun. Stronger enemies will drop item runes that you can use to augment your equipment.One of the nicest, unique features in this game is the Nemesis system. The orc armies have a hierarchy, and each individual will make different plays to try to climb the ranks. If a normal orc kills you, they will immediately be promoted into the hierarchy (orcs already in the hierarchy will become promoted). If you continue to die to the same orc, they will gain strength and levels - they will also make comments whenever you reappear to fight them, ranging from confident taunts to sheer horror at you refusing to stay dead. Sometimes, an orc leader you kill will come back after being defeated (yes, even from getting their head cut off). They will usually have a battle scar related to the injuries you gave them (scratches, bandages, etc) and will make a comment. Personally, the Nemesis system seemed a bit lacking for me because I very rarely gained a nemesis - even when I purposely died to enemies. Perhaps I was just killing everyone too quickly, I am not sure. The most times I've seen the same orc leader come back (from death, not just from retreating) was twice. As you progress in the story, you will unlock the ability to "brand" enemies. Branding orcs will cause them to fight for you when you activate them, causing them to go hostile to any nearby unbranded individuals. You can even brand orc leaders, and this is typically a very popular way to farm top tier runes. For example, you interrogate a normal orc and identify an orc leader with a weakness that is very easy to exploit (like weakness to fire). You then brand this orc and get him to rise all the way to orc warlord (highest rank) and help him with missions until he is level 20. After summoning him, you can insta-kill him by grabbing him or activating his suicide mode, most likely causing him to drop a top-tier equipment rune. Personally, I just liked finding the coolest looking orcs and making them my warchiefs. They will even have different ways of speaking - my absolute favorite orcs do not even talk, they just laugh, or breath menacingly. Orcs will also vary in appearance, attack preference (heavy shield, ranged, poison, etc), strengths, and weaknesses.The highest-ranked orc leaders will generally have other orcs in the hierarchy as officers - these individuals will appear alongside the leader should he be summoned. To make confrontations easier, it is advised that you either kill or brand all of a leaders' officers first. Regarding the difficulty, I eventually would just go straight for leaders without touching their officers to make the battle more challenging. After a time (like when you die or the next day arrives), orcs will move in and replace empty spots in the hierarchy. If you are quick enough, it is very possible to (temporarily) eliminate the entire hierarchy. Orcs will conduct missions against one another, which can you can interrupt by activating the respective mission waypoint. An example of a mission is a duel between two orcs - the winner gaining power and the loser usually dying (unless they retreat). If you wish, you can help one side, or just kill both combatants. Be advised, an orc that successfully retreats will increase in power. When you have a branded orc, you can interrogate it to learn weaknesses of hierarchy members (the warlords require interrogation of ranked orcs), or order it to conduct a mission against another orc. You can even command warlords to fight other members of the hierarchy - and they will bring along any of their officers.The missions you play also have an effect on Mordor. For example, liberating captive humans will slowly cause overall resistance to increase. As a result, humans will be more likely to help you fight the enemy. Overall, the game plays very smoothly and does not demand an unreasonable amount of skill or concentration to be enjoyable. ABSOLUTELY RECOMMEND!Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue ReviewsMy Website[theroguereviews.com]

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												One of the best games i have played to this day, and i have played many. I was first sceptical to buying the game as i have seen plenty of other similar sequels to big series, but after watching different gameplay videos, i decided to buy it on PC.As it was controller supported, i managed to convert my PS3 controller into a Xbox Controller playing the game with Xbox Buttons but it was still fun.Reading some reviews they talk about newer Assasins Creed and Batman games where a lot of combat and if i can say parkour system is taken from, as i have not played Assasins Creed for many years from Assasin's Creed 2, and i have never played Batman games, i really enjoyed the gameplay.I initially made a save slot and played for roughly ten hours, during this gameplay a lot of time went to try to eliminate all orc Captain's, which in fact the system is brilliant, as you challenge different orc leaders or captain's, when they die someone else take their place, as well with a lot of frustration from getting killed on my first try, it also introduces something completely new to me the nemesis system which is awesome. If you get killed in the game, the time advances and you can see Captain's challenge eachother and take higher positions, you feel the game progresses by the actions you do. As for other gameplay aspects i really enjoyed the jumping, climbing and combat which took me back several years when i enjoyed the Assasin's Creed Series. Stealth killing orcs from ledges, awesome combat with cool combat finishers really made the game cool.I started a 2nd save with more of a serious gameplay where i wanted to collect everything, and now after playing trough the whole game, i have around 17 hours on my save two, where i now have 100%, just collecting, roaming trough and killing orcs, doing side-missions, unlock abilities and upgrades just made the game complete. Exept the final boss-fight, i really enjoyed the game, and i would recommend it to others, buy it. It's worth its money.9/10

content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												I bought this game on sale with little expectations. I had played previous LOTR games and was mildly amused by them. Buying this game, I expected the same mild amusement.... until I played it.This game turned out to be far more amazing then I expected it to be. The fighting in the game is easy to just hack and slash your way around, but difficult to truly master - with effective and rewarding bonuses when you master your timing. Many of the negative views I've read complain about how easy the fighting is, but those folks apparently didn't take the time to try to master it, or invest in the bonuses. It was extremely fun.What makes this game truly great is how it adds to the story line. I am one of the sad, unfortunate souls who has never taken the time to read all the Tolkein books - I've only seen the extended releases of all the LOTR and Hobbit movies multiple times because I enjoy them so much. This game adds to those stories, by giving you insight into the great war, the black gate, and other known points of interest in the movies.The mission system is easy to use and understand, the various 'generals' in the orc amies and all the various collectiables give you lots of variety - there is always something to do. The missions also employ different play styles. You can be ranged DPS with your bow, mele dps with your sword, or stealth with your bow and dagger - with great bonuses for all styles that you could invest your experience into.I read another negative review complaining that the black gate area was too small, but it should be noted that there are 2 other 'lands' that you get to progress to. So, if you get board in the first area (the black gate area), do the gold missions, and progress the story to visit the new lands. The story is quite good and progressing it gives you access to new, exceptionally fun powers (mind control anyone?) as well as new missions and mission types.10/10 for a job extremely well done. Thank you!

 It's fun to kill orcs! It's fun to stab them from behind, like death from the shadows.It's fun to slit their throats, and watch them bleed to death.It's fun to behead them, without mercy and no guilt.It's fun to shot them from the shadows, and designing traps for them.It's fun to put them on fire, and watch them flee in terror.It's fun to poisen their grog supply, like it's a sign of bad omen to come.It's fun to let them be eaten by released caragors, a vicious beast of Mordor.It's fun to trample them while riding a graug, one of the oldest species in Mordor.It's fun to unleash a flurry of strikes at them, and watch their head explode.It's fun to let them kill each other, branded for life, with your will as will.It's fun to kill them, from the front, from behind, from above, from below, from the left, from the right, from a distance, from the back on a beast, and from the wraith world.Killing is fun, fun, fun. And it's allways fun to hear an orc inspecting a dead orc: "there has been a murder".

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor is a gritty, action adventure game that has great production values, excellent gameplay, and a solid story that is worth your time and money.Running this game on a i5 2500k @ 4 Ghz, and a GTX 780 ti, I ran everything at ultra with the exception of textures which I ran at high.  Visually speaking, the game is impressive with high quality animations, texture work, and long draw distances.  Only on occasions did I leave my target frame rate of 60 FPS @ 1080p.  Overall, I would rate the quality of this port as very high.Now that the technical details are out of the way let’s get into what makes this game so great.  First, the game play is very much in the style of Batman Arkham Asylum.  Which, if you are fan of that style of game play, you will find that this is the best implementation of that system outside of the Batman games.  The game makes you feel powerful in every way, and killing hordes of orcs is common place and richly satisfying.  The first time you are surrounded by 20+ enemies and you managed to execute the whole lot of them without breaking a chain is an amazing feeling.  The level up progression is well executed, as each unlock is interesting and helpful regardless of your play style.It is a Warner Brother’s open world game in the same vein of the Batman Arkham series, and Mad Max.  There are towers, you have to scale them to see all the missions and collectibles in an area.  At first, I just moaned when I first noticed that this was the way the game was going to progress.  However, the action and the story are tight enough, and more importantly, while the game is big, it isn’t too big.  As a result, the feeling of déjà vu that you get from other games of the type, is lessened.  Overall the mission structure feels tight, and the game is very well paced.  Much has been made of the Nemesis system in the game, a system where you try to kill the chain of command of Orcs.  I found this system to be both rewarding, and controller spiking frustrating all that the same time.  I will say that I liked the system enough that if it was introduced in another game with some tweaks made, I would love to see it return.The story is excellent, albeit simple.  It’s all about revenge, and a few subplots thrown in for good measure.  It simplicity works to the game’s advantage as it doesn’t try to do too much with the plot, which allows you to really appreciate the character development of the main characters.The soundtrack is worth mentioning in its own section.  Quite frankly, it is perfection.  Brooding, full orchestral, and emotional at all the right times, the music sucks you into the game a never let’s go.  It really is that good, and if you are into video game soundtracks, it is worth tracking down a copy, it’s that good.  It really could come from a Triple A movie production.Considering it has been out for a good amount of time now, getting this game at 50% off or greater is a steal.  There is easy 30 hours of gameplay here, and more if you get every single secret, and continue playing the nemesis system.  So go ahead and by this game, and kill some orcs it is the right thing to do.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2016
												I just beat this game for the second time, the first was on a Playstation 3, the second was on Steam.  I spent at least 30 hours each time I played it. So let's just think about that, I spent 60 hours playing this game.  Can I end my review with that?   You betcha. But I'll continue, what I really like about this game is it is based in a "movie" world (Yes I know it's a book as well) and yet really has one connection to the movie.  I won't spoil it but with in the first couple hours you see a character that's also in the movie.  And everything else is new and beautiful lore.  The game offers a very special system, called the nemesis system.  From this you get random autogenerated enemies.  I believe even the first set of enemies (outside of some VERY specific enemies for a few missions) is randomly generated.  And by random I mean fully random, not just "different name" a lot of characters have similar make ups (some enemies can't be attacked by some moves) but for the most part you're thrown against enemies that no one else will see unless they have to get revenge for you.  (Sadly the game has been out a long enough time that the revenge feature doesn't appear that often). And what's beyond that, if you die to a random grunt, they actually will raise up the ranks, even the enemies you fight normally gain power just from killing you. What this means is you have a very dynamic world that only you will see. It moves beyond just "the enemies you face".  What they say when they attack you the first time, versus the third or fourth time will keep changing depending on what happened previously.  Sometimes enemies will return from the dead with new "injuries" and they'll make reference to the fact that you gave them the injury.  Sometimes they'll insult you that you either ran away or died to them before.   It all is brilliant, giving random enemies a life that even heavily scripted games miss.The story is a great affair, recounting a written account of a character long forgotten.  As much gets revealed over time, I won't spoil that.   However I will say that the core is a story written by Tolkein, and adapted by the studio.  One thing that does work though is the fact the player dies and revives is part of the story.  This isn't a situation where the player is just magically revived with no reason, but rather the main character is unable to die, and thus able to continue to return to life.   The only real negative I have with the game is the ending is a touch abrupt.  You will fight a final boss, however by that part of the game, the fights before it are more fun and better.  The player gains a HELL of a lot of power near the end of the game  to the point that it's only in huge melees is there even a chance of the player losing (and not that much chance at that).  So the final boss isn't disappointing, but just not a challenge.  However the ending of the game is perhaps its weakest moment.  A shame. That being said the game does leave the player wanting more.  And hopefully WB and Monolith Productions gives the audience a sequel because while it's not a perfect game, this game did win a number of game of the year awards, because it's such a refreshing game. So for all of that it's a recommendation.  I'd have trouble trusting anyone who gave this game a low score, because while opinions are subjective, the fact is this is the freshest breath of air in the video game in industry in probably a decade.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												Finally a AAA game that feels like a budget well spent! On top of the gameplay being fun and fresh, everything feels perfectly polished.It plays a lot like the recent Batman games with a mix of stealth and melee combos. Over time you gain super powers which allow you to scrap with large hordes of enemies. Moment-to-moment the game is fun whether you’re sneaking, fighting, or running to your next objective of choice. The side quests sometimes feel grindy, but a for the most part fun challenges that can get you to try out a different play style.The innovative system that constructs unique bosses that build a history with the player is a Holy Grail that game designers have been chasing for decades and now it’s finally working! In the coming years you’re going to see this idea stolen all over the place. Between the randomized strengths/weaknesses, shuffled cosmetics, and huge array of vocal responses they become personal and interesting enemies.I’m not usually a fan of cut scenes, but these are quick, well written, and beautiful. I don’t know the historic difference between the words ‘orc’ and ‘uruk’, but I know that uruk is annoying to say and not recognized by spellchecker. The writing and acting in the chatter/barks has a great sense of humor. You can still hear a little of old Monolith’s No One Live’s Forever in the dialog.The only gripe I have is that the many systems and upgrade paths feel overly complex at first. I wish they were introduced one at a time, but eventually it comes together and makes sense. The arc of the story feel like it falls short of being epic, but I’m not huge on Tolkien so most of the backstory is lost on me. Or maybe it will get bigger in the upcoming DLCs. Either way I’m excited for more.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												This Review contains minor spoilers about the final scenes of the game, read at your own risk.Shadow of Mordor is a game about killing orcs. It it also known as a mix of the Arkham Series and Assassin's Creed. Many people call this a ripoff, but it is in many ways better than both of these games, but it still has it's own small problems. The Story is quite good and has a few twists and turns. It has many references to the Lord of the Rings series and it's lore is very accurate. The game plays and looks amazing. The combat is hard when you start off,  but further down the line you will only lose fights in unbeatable odds. It has a lot more variety than the Arkham series, but it is quite easy when you get some of the higher tier powers. The stealth system is nothing unusual, but it is not emphasised enough on. You crouch and take your opponents out. With the Arkham games you have many different foes and you have the ability to approach nearly every situation in your own way, but Shadow of Mordor dosen't have that, and it is not a bad thing. It is it's own game, and it does what it does well. It is better than Assassin's Creed though because it actually has a crouch button. The climbing is exactly like Assassin's Creed but it is much faster and you can climb up almost anything in a few grabs. The game also offers many side quests and the amazing nemesis system. I have literally not seen anything like it before. It is unique and it feels like what the orcs would be trying to accomplish with their power struggles. It has a high risk reward system with the runes that can make you overpowered as hell. The mounts in the game, while limited, offer a nice form of travel compared to simple fast travelling and can be used to kill orcs as well. However, there is one thing this game did not execute well; The ending. The first battle brought back your worst nemesis and it was awesome. Then the next battle was a easy stealth section where you had to stealth attack your opponent 3 times, then hold a button to finish him off. Then it picks up with a fast pace battle near the Black Gate. You charge through with a Caragor and kill 5 captains with the help of your branded orcs. Then the final part is a 5 button QTE. This was just lazy and I expected a lot more. However, the rest of the game is amazing. I am looking forward to the content in the Season Pass and I hope Monolith do not do that to the ending of a game again. Overall: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												Amazingly varied and fluid Arkham-like combat system with the stealth and movement of AssCreed, horde brawl melee, powerful ranged attacks, mind control and mountable beasts, and surprise environmental traps such as bait that draws Carragors who devour every Orc in sight. Too easy? Don't get any health upgrades and turn combat indicators off. The innovative Nemesis System crafts  foes worth killing, some Uruk Captains surviving your battles with scars, some ending up as heads on pikes, some growing in power and deadliness after killing you (you are reborn with a thirst for revenge each time you die) and some secretly serving you, waiting for your signal to stab their War Chief in the back as you shoot out their eye with a ghostly arrow from the front. I went in expecting a shallow rip off and instead emerged on the other side from a shallow grave as the legendary Gravewalker, cleansing fire of all Orc-kind. A fun, quick-paced, pretty romp that tries new things instead of playing it safe all the time. 9/10

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												Shadow of Mordor is what you get when you cross Batman Arkham with Assassin's Creed and wrap it up in the Lord of the Rings universe.  While lore purists may scoff at the prospect, the game actually does a very good job incorporating existing lore while paving its own way forward.  You play as a wraith-posessed ranger out to take revenge on the Black Hand while learning about the wraith's past.  It's a bit of an odd situation but it adds a lot of gameplay variety.The game takes place on 2 reasonably-sized maps which you have free reign of.  There is never any shortage or orcs to kill since they respawn extremely quickly, sometimes visibly on your minimap before an area is out of range.  Even considering this, the map rarely feels cluttered but there is still plenty to do with a wide range of missions, side missions, collectibles, and challenges.Shadow of Mordor uses a freeflow combat system very similar to the Batman Arkham games and pulls it off quite well.  While it does not have quite as much variety due to a lack of combat gadgets, the combat feels great especially thanks to some impressive animation work and responsive controls.  Overall the combat is pretty easy especially after obtaining a few upgrades, though the game makes it quite difficult to defend against ranged attacks due to only vague indicators of the attack.  Controls are very responsive except for the dodge, which will not interrupt attacks like countering does making enemies with uncounterable attacks difficult to deal with.  Orc captains, however, can be very dangerous especially with ranged attacks.The main strength of the game is the Nemesis system, which surprised me since going in I was expecting it to be one of the weaker aspects of the game.  This system procedurally generates the leadership of the orc army giving each captain and warchief a name, strengths, weaknesses, and dynamic conflicts between them that you can interfere with as missions.  Any orc who kills you will also receive a name and be promoted to a captain.  While I was expecting this system to quickly become repetitive, it actually produces a lot of variety.  Each named orc will taunt or boast at you when you encounter them and I did not have a single line repeated through the entire game.  While the conflict missions themselves are fairly limited, they are mostly optional.Graphically, Shdaow of Mordor is a bit of a mixed bag.  While the animation work is very impressive and there is a large variety of orc appearances that removes the common "hey I've seen that enemy before" feeling that most games have, texture quality is not very good and it requires 3 GB of VRAM to run on high textures.  There is also an ultra texture pack that requires 6 GB but it apparently hardly changes anything.  Thankfully the game runs extremely smoothly and performs quite well.  The only other open world-type game I can remember running this smoothly is Tomb Raider.The only big problem I had with the game is the mouse support.  Mouse control is very inconsistent with some mouse smoothing applied and the mouse sensitivity varying wildly in different situations.  Thankfully this is not a shooter so it doesn't interfere with gameplay much.  The one place where this really would interfere is when you are aiming with the bow, though the mouse seems to behave itself there.I highly recommend Shadow of Mordor.  It is definitely one of the best games to come out in 2014 and probably the best Lord of the Rings game to date even though WB is trying to separate it from canon by not using "Lord of the Rings" in its name.  Now, back to killing orcs.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												In all honesty, this game should be renamed to Orc Slaying Simulator or something similar. Shadow of Mordor is a very interesting take on the events that occur between the Hobbit and the Lord of the Rings, and I enjoy how the story fits in with Tolkien's world. However, the story itself was somewhat short for my liking, maybe only taking 10 hours or so of my total gameplay; the rest as I before mentioned, orc slaying. The story follows, Talion, a ranger living with his family and others in Mordor, who are overrun by Sauron's forces, leaving Talion on a quest to fight back against Sauron. The story then follows Talion and a Wraith who he is paired with as they quest across mordor in seek of answers and salvation. Like I said, an interesting story, yet a little short for my liking.The gameplay is excellent, and there are many things to do in the game: kill Orcs, ride beasts, kill Orcs, find collectables, kill Orcs, etc. And even though I keep talking about the game simple being about Orc slaying, it's still very enjoyable in the many ways you can kill Orcs, and even use Orcs to kill other Orcs. My only issue was I found the controls a bit clunky (I use a keyboard and mouse), but when playing with a controller that problem was removed; therefore, if you have a controller, use it.There are only two other issues I have with the game, one being that it's too easy (in my opinion anyway), and the other being that the fact you can choose your character somewhat ruins the game. The hardest part of the game I have to say is taking on high power orc warchiefs who are immune to ranged and stealth attacks, making fighting them in the field the only way to kill them, however even then, I can simply manipulate all the other Orcs into fighting him, and basically get all them to do the work instead. This may be a bit picky of me, as you could say I could just not use the other Orcs, and yes that would certainly make it harder, but even in the strongholds, I can easily escape a fight without dying. I'd just like to see the game being a bit more challenging that's all. The other problem is the character selector the game has, in which I can choose to play as one of the female characters who appears in the late game, which just sort of breaks the game when you're doing missions with her, as there are two of her then. It also sort of ruins the cutscenes, as you're Talion in the cutscenes but then this girl in the game. Maybe again I'm being too picky, but it just seems like a completly unecessary feature. Anyhow, I certainly enjoy the main game, and I'm looking forward to the DLC. I recommend all of you RPG, Stealth, Slasher, and Tolkien fans out there buy this game up.Peace.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
Shadow of Mordor (SoM) is, hands-down, my game of 2014 so far; I loved every minute of it!SoM is a sandbox game of combat & stealth, infiltration, manipulation and assassination, set in J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-Earth. It's been described as Assassin's Creed with the combat of the Batman series, but it has some original and innovative features. It's an AAA game so the graphics are as good as you'd expect and they don't seem to have forgotten about the PC; we have enough video options to push our most powerful graphical cards to the brink.My favourite aspects:True Sandbox: finally, a sandbox game that actually really lets you do your own thing all the time! The missions are instanced but even the scripted storyline missions never try to rein you in; you're always allowed to do it your way! As a bonus, instead of having entire missions dedicated to force you to learn how to use this or that minor new trick, those types of things are usually set as occasional (and fully optional) secondary objectives that you can achieve without deviating much from the approach you really feel like taking.Difficulty, part 1: SoM hits my sweet spot. A single enemy mook is easy to kill, sure, but an entire crowd can quickly become overwhelming. Some enemies are easier to fight than others so things stay pretty challenging because there's always a mix of opponents around. Unlike other games, SoM doesn't "cheat" by magically levelling-up the enemies at the same time you do, so you actually feel like you're getting more and more powerful. Things do become easier bit by bit as you get more practice at playing and gain more powers and options to take down your enemies, but death can still come quickly and swiftly if you don't stay on your toes.Difficulty, part 2: Dying is fun in this game! You still won't like getting killed, sure, but you'll have fun! For one, you won't feel like you're being punished for making a mistake: you won't lose progress, XP or equipment or anything; in fact you'll get a small experience reward for coming back from the dead. What happens when you die is the enemy captains and warchiefs will grow stronger; interestingly, this is all fully transparent to you: you get to watch the results as several individuals rise violently through the ranks of Sauron's army and accumulate more power and experience. The guy who did you in will of course get a big boost to his reputation and career, and it will feel personal to you that he did so at your expense! The game doesn't let you forget it either, so it's even more satisfying when you finally manage to lop his head off the next time around.Dynamic Campaign: the ranks of Sauron's army shift and evolve over time and you have a big hand in shaping this process. Enemy rivals face each other off, ambush or imprison each other, or try to progress by raising their reputation through several means, and you can interfere as you wish, from simply ruining their plans to actually culling them off the face of Middle-Earth to turning them over to your side. You can even to go as far as helping them along the way only to make their fall bigger (and the rewards more juicy). These Captains and Warchiefs are created randomly and have different names, personalities, strengths, weaknesses and, just as important, very different looks. This makes the opposition feel very dynamic and very much alive, even if part of that is just illusion (mechanically speaking there's only so much variety possible between fighting different dudes). Unfortunately, not many other games out there can claim the same.Recon & Intel: the game brings home the value of doing recon and getting good intel on the Captains and Warchiefs you're facing. Some of their strengths can really ruin your day while their weaknesses can turn a very difficult assassination into a simple job. And you want to check if they're nearby least you end up surprised when one (or worse, a few) of them joins the fray you just started. Mechanically speaking, you also get slightly better rewards if you have intel on a Captain/Warchief before you kill them. This seems very well balanced, intel doesn't simply pop out of thin air, but it's also not hard or boring to chase after. As appropriate for a game placing so much importance on stealth it is easy to tell where enemies are, but not so easy that you don't even have to take your eyes off the mini-map to waltz past them.Middle-Earth: there's a reason the setting is so enduringly popular, and it's very well used here; Tolkien Estate wouldn't let it happen otherwise. The two different regions of Mordor available are not very big and there isn't much variety in each of the settings, but they feel just right for a tighter, more focused experience than in your usual sprawling sandbox game. You won't have to get bored out of your skull traversing several kilometres to reach the next mission or hunting hundreds of collectibles the designers placed all over just so you'd have an excuse to actually see all those thousands of square kilometres of map they created presumably for you to chase hundreds of collectibles across.Multiplayer "aware": this is a single-player game, so I was surprised when one of the dynamic mission that popped up asked me to avenge the recent death of one of my steam comrades. This game sure likes to make it personal! Don't worry, Roberto, I got Latbag the Corrupt nice and good for you already!Minor Annoyances:The control scheme for keyboard and mouse feels awkward, at least at first. There's many different keys and combinations of keys to press if you want to trigger different powers; my fingers weren't used to having to do so much gymnastics to trigger different combos/powers, especially in the middle of fights when you're already trying your best to move and dodge and strike. It took some getting used to it, but I'm liking it more now; it adds some complexity and challenge to the mix. My only complain is really about those rare times when the character seems to get stuck for precious seconds against some piece of scenery, or when you wish he'd just let go of the damn ledge and jump down to the ground instead of only descending the cliff/wall one tiny step a time.After the promising short intro with Galadriel's chilling voice, the story starts off like an 80s revenge flick: our hero has his wife and son killed in cold blood right in front of his eyes and is left for dead by the enemy only to now come back seeking vengeance. It's the kind of stuff you used to love when you were a rebellious teenager of limited taste set to give the world a lesson. At least the revenge plot is thematically very consistent with the mechanics of the game so that's a bonus. Also, the story soon distracts you with much more interesting things, like figuring out who's that elf wraith who gives you power and denies you from true death, and all that yummy Middle-Earth background starts pouring in, so... yay!

8.5/10"A bit of everything plus LOTR." Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor is a 3rd person action rpg with "freedom", but don't expect a massive "open-world" like in Skyrim/TheWitcher3. It's recipe for fun: a lil' bit of Batman, a lil' bit of AssassinsCreed and a tiny-tiny lil' bit of Skyrim plus a big pinch of LOTR. The good story line closes the gap between the Hobbit and LOTR. You're Talion a ranger who's stuck between life&death - will you bring him brutal peace?! Pros:+ great fights+ very good gameplay+ very good graphics (but not everything looks "new")+ very good story+ good atmosphere+ good sound&ost+ good voice-acting+ good Orc personalities+ good controls(controls don't feel as "scripted" as in AC)=> U can jump down wherever U like!+ dynamic nemesis system (Sauron's Army)+ side quests don't feel as loveliness as in AC/Batman+ the Vendetta integration (to revenge fallen friends)+ the feeling of: "I am He-Man on BattleCat"+ recommend a x360 pad for full fighting experience+ a 2nd map, what a relief!Cons:- not a large open-world- repetetive locations- still some few control "♥♥♥♥-ups"- if it's not 90degrees = not climb-able- no SLI support => SLI Fix- 2 too easy story boss battles- a coop campaign wouldn't have hurtIt's not a 9.4 IGN, but Splatter & LOTR fans can definately go for it & the rest should wait for a sale...

content:
Posted: October 19, 2014
Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor  Field Rating Review   Graphics 8 Shadow of Mordor isn't the prettiest game out there, and the HD texture pack makes almost no difference. But, that being said, the graphics overall are very well done, with nothing jarring sticking out. But it's certainly no Crysis.   Gameplay 9 This game almost shines flawlessly. You can spend countless hours killing orcs, and every moment is satisfying. The only downfall of the gamplay is the lack of mission diversity, and the fact that eventually, if you want to get an orc promoted, you're going to just have to stand there and do nothing. Because frankly you get a bit too powerful, and captains/warchiefs really pose no threat to you anymore, even in groups. Other than that, you will not find a better, more fluid combat game out there. The diversity of skills and abilities is fantastic, allowing you to fight the way you want to fight.   Story 5 This game has a pretty mediocre story. It's not terrible, but it really isn't good. It's just...there. It takes a backseat to all the killing and joy you will find in the game. Shadow of Mordor attempts to bridge the gap between the events of "The Hobbit" and "The Lord of the Rings." It seems like a silly grab-all, but Shadow of Mordor makes it work. The Lore in the game that you can gather is more interesting, in my opinion.   Replayability 8.5 As fun as it is, you can only kill so many orcs, and again the game's rating is hit by a lack of mission diversity, and things to do other than kill orcs. But that being said, you will spend a LOT of time controlling, murdering, shooting and crushing orcs.    Overall 8/10 Overall, Shadow of Mordor is a must buy for any gamer, anywhere. With extremely satisfying combat, darn good graphics, and fluid gameplay, the only drawback is the lack of solid story. But you will find few other games that will suck your time away so joyfully, and reward you for every minute of it. If you liked this review, feel free to check out my curator page:The TipsterYou are also welcome to join our group and play/discuss games together, here:  The Tipster

Posted: December 6, 2014
												Let me get the negative out of the way.  The portrayal of women in this game is beyond terrible.  It is, across the board, the worst representation of women in games I have ever seen.  Developers need to do so much better than this.  Now, that aside, this is the best action game I have ever played.  The dynamic enemy hierarchies are brilliant, as are their randomly generated strengths, weaknesses, and personalities.  The first time an Uruk I thought I had killed came back with an appropriately changed visual and a burning desire for revenge was amazing.  I think the ability to manipulate the enemies came too late in the game, but it definitely changed how I played the game.The combat system is the best fluid-combo system I have ever seen.  Finally a system where countering takes precedence over everything else, so you aren't constantly getting cheap-shotted in the middle of an animation.  This system is clever, builds well upon itself, and is a tremendous joy to use.  I never got tired of the many various ways I had to murder orcs, and all the ways to use the environment in support of your battle was very good.Story-wise, asides from the portrayal of women, I found the game to be very solid.  I enjoyed the story, I found it interesting and I genuinely wanted to learn more about what was happening. I highly recommend this game, and it is the metric by which I will be comparing all future action games.

OMG- We find some voices of Peter Jackson's films- Drawbacks :- The evolution of Talion pushes the player to solve everything with swords- Nemesis System hasn't a great influence on the game finally- Too close to Assassin's Creed places- Repetitive- Low varied scenery and uninspired- Some situations are overly difficult because badly thoughts- The script, a bit empty finally- We would have liked to get a lock-on for fights- Captains and warlords who simply disappear from the screen when they are fleeing the fight, even if you pursue them. One would like to do the same.Summary :Middle-earth™: Shadow of Mordor™ is fairly complete, rather long, has a terribly addictive combat system and nice graphics. We just regret the lack of inspiration for the sets, bad AI and repetitive nature of the adventure, spent ten hours of play. Nevertheless, the title should appeal to fans of Tolkien, who will enjoy more on Talion, his teammate elf and Sauron returned to Mordor. Others will find an action-adventure open world game well done and quite demanding, which should put their talent to the test. While waiting for a Shadow of Mordor 2 most successful ?

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												Pros/cons at the bottom of review.Beat the game in about 20 hours and got to say it was a solid experience for the most part. In terms of my play time I did a very hefty portion of the side missions/challenges, I wouldn't be surprised if you could beat this game in 5/10 hours if not less but hey the batman games have been the same even skyrim's main quest line so i guess this isn't too out of the norm.  The combat in my opinion surpasses the batman games in smoothness and obviously brutality which is a nice switch up from the fist fighting batarang wielding hero i've loved for the past three games.  The brutality of this game is probs one of my favorite things it had to offer. The lord of the rings movies have always been violent but this game takes it to a whole new level i've always wanted to see. Another great feature that I didn't really expect was the ability to mount the monsters in the game and unleash chaos on your enemies, graugs destroy everything and I love picking up a brave orc commander and biting his head off.... good stuff. One thing that did get me (and i was expecting to see this the whole game) is that none of the orcs manage to mount these beasts especially the caragor which is kinda weird because on more than a few occasions I thought i heard them talking/boasting about mounting these things, guess none of them actually have the balls that our boy talion does. What this game really lacks, something that they should have taken from the batman games, is a line up of real bosses. Yes the nemesis system is cool as well as the lineup of orc commanders but in my opinion most of these guys are like mini bosses at best, unless three or more of these commanders jump you at once they don't really pose that much of a threat especially if you go the extra mile and get the intel on them or mind control a few of his boys. You get one of these commanders in a one on one situation and no matter how strong they are you can take them down with a little planning and common sense (yes this is a rare situation but it happened to me more than a few times in my play through).  The games actual bosses go really south after the first of the black hand you face in mordor, even him I beat on the first try, but the other guy and then sauron are just complete jokes....This game had some alright characters and a good story but the moment you fight the second boss of the black hand I feel like the story goes south and is abit rushed to the conclusion. The game does offer two areas to explore and while they are different in layout I can't help but feel the second area is a grassy reskin of alot of the areas in Mordor, especially how everything is setup in the same plato layout.Pros-runs real smooth (I had no issues with graphic setup or game crashing)-amazing combat system-lots of brutality-solid graphics-runes/upgrade system (abit too easy to get ability points and such but still a good system)-pretty good characters (especially tallion)-caragors and graugs!-good story (until the end)-smooth stealth/climbing-warchiefs /nemesis (even if they are abit too easy I thought this was a very innovative idea)Cons-too easy/lacks difficulty settings-abit too short-lack of "real" bosses-story is "rushed" near the end (in my opinion)-first area and second area feel very similar-some characters are really underdeveloped (again my opnion)-once you gain the abilities to cause fear in orcs through your brutality moves (as cool as they may be) the game becomes drastically easier-lots of quick time events ( I personally dont mind them and rarely found any challenging but I know most people dont care for them)My verdict 8/10All in all I think this games a fun experience and worth playing, I don't really know about the 50$ price tag for 20 hours I got out of it so I would recommend waiting for a sale but its still a great game worth playing through.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Definitely not the best game ever, but it's a damn good game nonetheless.It looks fantastic, even on the lower graphics settings (but, honestly, if you're buying a game because of the graphics you're an idiot), the music is great, the voice acting is great, and everything ties together nicely to make a really good-looking Mordor.The Nemesis system, being the focal point of the game, is obviously done really well. It gets repetitive at times, but overall it was executed fantastically. You can do pretty much whatever you want. You could turn all the Ork captains in an area into your own slaves if you wanted to. You could murder every Orc in the game. That's the beauty of open-world, you can do whatever you want and nobody's going to stop you. It's especially interesting when you get deeper into the game. In my case, I found a nemesis Orc who had existed from the start of the game. This guy killed me several times and had absolutely no weaknesses. After he became a Warchief, I killed him for what I thought would be the final time. And then he returned in one of the final missions as what could be considered one of the final bosses. You'd better believe I felt immense satisfaction in lobbing his head off for the final time.The only detriment to being open-world is that, in most cases, one tends to sacrifice quality of storyline in exchange for the opportunity to roam around and do whatever you want. Only a few games have had good story along with being open-world. Skyrim comes to mind. This, unfortunately, is not one of those games. The story isn't bad, but it really isn't interesting, and the final boss is just a bunch of quick-time events, not actually a battle as one would expect. It does set up nicely for a sequel, which hopefully will actually come around, unlike some games that promised a sequel that never happened (I'm looking at you, Rayman 3).But, point is, there's a hell of a lot to do, everything works nicely, for once death isn't actually a failure state, and all things considered it's a damn good game. Would I pay 50 bucks for it? Hell no, but honestly I wouldn't pay 50 bucks for anything anyways. Grab it on sale when the next sale comes around. Or grab it when it's at full-price if that's your thing. I don't care. But it's a great game, and it would be a shame to not have it.

But the Multi-purpose Buttons sometimes do what you did not intended to do.It would be great to have options to bind them seperately. Sadly there isn't at the moment.About the game It's an Open-World Action game. So get in there and have fun.And I'm surely having so much fun out of it.-Recommended-___________________________________________สวมบทบาทเป็นสุดยอด Wraith แห่งแหวนป่วนทัพเซารอนระบบการต่อสู้ในสไตล์แบทแมนอาร์คัม เหมือนจะพัฒนาไปอีกขั้น ร่วมกับ อนิเมชั่น,เสียงเอฟเฟค,กราฟฟิคตระการตา และที่สำคัญที่สุด ระบบ Nemesis ที่สร้างศัตรูที่มีคุณสมบัติต่างๆ ทำให้ต่อสู้กับกองทัพอูรุคได้เป็นชั่วโมงๆ โดยไม่มีเบื่อเนื้อเรื่องหลักอาจจะสั้นนิดหน่อย แต่ก็มีพวกภารกิจอื่นให้ทำ เกมนี้ เป็นการต่อสู้ซะ 70% เรียกได้ว่าฆ่าออคแทบจะทั้งเกม การต่อสู้ก็ไม่ยากมากเท่าไรตัวเกมไม่มีระดับความยากให้ปรับ แต่เราก็ยังสามารถหาความท้าทายให้กับตัวเองได้ อาจจะด้วยการปิดสัญลักษณ์เคาท์เตอร์ ฯลฯ หรือสู้กับออคเลเวลสูงๆ (แต่ก็ยังง่ายอยู่)เล่นเกมนี้สนุกมาก ขอแนะนำเลย

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
Rumor grew of a Shadow in the East...whispers of a great game in the land of Mordor.Even to a newcomer, Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor is comfortably familiar. It is not a sequel, but it feels like one. Most who play this game will have seen the Lord of the Rings films, or read the books, or played either the Assassin's Creed series or the Batman Arkham series. Shadow of Mordor is greatly influenced by these popular sources. From its gameplay, to its story, to its visual style and soundtrack, this game makes you feel like you're returning to a land that you love. It is, however, this same familiarity that cuts into its longevity.The big innovation that Shadow of Mordor brings to the table is its Nemesis system. Much praise has been heaped upon it. In my view, it works very well in an open world game but it is not without its weaknesses. For example, it is enthralling to cross blades with orc captains when each one feels unique from the others. Yet it also seems impossible for a pseudo-randomly generated boss to match that of a static, hand crafted boss like you'd find in other games. The Nemesis system has quantity on its side and is more true to life but tends not to be as memorable or as fun to fight as those bosses you find in games like Dark Souls or Shadow of the Colossus. To its credit, Shadow of Mordor also has a handful of standard boss  fights throughout its main missions. Unfortunately, the final one is a major letdown in the form of a short series of quick time events.Tolkien's Middle-earth is immensely rich in history. Shadow of Mordor's story utilizes that history mostly for the game's setting, and then makes up the actual plot as its own alternative history. As someone who has seen all the movies but never read the books, I was very pleased that the story was both new to me and still connected to the epic tale we all love. With the exceptions of Gollum, Sauron and a couple brief cameos that I won't spoil, the cast is composed of characters not seen in the films. Not until writing this did I look up to see how close the game sticks to lore and it seems the consensus is that it largely doesn't. Yet this doesn't bother me and, if anything, I wish the game had had more story and was less gameplay centric. This was definitely written more for fans of the movies than for scholars of the Silmarillion.Artistically this game takes most of its cues from the original movie trilogy. Orcs, Elves, Dwarves and Men look and sound as they do in the films. I see that as a good quality. The voice acting is very well done, particularly for video game standards (though those have been rising in recent years). The soundtrack is mostly befitting of the orcs. The heavy percussion, deep horns, cellos and warlike chants can actually become too imposing at times, making me wish for a brief respite.Environmental design I found to be somewhat weak, though it was obviously catered more to gameplay than visual spectacle. Some of that is hard to escape with the first half of the game taking place in the barren, rocky wastes of Udûn. The second half's setting along the Sea of Núrnen is more lush and interesting to look at. Both areas, however, feel relatively small. This is less an artistry complaint and more a wish for greater real estate in which to battle the orcs and beasts of Mordor. The game is never able to imitate the movies' epic, sweeping vistas.At around 30 hours for 100% completion of the main game, Shadow of Mordor is not as long as many similar games out there. Yet in the waning hours I still found myself growing bored. Many of the side quests and a few of the primary missions I could have done without. In particular, the 24 Outcast quests are painfully repetitive and have no business being so numerous other than to pad out play time. It doesn't help that, aside from The Bright Lord DLC, I found this game to be considerably easier than I anticipated.I would list both major DLCs, Lord of the Hunt and The Bright Lord, as disappointing as well. Neither introduces any new areas to explore nor deepens the story in any appreciable way. I will say that the final battle of The Bright Lord is like the end boss we never got in the main campaign. Even still, I wouldn't recommend either outside of the Game of the Year bundle. For some, Shadow of Mordor's familiarity will hurt it sooner than it will for others. For me, it never bred contempt but it did darken an otherwise compelling game.

												I've yet to get far into the game but there's one thing I know and that this game is kind of like the Assassin's Creed series (as well as the Batman Arkham series) but I'll focus more on the similartites to AC.Climbing stuff: ✓Stabbing stuff: ✓Stealth stuff: ✓The ability to tea-bag by rapidly spamming the stealth button: ✓Jumping off things and stabbing stuff: ✓Throwing stabby stuff: ✓Free-roaming the (depressing) world and doing missions at your own pace: ✓Etc, etc, etc.Furthermore, just like in the AC series everyone has a funny accent except now they're ugly.The only difference from AC is that this game actually runs well.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3
												Refreshingly entertaining. Worth a buy for sure, if you like action, stealth, magic, customization, leveling, type games. A bit annoyed that most missions are save 3 guys, it gets old fast. It also feels grindy at time. Once you get the hang of it and it's easy to do it's a lot of fun. Great moves, combos, and finishers. Good pace and fun to play. Not overly difficult and story is engaging. It's pretty linear story with an open world type mechanic but all in all I like it.You basically play a ranger who has 3 types of weapons and two trees of skill. Sword, Dagger, and Bow. As well as Ranger and Wraith. Interesting blend of concepts and alot like the arkham games if you've played those. You can pick where you level up your abilities and what you want to focus on. The bad guys keep coming so you can't really kill them all, this is both good and bad. You can grind for powers or just play, I did a bit of both.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												This game is intricate, complex, and all around really fun. Its a great experience. The gameplay is lots of fun, really exciting, and it doesnt get boring. On the outside it may seem repetetive, but it never feels that way. Every fight you get into, and just any action in general always feels like you are fighting for something. Its like you have a greater purpose and every ork you kill or brand or interrogate is all going towards your cause to liberate Mordor. The story isn't very complex, its simple. This is good though, because its just simple enough to still be very interesting and engaging without taking away from the rest of the game. I just played Assassin's Creed Unity and I found its story to be very lacking, making it hard to enjoy the game because the whoe time I didn't know what was going on. This is not the case in Mordor. On that same note, this has been accused of being an Assassin's Creed clone, it is not in any way. It may look similar due to the parkour and assassination style missions, but after playing ACU and every single other Assassin's Creed I can confidently say these games are all diverse and different.Bottom Line: This game is worth your money and your time, it is a fun, interesting, and fresh experience. I loved every moment of it.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
Would you look at that, a game I preordered that I actually enjoyed immediately and without one of the infamous "day-one update"'s!All joking aside, this game is a blast. The soundtrack is great and the cutscenes are very well done to the point where at times it is almost passable as a movie on it's own. I own a controller and have tried playing with both keymaps (You can switch interchangeably with a button press of either the keyboard or controller, Bonus points!) and I prefer the keyboard controls but can fluidly play with either one.So far the combat system seems a little repetitive and slightly easy at times where I have ran into a group of around eight uruks and picked them off one by one. Definitely not regretting buying this game and can highly recommend to anyone looking for a great single player RPG experience.Edit: The combat system has definitely gotten harder as the game progressed, so my statement about it being easy was taken off.Rating: 9/10TLDR: Great game with interesting characters, awesome combat system, amazing visuals, and hasn't gotten boring yet. Definitely worth buying or renting even if you have to resort to console peasantryEdit: Have died many times now and it doesn't seem to matter how many captains I kill, they keep getting promoted. Currently stuck trying to kill the #$%^ing gul matron because it keeps killing me every time. Probably the most agitating side quest I've done so far in this game.Edit 2: 12.5 hours into the game, killed all the warchiefs except Ratbag and killed the Black Hammer, and am now in the second part of the map that is set near the sea of Nurnen and it looks breathtaking. I'm on medium graphics and am stunned at how good this game looks. Hopefully these quests I have left will be as fun as the first.Edit 3: Just beat the game earlier today and am working towards getting the rest of the collectibles and finishing the side quests. The story mode was fairly short and the ending "Time to forge a new ring" just paves the way for DLC. Still a solid game and still recommend buying.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												This game is very derivative. And I mean that in the BEST KIND OF WAY POSSIBLE. The developers (Monolith) shamelessly borrowed successful mechanics from other high-profile video games, and combined them into some kind of amazing all-star supergame. In this case, they took: The exploration and movement system of Assassin's Creed; the combat of Batman; and the enemy design of Warhammer 40K: Space Marine. Brew that all together, add in a pinch of Sleeping Dogs and Far Cry 3, and you have one of the most ridiculously good open-world action games ever made. Ridiculously fun. I can't recommend this enough.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												At first I was not very impressed with the limited tutorial in this game. But after watching a couple youtube videos, I dove right in and became fully immersed. The melee combat is quite responsive and fluid, and offers a fair amount of excitement. No shortage of gore and carnage!The story and voice acting are top notch. The content is plentiful and satisfactory. The challenge of some of the quests and objectives are not a simple walk in the park, but not impossible either. Which is exactly how I like them to be. Being able to take control of beasts and orcs as well as using environmental objects and traps to hurt and manipulate the enemy was particularly entertaining to me. There really aren't enough of this caliber of hack & slash games for PC out there and I'd like to see a lot more of them. I tip my hat to Monolith and will be paying close attention to their future releases.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												Aside from a few glitches I throughly enjoyed my time with this game.The combat is nice and once you've grow accustomed to the combos it's very satisfying to mow down entire garrisons of orcs by tackling them head on or slaughering them from the shadows. Over time the game throws more advanced enemies in your path giving your a feeling of power as well as challenge.The nemesis system is rather clever - letting you play Vendettas and Klingon politics among the ranks of orcs.The progression system is good enough for a game like this. I've not found it tedious to hunt down the artifacts and experience points to unlock pretty much everything.The only gripes I have with the game are the controls which sometimes glitch out. I've found it very difficult to use bite attacks on any mount and my attempts to block an attack often put me into ranged mode instead. A handful of times I had my character get stuck on some ledge or something and once I was unable to finish a mission. Finally I found the story a bit hard to follow since there's often much time between snippets of story and the format of disjointed flashbacks doesn't help either.But over all I'm still very much glad I played this game. The closest two games I can compare it with are Assassins Creed and Far Cry 3, both of which I consider significantly inferior games to Shadow of Mordor.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												This game is intricate, complex, and all around really fun. Its a great experience. The gameplay is lots of fun, really exciting, and it doesnt get boring. On the outside it may seem repetetive, but it never feels that way. Every fight you get into, and just any action in general always feels like you are fighting for something. Its like you have a greater purpose and every ork you kill or brand or interrogate is all going towards your cause to liberate Mordor. The story isn't very complex, its simple. This is good though, because its just simple enough to still be very interesting and engaging without taking away from the rest of the game. I just played Assassin's Creed Unity and I found its story to be very lacking, making it hard to enjoy the game because the whoe time I didn't know what was going on. This is not the case in Mordor. On that same note, this has been accused of being an Assassin's Creed clone, it is not in any way. It may look similar due to the parkour and assassination style missions, but after playing ACU and every single other Assassin's Creed I can confidently say these games are all diverse and different.Bottom Line: This game is worth your money and your time, it is a fun, interesting, and fresh experience. I loved every moment of it.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												This game has very smooth combat encounters and enjoyable boss fights. There are lots of objectives you can do in addition to the main missions. You can hunt animals and sneak kill some uruks in stealth missions, for example. So the gameplay is pretty good in this game.It can be irritating to fight some bosses when there are many other bosses nearby. I tried to encounter one captain and suddenly there were 2-3 other captains and enormous horde of minions all around me. That can be a good thing if you are looking for challenge (like me).The plot in this one left a lot to be desired. I wasn't impressed by the first cutscene and did pretty much skip the rest. And the main missions' objectives were not that interesting.All in all I would recommend this game because the lack of top notch storyline isn't that much of a problem when you have many hours of very enjoyable gameplay ahead of you.

												The combat system is fluid and great to behold (being based on the same system as Batman) and the options for tackling the open world are huge; from brainwashing an ork captain to attack his superior to teleport-executing a sentry from 100s feet away. Viceral, solid entertainment and the kind of game I pick up not to make further progress or level up, but simply because it's fun. I can spend ages just hunting for large groups of orks to jump into the middle of and dispatch without taking a hit; lobbing one through a camp fire, skewering another through the throat, leaping over another to stun them before making their head explode - all the while effortlessly parrying and ducking.Great fun and an excellent title to show off your graphics processor!

content:
Posted: October 15, 2014
												This is by far one of the best LOTR games out there, up there with the LOTR: The Battle for Middle-earth series (an RTS).  This game makes some massive changes from any games set in Tolkien's world.  It takes place between The Hobbit and the LOTR trilogy, with an entirely new story set in and around Mordor, and all new characters.  It does a fairly decent job of not messing with any kind of lore in a bad way too.  New characters, as well as familiar ones are in the game.  You play as Talion, a man who should have died but for reasons unknown to him has come back to the world of the living, and has been connected to a wraith of an ancient and dead elf.  This will provide you with many cool powers, and the fact that you can't truely die makes the nemesis system even more interesting.The combat is akin to that of the Batman: Arkham games, and Assassin's Creed.  You have multiple weapons at your disposal, each with their own rune slots, as well as a skill tree to level up.  Take a stealthy approach with bow and dagger, as well as environmental weapons you can trigger, or run in and make some heads roll with your sword.  The nemesis system is a really amazing thing as well.  Orcs get promoted for killing you, or just randomly if a space is open, and eventually can become warchiefs.  Captains and warchiefs all have their own strengths and weaknesses, and different kinds of attacks and weapons as well.  There's a lot of cool stuff you can do with that as the game goes on.  Also, you can "kill" captains only to have them come back later a bit more mutilated than before.  If you met them before, they will remember you.  Things like this make the enemies you encounter a bit more interesting.  I have encountered some weird bugs that forced me to end missions and teleport to a tower.  Getting stuck inside walls and glitching through some buildings to areas I can't get out of.  Not a ton of that stuff, but it's there.  The only thing I can not speak for is the DLC.  So far, I have not heard much about what has so far been released.  What I have heard of so far doesn't sound bad...but maybe overpriced.Overall, a really great game and definitely worth playing.  Especially if you like LOTR.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2016
												Rating: 9/10Overview: Open World Third Person RPGThe Good:+ Very well optimized, plenty of graphical options + Story and characters are well thought out. You don't need to be Lord of the Rings fan to understand what's going on. Cut scenes are really well done. + The nemesis system is a random boss generator. Enemies that kill you get promoted to captain making them much tougher.  By collecting intel either by finding or interrogating enemies you can discover randomized strengths and weaknesses for captains and warchiefs that you can exploit. The system itself is decent but the way its implemented in the game is what sets it apart.   + The orcs in the game are the best representation of orcs in a Lord of the Rings game I've ever played. They gang up on you in numbers, run in terror when you kill a captain or warchief etc. Everything about them make it feel like your battling a huge orc army.+ The combat is a near replica of Rocksteadys Batman games. You have a strike, dodge, stun and counter. By combing these together and getting your combo meter high enough you can then unleash more devastating moves.  + Lots of side quests, collectables, missions etc that are varied and provide a nice distraction from the main quest. + A well balanced upgrade system. Most open world games either have an upgrade system that is pointless or one where you become way too powerful early on. This is one of the first times where the upgrade system is well balanced so that you don't get too powerful too early on, but makes each individual upgrade feel like you are making real progress. + Stealth is a big component of the game and is handled incredibly well. Again it's a near identical system to Rocksteadys Batman games. + Killing Captains or Warchiefs drop runes which can then be slotted to upgrade either your sword, bow or dagger. Plenty of different runes to fit your play style. + Both DLC and Trials of War add a lot of extra content to the game. Trials of War is a series of different trails with requirements, complete them and see how you do on the leader boards. + SoundtrackThe Average:The game can be a bit frustrating in the early sections. Some missions send too many enemies at you making it very frustrating if not impossible to complete. In these situations your only option is to run away and try the mission again.  Conclusion:Shadow of Mordor is a great game that borrows heavily from different games and puts it together in one complete package. Take the combat and stealth from batman with the traversal of assassins creed add in the lord or the rings universe and you have what is essentially Shadow of Mordor. I consider this a great open world game but I wouldn't put it in the same ranks as a "Game of the Year" contender. This is not a fault on the game per se but open world fatigue is starting to set in for me. The game has all the prerequisites of a great game but doesn't push the boundaries in the genre. If anything I think its biggest problem is that it plays it too safe. The nemesis system is cool but not enough to elevate it to a higher status.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												The good, the bad and the ugly.The good... Combat mechanics. A perfect blend of some of the best fighting elements borrowed from recent Batman games flavoured with a decent amount of Assasin’s Creed parkour. Slashing, bashing and trashing, its all there in a perfect Uruk discrimination package filled with disemboweling, cutting off limbs, bone crushing and of course tons and tons of whatever stuff runs though orc veines. Need some tutoring on how many ways there are to kill an orc? Look no further. This game will provide you with more than enough insight on that particular topic. The combat is generally very responsive, it feels right no matter what type of controls you are using, gamepad or mouse/keyboard combo. Whatever you do, combat will probably never be the reason for any of the problems you might experience in the game.Ingame cinematics. Oh boy… Some of the cinematics made for this game are pretty much movie theater material, going on par with LotR movies themselves. They are also the main source of the game’s narrative so it would be pretty unwise to skip them unless you are only after some orc blood.The bad…If you are after some decent story from the expanded LotR universe you will probably be heavily disappointed. Yes there are some interesting plot twists which fit nicely with the original LotR lore but the buildup and the anticlimactic conclusion leave much to desire. There is also a huge amount of pointless story missions which pretty much only serve to add some effective game time and bore the player to death in the process. Poisoning Uruks with grog and destroying Mordor’s cultural heritage as main storyline quests!? Cmon! Give me a break.“Though you shall have no meaningful UI” was probably what the publisher said prior to releasing this game for PC. Having to leave the game and open up the main menu every time there is need to adjust weapon runes or simply pick up an orc target in the Uruk hierarchy is pretty time consuming and frustrating.Environmental interaction. As much as the controls themselves are fine, for both gamepads and keyboard/mouse combos, interaction with the environment can be often pretty frustrating. Picking up a perfect path to reach a fleeing boos often ends in a total disaster just because the main character likes to stick to every damn thing that comes even remotely close to his path. This effectively means that instead of jumping off from a high vantage point in order to pin down a boss to the ground you will find yourself suddenly hanging from a wooden beam which just happened to be near the jump path halfway through the jump. There are also some problems with the controls which change their behavior depending on the situation. The best example would probably be “drop down” which is usually reserved for “E”, however if you are on a ledge or a line of rope it suddenly changes to down (“S”) which can often lead to situations where players don’t actually know which “down” they should use.The skill progression system. Its not that skill progression is bad. Its simply that some of the most interesting skills are unlocked almost at the very end of the main story line. Branding, chained mass executions, caragorn mounting… Those are all skills that greatly add to the experience but require access to top skill tiers which on the other hand require a lot of side mission grinding. Players will probably feel unnecessarily locked out of stuff that they should have been able to use from a more reasonable moment in the game.The ugly…The graphics. It would probably be unfair to call the game ugly but its surprisingly shocking to see how little effort was put into creating imaginative levels which even remotely represent the quality we got used to from other LotR games or even movies. The map feels bland with repetitive sections which feel like a simple copy/paste from the terrain seen just a minute before. It doesn’t help that it got divided into two distinctive parts because the second part also feels like the first one just with added vegetation. There is simply no diversity and no “wow” effect we got used to for anything LotR related. In all honesty I haven’t been able to test any of the graphics modes which require more than 2GB VRAM but I highly doubt that any texture pack could resolve the problem of bad level design and lack of imagination while creating the map for this game.The overall lack of gameplay diversity. Aside from the main story, a couple of types of challenge missions and some collectables there is actually nothing to do in the game. Challenge missions are picked from a poll of three or four mission types which seem to repeat endlessly. Simply put, if hacking and slashing orcs for hours isn’t something you get easily entertained with then chances are you will get bored to death in Shadow of Mordor.Would I recommend this game? Yes I would. But its important to make a note about the target audience which will enjoy it. Players which expect some deep meaningful LotR experience with huge amount of RPG elements will be disappointed. On the other hand players that don’t mind killing orcs for hours in a GTA mission style oriented game will probably enjoy it.If there wasn’t for an interesting combat system the lack of any meaningful story and bad level design would have probably made me rate this game 6/10. However, short-term enjoyment of the combat system earns this game a 8/10 from me.
