content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Middle Earth Shadow of Mordor is the new game based on Lord of the Rings series but will you want to play this ? In Middle Earth Shadow of Modor we play as Talion. One day Talion and his family is killed by the black hand to summon the wraith but gets himself fused with Celebrimbor who is suffering amnesia. So him and Talion try to find out who is Celebrimbor and to avenge the death of Talion's family. So how is this game ? This game is a fantastic game and everyone who needs to play through this game at least once. The game is like Assasins Creed and Batman Arham games fused together to create this. You can freely roam around the map and do what you like. Theres tons of stuff to do and lots of stuff to see. The game also looks really good maxed out. The gameplay is smooth and is really satisfying. Stealth is also really fun. The game is never too easy but never unfair and is a blast to play through. The game's story is fantastic and you get attached to the charecters and you do want to make it to the end which is not good. Yeah the ending to this game was dissapoiting and is sequel/dlc bait. The game also has bugs. Sometimes when jumping and grabbing onto the ledge my charecter wouldnt let go no matter what i did. The game is one of the best games i played in a while and i definetly reccomend getting this game and playing through it once. I give Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor a 9/10

Posted: May 6, 2015
												At first I wasn't really interested - it looked like it's going to be AssCreed or hack'n'slash, which I find boring.  But then it turns out to be like a Batman and now I'm having lots of fun. And all I know about Middle-earth is that Tolkien wrote something about it and someone made some popular movies.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												After watching The hobbit the battle of the five armies I really wanted to play a game related to LOTR, So I played The Battle for Middle-earth II. After being desecrated by an army of Ents Orcs and Nazgûls I rage-unistalled the game and looked for a differant LOTR game. I found this, after downloading 40 ♥♥♥♥ING GIGABYTES worth of game I started to play. The whole game is a hack and slash Orc holocaust simulator. The Orcs might aswell be nazis with no redeemable qualities: All the chatter you hear from them include "I really like killing things" and "Living things better watch out becasue I might kill them!" It actually makes the Orcs seem really insecure with every silence being filled in with thier own version of small talk. Now onto combat the whole combat system was probably ctrl+c ctrl+v from Batman to Shadow of Mordor with the standard counter attack stun combo system, However that isn't a bad thing: I personally think its better that a game has a working, established and old combat system. Rather than trying to create its own which will most likely end up feeling like darksouls with polio. *NOTE* They cleverly renamed batmans gadgets to wraith powers.Size, The map is small-ish. It  never really feels vast but it also never feels small. I think considering what the player has in terms of travel and what the game offers the map is an ideal size. Story, I honestly found it hard to care for the protagonist or the problems he faces, but I don't think the game was made with story as a high priority.Conclusion, If you like any of the following: LOTR, Batman, Mindless slaughter, Mud, People Talking about axes and killing then I'd recommend looking into this game, its a really fun mindless hack and slash. 8 Orc WarLords/10

content:
Posted: September 12, 2015
												I played this game through doing all the main game quest, meaning all of the main quest, Outcast rescues, Ithildin collection and artifact collection. I also did all the survival challenges and nearly every hunting challenge. I used some time to grind a few specific achievements. All of this took me about 26 hours.The game seems pretty well optimised, with the FPS staying confidently at and over 60 on my GTX 960 and high settings (if I remember right). The game looks great and the animations are smooth and they vary enough to instill gasps of delight even after many hours of playing. At least with me the game didn't crash at any point and I did not encounter any bugs or glitches whatsoever.Even though I am somewhat sceptical about open world games these days (open world seems to be an excuse to put soulless collection-/busywork-ish sidequests without any other real thought process what makes open world interesting) I think it worked out pretty well with Shadow of Mordor. The world (= the two main quest areas) are large enough so that you don't have to look at the same valleys and mountains all the time, but it's small enough so that empty travel does not take too much time. Eventually when you unlock all the necessary skills the world is full of exciting stuff to sink your time in. You can stalk orcs, listen to their jammering, then drop a fly nest on their heads and go gut the lot. You can interfere in the internal politics via simple automatically generated quests that show you the everyday life of an evil guy warhost commander. These mechanics also play a big part in the actual main quest, which I find was executed pretty nicely. In a way it might seem at times unnecessarily grindy and repetitive, but more often than not it is interesting to raise an interesting and cool orc captain. Help him rise through the ranks to eventually become a warchief, then arrange a fight to the death with this thing that is practically your own child by now. In the long run the system starts to shift in to the dull side. The training of captains isn't really necessary for other things besides your own enjoyment and the main quest (you also get more powerful runes if you kill high level captains, but at least I found the runes to be nice and helpful bonuses, but not something that need to be farmed in order to get through the game).Orc captain/warchief system is adequately large enough so that you probably won't encounter two similar boss-orcs during one play through. The somewhat-emergent gameplay system helps you to form a kind of personal connection with the enemies and they actually seem to have a personality every now and then. All the different names and outfits the orcs wear are not probably too canon, but they make for a good game.The story in Shadow of Mordor is a let down. It is a basic vengeance quest with the protagonist avenging the death of his family and trying to save the world in the meantime. Whereas the orcs you encounter might occasionally have an interesting personality, the supporting friendly characters are pretty soulless and uninteresting, the only possible exception being a certain hunter dwarf. Boss fights seem a bit forced and are too simple considering how fun and engaging the captain system is. Especially the main boss was a let down in many senses, ranging from the story to the execution.There is no question that Shadow of Mordor is a wonderful game with unique gameplay systems, awesome visuals and enough gameplay to keep you engaged but not too much that one would get bored. In the long run the nemesis system starts to lose its edge and might become a chore, but you will probably finish the game before that happens. Only real downside is the lackluster story, which fortunately is not too large a focus. It seems that in many ways this game has managed to dodge several pitfalls: you can see that the potential of crappiness is there, but it has been artfully averted with right design decisions and systems that far outweigh the downfalls.

number of helpful: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												★★☆☆☆A functional, but uninspired blend of Assassin's Creed and Arkham City, with a weak LotR theme, limited mostly to name dropping, and even weaker graphics.  Expect to die, a lot, until endgame, when you can take on every orc in the world at once.  + Combat mounts+ I got the Season Pass somehow?+ Hunting & Gatherting mini quests+- Fast travel, rather spread out+- Arkham Combat, but Arkham City did it better+- Assassins Creed free running, but ACB did it better+- Weapon runes add minor stat customization, can buy more OP ones in DLC+- Varying performance on a 970, sometimes 90+ FPS, other times sub30.  This seems to be due to ultra Shadows.+- Branding.  Mind control enemies.  The best feature in SoM, but they save unlocking it until halfway through the story.  On top of that, its not unlocked for any meaningful reason, just "OK, lets brand now!"+- Sauron's Army.  Enemy rival system, over hyped.  Hardly has an effect, especially later in the game, when you're unlikely to die and/or brand them all.  The way it only updates when you die isn't enjoyable either.  Its also required for story progress, which makes it feel even less like a natural and dynamic part of the world.  The way orcs visually upgrade, and remember you if you and/or they die (but somehow survive) is interesting, and it gives you the option to take out captains before going for the warchief to make things easier.  Could be a much better system if integrated better, instead of as a punishment for death.  - No multiplayer/coop- Can't replay missions- Clunky camera angles- Insta-fail stealth missions- Seperate zones to load between- Jump dodge rarely works, if ever- Weak graphics, even with the HD pack- Progression has no impact on the world- Some interactions only work in ghost mode- The only character customization is pay2dlc skins- Poorly written story, with practically no relation to LotR- Combat lacks the quickfire gadget variety of Arkham City- Mid-combat healing is handled very oddly, picking flowers- Attacks in combat don't knock down enemies in a single hit- Flurry finisher animation has no iframes until you upgrade it- Never visit any memorable, recognizable, or interesting locations- Expect to die, a lot, as an integrated part of the game and progression- Being low on health has an annoying mute + heartbeat effect on sound- Open world is mostly empty nature space, with non-stop enemies to kill- Upgrades are locked behind multiple gates and split between multiple currencies- You play as not-Aragorn.  This replacement is unlikeable, selfish, and poorly written- Inaccurate sloppy combat.  Counter inputs can fail, finisher inputs can fail, finishers can hit the wrong target, fury strikes can hit the wrong target, target friendlies, timing on the combo system doesn't feel right, etc* Controller required

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												I enjoyed my time with Shadow of Mordor. The combat is "Arkham-esque" in a good way. The feeling of being powerful is a lot of fun. The nemesis system has to be experienced to be appreciated but it adds a interesting element of love/hate to the enemies who would be otherwise nameless grunts being mowed down under your sword. If you don't already know the nemesis system is the hierarchy of the Uruks (orcs) and as you defeat a higher ranking soldier, or if they defeat you, they will rise in the ranks of the army gaining power. Later in the game you obtain the ability to brand Uruks and they will join you in your fight and you will protect them as they go through challenges to become more powerfull. I do have some criticism to the game. It is an open world game but the world feels mostly empty of everything but enemies and an occasional NPC. There was a fair amount of button prompt kills which are overplayed. The story is interesting but without giving anything away....I felt the ending was somewhat hollow. The graphics are wonderful, but the color pallate is somehat bland. Enemy AI is acceptable, if a little lackluster and although I still had fun with the sneak kills, it was perhaps overly generous with stealth detection.All that being said, I had a lot of fun and I would certainly recomend it if you like the fast over the top combat of Arkham Asylum but with swords, gory executions, and orcs.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												I just picked up this game on Christmas and I have to say I'm genuinely impressed with the Nemesis system.I have no problem admitting when I was wrong, and I was definitely wrong when I claimed "it will be just ♥♥♥♥♥♥ level scaling under a new marketing name". It's not, not even close.It's an interesting system that I can't wait to see expanded even more in future (eventual?) titles.Of course, it has its limitations and in the long run you'll start noticing some repetition, but it's still noteworthy. Uruk's dynamic hierarchy, an *enormous* amount of aesthetic differentiation and their ability to memorize their previous interactions with you (in a simplified way, of course, but it works) all contribute together to make mooks feel like real characters who play a part in your story. Sometimes even a memorable one.Before I familiarized with the system enough to learn how to exploit every single weakness the game even manage to give me my actual nemesis.This ♥♥♥♥er of a hunter captain started as immune to melee attacks (which were at first the only subsystem I was somewhat familiar with) and opened his way into becoming a virtually un-killable beast just kicking me on my teeth every single time.He wasn't just hard to kill, he also dealt a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of damage with his poisonous spear, and he turned constantly out of nowhere even when I was facing other commanders.He became my nightmare until I had a chance to exploit his only actual weakness, which was fire and explosive stuff.And of course he never stopped remembering me how many times he already kicked my♥♥♥♥♥or forced me to retreat.When I finally got how to deal with him and managed to kill the sucker I cheered, then I had to stop for a moment to realize "Goddammit, how cool was that?".Now, for the bad parts. What I liked the least about the game (beside the dull plot and the long-term sense of repetition, which to be fair is almost inevitable) was the Assassin's Creed-inspired collect-a-thon garbage.I get it's optional stuff, but Jesus Christ, when you are designing a world and your idea to fill the map is "We should totally put in dozens and dozens of shiny spots that reward you with 50 exp each one", you need to stop and reconsider what you are doing.Coming just out of Dragon Age: Inquisition forced me to think how much this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ way to design content is becoming popular for some inexplicable reasons.The worst part: not a single one of these boring activities lead to any climax with a final reward. They are literally there just to be there.Here's my suggestion, dear game designers: the next time you feel like you need to hide "treasures" in the game map, don't bother with hundreds. Put in ten-twenty of them at most, but be sure that finding them is a bit more challenging/interesting and the reward a bit more exciting (alternate weapons?, unique upgrades? alternate outfits, maybe even with their unique bonus/malus? etc).You'll be surprised by how much more "filled with cool stuff" the world will actually feel, even if there is factually more empty space.Anyway, I'm overall pleased with the purchase and I would recommend the game.P.S. In case you are on the fence because of the similarities, it'w worth noting that I can't stand Assassin's Creed games and I still enjoyed this a lot.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Shadow of Mordor feels similar to the Assassins Creed and Batman games in the way that it plays. I enjoyed this more than both of those games however, mostly due to the excellent fluid sword combat. The Orc hierarchy system, in which Orcs who kill you rise through the ranks becoming increasingly powerful, is also unique and interesting. The world at first felt somewhat sparse, but plenty going on once you start exploring. Be warned, the game has a steep learning curve at times, but you can find a way to progress without too much difficult if you think laterally. For example, whilst I never really got stuck, I did encounter a particular Orc Captain who was practically invincible. Luckily none of the actual War Chiefs were quite so tough, so it didn't prevent me from progressing to the second greener setting in the game. Overall it's a fun experience with an okay story, pleasing graphics and presentation, that you will certainly enjoy if you are looking for an open world game of this type.

Product received for free
												This game stays true to its Genre, an open-world/action/adventure game. Being a bit different combat wise, it did take some time to get used to it. The combat system though a bit glitchy at times, is one of the best things about the game. For first couple hours strategies to kill uruks would be better but once you advance through the story the combat becomes relatively easy. The graphics are fine and the side missions are good too. Although the story is just average the best thing about the game itself is that when you die, the story still advances and the uruk who kills you gets promoted. :DLast but not the least hunting is good too, but limited to 2 creatures. And because the map is not that big you can run through the whole map in no time so hunting doesn't make too much of a difference. Till the end you keep getting new skills so the game doesn't get repetitive and because the storyline is not that long even if you get bored you can take a couple of hours and finish the game. I would recommend this game, but only on sale, doesnt justify the full price being single plater.

Posted: December 11, 2015
Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam groupFew words about the gameShadow of Mordor is quite good adventure-action game and, let's face it, if you want to freeroam a bit in LOTR universe, it's one of a kind game for now. Gameplay is not best one around, yet alot of games could learn thing or two from this game about its mechanics. As a LOTR devotee, with all those simple and old or LEGO games placed in this universe, i had to play it. Personally, I recommend it to everyone who finds tons of orks somehow sexy and finds enjoyment in running around behind enemy lines where everyone wants You dead.Advantages - Graphics really amazed and surpriced me, I really wasn't expecting that many details to be polished - Sounds in games are pretty good with variety of snarls, mumbles and roars, although voicing of characters could be done a little bit better - Story in game is good and well told, somewhat short but still good - Pretty good combination of stealth and action with really nicely done mechanics of movementDisadvantages - Gameplay quite disappointed me. It was fun for the first 2-3 hours where you get to know with what was going on etc. but after that you can clearly see that it's REALLY repetetive but you know, personal preferences here, most people probably would enjoy that after all. - Combat system is simillar or even same as in Batman: Arkham Origins. Enemies are slow, attack you one by one and it's really, really easy to dodge / counter them. - Gets annoyingly repetitive after few hours of fighting hordes of UruksIf you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												THIS IS STORY SPOILER FREE REVIEW (I'll limit the story to tutorial)Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor is TPP Assassin's Creed like action game. You play as a Talion - ranger banned from death, seeking the one who refused death to him. His family is getting killed with him but he managed to hmm "respawn". He's connected to weird ghost who's name I won't reveal. This allows Talion to read minds, use slow motion and Azkâr bow, and further on he gains abillity to make orcs fight on his side, and some other cool stuff. Talion is also equipped with Urfael sword and Acham dagger. The game mostly allows you to choose if you want to sneak into somewhere, bring death to all of enemies on your path or create a little distraction releasing caragors etc. This game is pretty much about killing orcs or making them kill each other. There's a very deep nemesis system which allows orc thatkilled you to become captain, and if he's a captain already he can gain Power. Captains fight each other, go hunting, recruit other orcs, set traps, betray themselves, participate in executions etc. Captains can become Warchief's bodyguards. Warchief is highest tier in Sauron's Army. If you want to kill Warchief you've gotta lure him out doing something game asks you to for instance killing X of Y in stealth, releasing Z caragors. If you haven't killed Warchief's bodyguards they'll be with him to help him fight with you. If you dominated one of them before and left your mark on them they can start fight just on the press of an button. You can upgrade your arsenal with runes dropped by Captains and Warchiefs. The higher the Power they have the higher level of runes. You can buy up to 5 slots for runes on every weapon. There are a lot of side activities in this game and they're pretty fun, e.g. Vandetta, where you have to kill certain captain that killed your friend or if you don't have any friends (well, dead friends) it'll choose outside your friend list. You can also release slaves, do legend missions for all of your three weapons, help your orc captains in a hunt, duel and other things, search for artifacts, etc. Little warning here: the story is pretty short. I would not advise you buying this game for full price if you are not going to do "at least" a lot of side activities. I bought AC4 for similiar price and it kept me in for much longer. That doesn't mean I did not enjoyed wandering around Mordor. If you want to do this game at least on 70% and you would like to play Assassin's Creed with Batman combat in Tolkien's world - go for it.79/100Awaiting 2nd game with MUUUUCH longer storyline and more difficulty levels (there's only 1 in this game and it gets super easy quite fast considering it's short which makes it not as fun).

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor has been one of the best games I've played, this is one of the best or THE best LoTR game that exists. You play as Talion a ranger in charge of guarding the Black gate until an attack overruns the guard and you are sacrificed with your family in an attempt to bring an ancient elf lord (Celebrimbor), yet in this attempt the wraith binds with Talion and thus you emerge as The Gravewalker.  The events of the game take place between The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings. I have to be honest, if you are in any way a fan of TLoTR franchise either by books or movies this is a game that you must own. Really. In the game you will face against Saurons armies. The nemesis system of the game remembers the player's interactions with specific types of characters they encounter and adjusts the manner in which these characters react to the player throughout the game. As I mentioned: If youre a fan you'll have tons of fun slicing thru waves of Orcs and Uruks and using the weapons and abilities to their fullest to experience the game in every way. If youre not a fan then I'd still recomend the game since it is so much fun.The graphics in this game are beautiful. For me, they really captured what I imagine Mordor would look and feel like. Enemies and creatures sprawl the lands that you can choose to fight, sneak or run past.There are only three things that irked me in this game: 1. the controlls are sometimes clunky (note* only in some places where you want to jump or drop and Talion either gets stuck or jumps or drops the wrong way)2. The end fell a bit short to me. 3. Game sometimes felt a bit too easy, yet you are bound to the wraith so that explains the power that you wield against the enemy (think: maybe around the same or greater power than the Nazgûl)Honestly this has been a great game that had me to the edge of my seat from beginning to end. Never thought it would be so much fun to slay waves upon waves of orcs and uruks, destroying the armies of the dark lord of Mordor. Obviously fighting the captains and warchiefs is the most fun and rewarding of all.EDIT for DLC- The Bright lord & Lord of the HuntIn the Bright Lord you play as Celebrimbor, the wraith that took into Talion in the main game but also the famous Elven Lord Smith form the Simarillion, it starts before the events of Talion (a couple hundred years) and sets you right after Celebrimbor has stolen The One Ring from Sauron. The meat of the DLC is the twin of the main game. brand the warchiefs and force them to a fight with Sauron.In Lord of the Hunt the DLC introduces the new Beastmaster Warchiefs into the game, and involves Talion joining with Torvin using his powers of Domination to turn these new beasts against the Warchiefs, proving that Mordor cannot be tamed. The creatures you fight in this DLC are well done and a challenge to overcome.IMHO: 9/10 Increadibly fun game with a great system that fits to you and what you do. Hardcore LoTR fans: this is a MUST buy.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												The first thing to ask with this game is quite simply: Is it the 3rd-person Assassin's Creed/Arkham/etc that it looks like? Answer... yes. And yes, the majority of the game touches on nothing new or exciting there. HOWEVER. There is the nemesis system.The Nemesis sytem does exactly what it says it will - it makes you enemies. Some of these enemies will give you a brutal makeover everytime you meet them. Some of them are so easy you barely notice they're harder than normal mobs. However, the brilliant thing with this is that you don't need a constantly changing landscape or storyline to progress - your enemies and THEIR rivalries and development ARE the changing landscape. You will hear normal mobs discussing their captains and their progress as you wander around in stealth. You'll hear rumors being spread of the times when you go in and slaughter billions of orcs one day, and you'll hear them asking their captains 'how they beat that ranger'. THAT is awesome, and this kind of developing characters is the future for this kind of gaming.When I first saw Assassin's Creed, I remember thinking 'Now, these boss scenes are amazing, you go into huge techincal planning, and a bit of fly-by-ear in approach, but it's a shame the boss fights themselves are so frigging dull.' Nemesis answers this, and answers it well.I remember the horror in looking at a particular foe I'd accidently died a couple of times to and realising that he no longer HAD a weakness. Worse, he was immune to pretty much everything - no missiles. No stealth. No battle combos. No finishers. I couldn't jump over him. He blocked normal attacks from the front. All I had left was chipping away very slowly at his health using finishers and wraith moves. Oh, and did I also mention that he lived in one of the forts, so there were usually at least two other captains near him 90% of the time?So I tried ignoring him. But he had a taste for my blood, and actively went out in hunting groups for me with other captains! I lost count to how many times he'd killed me. The satisfaction of FINALLY killing him came when I managed to set him on fire, and, for the first time ever, saw him running, all immunities forgotten. I beat the bejesus outta him, and felt immensely satisfied for doing so. Then I realised. This wasn't a stunningly hard boss that someone had intricately created to puzzle and perplex me. This was a boss that I had made (albeit by screwing up and very bad luck on his random rolls), but this enemy I'd just got such satisfaction out of finally figuring out and defeating - this guy had started out a normal mob who'd happened to get lucky and stabbed me. Damn. Now THAT is progress - this game makes real, tough enemies, and not because they're OP. not because they're some ingenius plan that neds exactly the right combo to beat, but because you're fighting an inexorable army that grows and progresses as you do.I would've liked to see more from the game in terms of a greater range of difficulty in it's enemies (I genuinely would like foes that are genuinely lacking in weaknesses, or where you have to combine more than one weakness to make it plausible to beat them ordinarily (or even force you to use the special events to try and weaken them a bit before pouncing on them) - I'd have liked more types of foes at times, and other portions of Sauron's army of darkness to go up against, more of a range similar to the critters you get - Ghul, etc, and more different location types for the orks to live in - condensed, claustrophobic tunnels full of them would be fun alternatives; but these are probably coming up in expansions, and I KNOW this will be covered by other, future games built on a similar premise. In fact, I can already see the next step of Nemesis systems - the stage when the whole systems learns from you. When it works out which traits tend to utterly screw you up and will be capable of keeping the pressure at a constant high by making you develop your skills to suit, whether it be to power up the harder parts of your skills, a piece at a time, or by progressing like a seesaw - underuse one item or skill type purposefully so that suddenly, you can drop back into it to dominate for a time against foes too used to massacreing you in one way, just to switch to another.I also respect the skill and precision in making all things potential flaws in enemies or potentially lethal to you - the Hatreds is a brilliant answer to things that might otherwise just squish every ork out there. I remember the horror on realising that the Graug, my ultimate weapon at the time, was being killed by a single ork because, hey, he hated them and beat the crap out of them. Worse, i couldn't kill him because A) it might kill me easily, and B) Hatred was on him, so he was on full regen and pummel-inducing adrenaline.So I've got to hand it to the makers - this game will be the root of a generation of games, and I cannot wait to see them.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
												Finally we have a LoTR game worthy of many hours of our time! Shadow of Mordor brings free roaming adventure and game changing new features together to make one amazing game. One of those games where you get lost in its mechanics and find yourself putting the story on the back burner. For me that's a good sign of a game with good longevity.Nemesis system is great, combat is satisfying and gory to boot. Story is there but I find myself making my own story to enhance the main one. RPG elements are there. I especially like how the weapons upgrade with ruins you collect off of war chiefs or other notable enemies. Graphics are great. There is not much tediousness that comes with the open world genre. You can fast travel pretty readily conveniently. But this is one of those worlds where I prefer to get lost in and take that short cut threw the woods.Even if you are not a fan of Lord of the Rings check this game out. It is an amazing game on its own.If you are a die hard Tolkeinite the lore should not be that blasphemous to you either.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Shadows of Mordor is a game that, mysteriously, contains ideas that UBI soft initially advertised as contained in 2012-2014 FLOP of a title, Watch_Dogs.  An open-world experience complete with an intelligent and dynamic method of interacting within the world and watching stories unfold based on your choices and actions as well as failures (IMO, that's the best part of Shadows of Mordor: the one that omitted from a game about digitally manipulating an Orwellian world where you can know everything about everyone.)Take an open-world third person perspective, slap it with a Lord of the Rings coat of paint, give it "Assassin's Creed"-like movement and parkour, and implement a response-based combo timing system a-la the proprietary "Batman Arkham" series titles from WB as well and VOILA: you have Middle-Earth, Shadow of Mordor.TL;DR20/10 orc heads, would impale (and be impaled by Ratbag the Coward) again.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												Shadow or Mordor is simply a fun and well-made action game. You will fight, slash, stab, shoot, throw. Sometimes you will devour while mounted on a beast. Other times you will mind control. Some other times again you will mind control a captain to kill another captain.  The game ultimately ends up as a sandbox experience, an uruk-manipulation-simulator where you have tons of fun trying to come up with new ways to mess with and kill these silly not very smart, yet tough creatures. Best part of the game is the personal touch it gets when an orc kills you and mocks you afterwards. He gets a name, a promotion, a mental and physical personality, and you can seek him out for revenge. If you don’t succeed, you will be farther mocked an insulted, which feels great!The game succeeds in letting you feel as an ultimate bad♥♥♥♥♥ especially as your skills grow during the game. You end up so insanely overpowered after a while, that only a few enemies remain a challenge. But at this point the game is still very fun to play, as you will be toying around with the above mentioned uruk-manipulation. The fighting looks and feels really great (played with a controller), and the amount of graphic detail is outstanding. The open world offers lots of content, and I especially enjoyed collecting all the artifacts as they provided smaller stories, related to the lore of Lord of The Rings itself. I even liked collecting all the mushrooms and flowers. Cozy.It amazes me however that the main story of this game is so shallow, when everything else is pretty great. The cinematics of the game are top notch and really fun to watch. The voice acting is superb. Certain smaller sub-quests aren’t that bad either, while the main story simply isn’t very interesting and appears unengaging and below average. It’s strange, when the game otherwise shines, developers obviously knew what they were doing regarding everything else in the game. Despite the unmotivating main story, I still highly recommend this game for its great action and the orc manipulation system. The latter is something entirely new in the modern world of gaming.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
Product received for free
												This game stays true to its Genre, an open-world/action/adventure game. Being a bit different combat wise, it did take some time to get used to it. The combat system though a bit glitchy at times, is one of the best things about the game. For first couple hours strategies to kill uruks would be better but once you advance through the story the combat becomes relatively easy. The graphics are fine and the side missions are good too. Although the story is just average the best thing about the game itself is that when you die, the story still advances and the uruk who kills you gets promoted. :DLast but not the least hunting is good too, but limited to 2 creatures. And because the map is not that big you can run through the whole map in no time so hunting doesn't make too much of a difference. Till the end you keep getting new skills so the game doesn't get repetitive and because the storyline is not that long even if you get bored you can take a couple of hours and finish the game. I would recommend this game, but only on sale, doesnt justify the full price being single plater.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												THIS IS STORY SPOILER FREE REVIEW (I'll limit the story to tutorial)Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor is TPP Assassin's Creed like action game. You play as a Talion - ranger banned from death, seeking the one who refused death to him. His family is getting killed with him but he managed to hmm "respawn". He's connected to weird ghost who's name I won't reveal. This allows Talion to read minds, use slow motion and Azkâr bow, and further on he gains abillity to make orcs fight on his side, and some other cool stuff. Talion is also equipped with Urfael sword and Acham dagger. The game mostly allows you to choose if you want to sneak into somewhere, bring death to all of enemies on your path or create a little distraction releasing caragors etc. This game is pretty much about killing orcs or making them kill each other. There's a very deep nemesis system which allows orc thatkilled you to become captain, and if he's a captain already he can gain Power. Captains fight each other, go hunting, recruit other orcs, set traps, betray themselves, participate in executions etc. Captains can become Warchief's bodyguards. Warchief is highest tier in Sauron's Army. If you want to kill Warchief you've gotta lure him out doing something game asks you to for instance killing X of Y in stealth, releasing Z caragors. If you haven't killed Warchief's bodyguards they'll be with him to help him fight with you. If you dominated one of them before and left your mark on them they can start fight just on the press of an button. You can upgrade your arsenal with runes dropped by Captains and Warchiefs. The higher the Power they have the higher level of runes. You can buy up to 5 slots for runes on every weapon. There are a lot of side activities in this game and they're pretty fun, e.g. Vandetta, where you have to kill certain captain that killed your friend or if you don't have any friends (well, dead friends) it'll choose outside your friend list. You can also release slaves, do legend missions for all of your three weapons, help your orc captains in a hunt, duel and other things, search for artifacts, etc. Little warning here: the story is pretty short. I would not advise you buying this game for full price if you are not going to do "at least" a lot of side activities. I bought AC4 for similiar price and it kept me in for much longer. That doesn't mean I did not enjoyed wandering around Mordor. If you want to do this game at least on 70% and you would like to play Assassin's Creed with Batman combat in Tolkien's world - go for it.79/100Awaiting 2nd game with MUUUUCH longer storyline and more difficulty levels (there's only 1 in this game and it gets super easy quite fast considering it's short which makes it not as fun).

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												This game was something I admittedly didn't think would be very good, but after playing it through 100%, I can honestly say it was worth the time.The combat alone was worth the price to play, and even though there are side quests and things to do, they tend to get a little tedious, so the combat helps to keep it fresh.The game plays like Assassin's Creed and the Batman Arkham games. There's bonuses given for freeflowing moves (there's only one attack button for melee) but this means simply not getting hit and stunning your enemies to keep the combo meter counting. As you unlock abilities, you get to spend points on abilities that allow you to perform special moves every time you get 8 uninterrupted hits (5 with an upgrade). The combat is just hard enough to keep you on your toes, but not so hard that you want to quit. Every now and then you get hit with a QTE that takes you by surprise, but there's nothing crazy (like God of War or Casltevania Lords of Shadow).The ability system is two-fold, and veterans to any series that puts RPG elements with hack-n-slash knows that the primary system for becoming stronger is to spend some sort of currency. In this game, there's both. A currency system is used to buy health and focus upgrades, carry more arrows, add slots to your weapons for runes, etc. While an XP system is used to unlock various abilities. The abilities will generally unlock over the course of the game, but there's also incentive to go off and maul orcs on your own... the higher tiers are unlocked as you earn Power. Power is earned by killing orc captains and warchiefs, settling power struggles, or even avenging the death of your friends. As you complete these missions you will gain access to stronger abilities that don't outright OP your character, but make battles where you are clearly outnumbered a little easier.The ranking system for Sauron's army is a little tedious and repetetive, but it's so in a very pleasing way. As you progress, you will gain access to "intel" which allows you to get information about the captains in Sauron's army, as well as their strengths and weaknesses. Killing captains will affect the state of the army and allow you access to some of the more powerful warchiefs, each which drop their own special prizes. As you progress, you can even command your own orcs and have them battle each other. When an orc kills you, he gets promoted and is identified in the army so you can exact your revenge. The possibilities are endless... literall, as the army can never be fully wiped out.There's much more to say, and I've said a lot already, so you should just go play the game already!

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												I am HIGHLY critical about everything I hear or see, even if it may not always seem like it.Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor is brilliance. Everything you could ask of a game within it's genre exists in the game, very interactive and agile movement, stealth, ranged combat, but not powerful to the point of making the game easy, in fact, most of the significant foes can't be taken down using ranged combat. Very interactive combat, excellent AI-coordination from what I have experienced, swarming-combat, 1 v 50, yet you can, if excelling in the gameplay, walk out of the fight without a scratch. A very clear storyline, which still branches off, to part, at some places here and there, not to mention the never-ending recurring missions, every time you clear out the entire rank-line of the orcs, all you have to do is progress time, and newly promoted orks have taken their slain brethrens place. Simply speaking, you never run out of things to do, and every fight is different from the other.Do I recommend the game? Well as clear as the sky at a cloudless night...YES! Looking for a great story? This game has it. Looking for excellent gameplay? This game has it.Looking for open-world gameplay? Oh it's there, alright.Looking for neverending gameplay? It's all in there.This game is worth every penny when it comes to extended entertainment.  Hopefully you find this review helpful and that you'll consider getting the game, if you do not have it already, because it's certainly worth it :)

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												TL;dr? This is effectively Batman, Arkham Asylum set in the Lord of the Rings 'verse.This isn't something bad. This is, to be honest, quite fantastic as the combat mechanics from the Batman games (Barring the latest one) is fantastic. The combat may not be perfect (there are peices of the terrain that will abruptly stop you from moving when the majority of other structures makes you parkour around like a man on speed and crack. For those of you who are mechanically gifted, as in you can keep all your keys in your head and not get confused with what buttons do what, you near literally can not be stopped. The captains are a nice mechanic to fight and them being able to level up is a fascinating mechanic that is fun to fight against. even if you fail and they finish you off, they come back stronger, giving you more rewards if you kill them. Leading to an interesting dynamic of letting them kill you to make yourself more powerful. If they kill people from your friends list, you can even avenge their deaths. Everything about them gears you up to becoming more powerful and dangerous.The last stand mechanic, letting you recover yourself even if you ♥♥♥♥ up or miss-press a button, is nicely difficult without being overly stressful and damaging your enjoyment of the game over soemthing cheap seeming. This game continuously aims to reward you if you can pull yourself out of a bad situation. Coupled with an excellent feat/abililty system that empowers you without giving you an 'I win button', instead making you stronger while expecting you to still use skill or finesse. I again seriously can't recommend this game enough.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor chooses its own path outside the regular "Lord of the Rings" move-game chum we've been fed over the years. The main story is interesting, but it failed to unravel as smoothly as the mechanical aspects of the game.Game mechanics - combat, stealth & movementThe combat, stealth and movement systems are a direct rip from the Batman: Arkham series of games (sans batarang of course). This was a smart move on the developer's part given the focus of the game. The difference being that the team opted for a slightly less stringent stealth implementation. This "nerf" to the Batman level of stealth isn't a bad thing. I found it a great middle ground compared to other more stealth-focused games (Assassin's Creed, Splinter Cell, etc.). Movement, more specifically parkour movement, was much less fluid and tended to be less forgiving than other games. After I taught myself to be a little more deliberate in my movements this tended to become less of a problem.Skills, runes & other progression stuffsGame mechanics such as skill systems and gear upgrades exist. There is a rune system designed to enhance specific aspects of your weapons. While the runes were fairly diverse, I found that once I had specific types I rarely changed them out and merely chose to upgrade them. This is more than likely a result of my play-style, but I would've liked to have seem even more diversity with runes and/or ways to "upgrade" them myself. As far as skill progression I actually found this aspect quite enjoyable and rather than sticking to "what I knew" I found experimentation with new abilities and skills to be very rewarding. My one wish is that "Nemesis system" skills would not be directly locked to the story missions.Nemesis systemThe Nemesis system was a big focus of the game. The system allows you to view and manipulate, in some ways, the Uruk leadership in the two major areas in which the game takes place. While there was much ado about the system, I found it a little sad that I was forced to progress deep into the game to get into the really neat aspects of the Nemesis system. I feel like there could've been considerably more depth to my overall game if I had been able to unlock those skills sooner. How does the Nemesis system play?In the beginning and even mid-way through the game it just isn't all that interesting. It wasn't until the end after unlocking key skills that I got to really mess around with it. That being said it is not nearly as expansive as the developer's try to make it out to be. There were a few Uruk's I wound up despising towards the end, but mostly I found my desire for vengeance to be quite satiated with the rivers of Uruk blood that flowed in the wake of my wrath. Monolith take this from me (Monolyth), if you choose to add a sequel to this game you need to greatly expand the Nemesis system and allow greater interaction with it sooner rather than later in the game.Story timeSwitching gears now, lets talk about the story. First of all I would have to say that Tolkien purists may do well to steer clear of the game (as many do the movies). The game takes many liberties with the Tolkien universe that might not be as appreciated. While I was able to follow the story easily enough I found in most cases I could not engage emotionally with the primary protagonist(s). Talion and his (trusty?) wraith sidekick family flashbacks served little more purpose than to push the story a long. I found that I cared more for some of the secondary characters than I did the primary...yeah. Overall the story takes a slightly different approach to the battle against Sauron and his minions than what we are all used to seeing. It is a refreshing viewpoint to see and could set the stage for even more aggressive "based on" Middle-earth lore.Just one more before bed...Another failing point in the story is its brevity. We are treated to some very cool ideas and concepts that if further explored could've provide some solid content. This wasn't necessarily an overall negative for my experience, I tend to focus heavily on side-quests and other content in the game. My overall game time is probably much higher than someone who wouldn't. Anyone expecting the main story content to take more than 8 hours if you focus on nothing but that will probably be a little bit disappointed.So what's the verdict?The game played very well for me and while some game mechanics suffered from a lack of options, I found the combat to be fluid and very rewarding. The much touted Nemesis system lacked depth until late in the game. The plight of the progranist(s) was fairly forgettable especially when compared against the much more interesting story elements overall.TLDRIf you like Batman style fighting games, are a completionist (or even like to do a few side quests here & there) and appreciate Middle-earth based stories I think you'll find your money well-spent.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												Welcome to my first review in a long time! During this review  I will be addressing the games elements which include: Gameplay, Graphics, Sound/Music, Story, along with the things that make it unique. I will also along give my thoughts and feelings on the game. Be warned there are VERY MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD! Gameplay: 9/10 When I started this game the first two games I thought of (and many others agree) were Assassin's Creed and the recent Batman Arkham games. The game takes the parkour and stealth system of Assassin's Creed and combines it with the timed button pressing combat of Batman. While many will say this is a complete rip-off of the two, it simply is far from it. It takes the elements from these games tosses them into a polisher to polish the mechanics and refines them so that it can flow almost seamlessly. Each mission uses different elements of these mechanics by utilizing different challenges in each mission such as getting stealth kills, executions, and others which give you bonus points for abilities and so on.The reason why I did not give this a 10 was due to the slight lag in the counter system. It was not as fluid as Arkhams system but it is damn close to it! Graphics: 8/10 I can’t really say much about the graphics as I only played it on PC. They are nice enough to get you immersed into the game. However where it really shines is on the 4k resolution. Sadly you need at least a 4GB card for this to happen. From what I have seen from the PS4/Xbox One versions they barely push the systems to their limits. I will update this section when I know more about the PS3/360 versions. Sorry Wii U fans no version for you unfortunately. I will say that the ambient effect are nice like getting soaked in water or mud and the wind mechanics and adds more realism to the games. There isn’t really anything EYEPOPPING here at the moment.  Sound/Music 10/10: I CAN PERSONALLY SAY THAT ONE THING OF THE BEST THINGS ABOUT THIS GAME IS THE MUSIC! Though there aren’t any tracks recognizable from the Lord of The Rings/Hobbit Movies. The musical score is fantastic and very well done in my opinion. The sounds of swords clanking off metal armor, shields cracking, and the voice acting is fantastic. I can't praise it any more. Story 6/10: The story is pretty simple. Your character and the games protagonist Talion is killed, along with his wife and son, by servants of Sauron called the Black Hand. You are then possessed by a wraith who is also seeking revenge on the Armies of Mordor which makes you become an undying Ranger to claim your revenge. And that's all that's all that is explained to you to start. I won't spoil any more. Though the story has some weak points the interaction between the characters is enough to keep you wondering what’s next even though the story is rather one dimensional when it comes to the main subject of it (Revenge!) Unique Elements 8/10: One thing I can say about the game is that it has quite a few unique features that have kept other players and myself engaged. The leveling system is slightly different from others where as you gain XP, you learn new abilities to make your character better at combat, stealth and bow attacks. You can also learn new finishing moves, and combos which will help you in battle. There are also side missions that can be done to acquire a currency which is then spent on upgrading your total health, ammo, and slow motion focus time.  The most engaging part of the game is the "Nemesis System." As you play through the game, various Uruks, captains, and chiefs in Sauron's Army willA look at the nemesis systemA look at the nemesis system by battling each other for power within the army. Most of the time can be to your advantage but can also be your downfall. One instance can be they will be dueling each other for positions of power while moving about in the ranks on their own. However, let's say you attempt to kill off one of these Captains. If you defeat him, his position will be left over in the army for a new enemy to fill the space. If you are slain in battle, the enemy who killed you will gain reputation, called power, and be promoted to Captain, gaining special abilities and weaknesses. The game does not hold your hand as it punishes failure, which is something we haven't seen in a lot in recent games at all which also makes it more rewarding.  In conclusion, that Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor is a great game to pick up; even if you aren't a fan of Lord of the Rings it has a lot to offer a gamer who is looking for something new. I think that is part of the reason why the decided to not use the Lord of the Rings trademark name. They wanted to make this game a game that anyone could pick up and enjoy without knowing the lore if they wanted to. However for fans of the lore there are plenty of references to the books and films within the achievements/trophies, (Like "Fly, you fools” which is obtained by making 20 Uruks flee by dropping Morgai fly nest on them). Should you play this game. YES! YES YOU SHOULD! Overall: 8/10

												Sunder Sauron's army as Talion, the wraith-possessed ranger of the Black Gate embarked upon a quest of vengeance.PROS:+ the nemesis system(brutal powerplay between elite uruks; you can assist/slay orc officers as they attempt to rise to the rank of warchief)+ free roaming(similar to AC series)+ combat(similar to Batman Arkham series)+ various methods of completing mission objectives+ well-used source materialCONS:- the beast riding is rather tedious and feels like a choreI loved every minute spent in the game(except for those few beast riding moments). Even though I'm usually no completionist, I found completing side missions and finding collectibles fun and rewarding. The overall quality of the game surprised me, since most LotR universe games which I had experience with so far were mediocre at best. Until the Shadow has been cast over Mordor.

Posted: January 2, 2015
												Ok here we go. One of the best Middle Earth games i've ever played so far. BFME1 was a good strategy game but action,rpg,open world style this is the best. Pros: Nemesis system. Challenges are good and hard. Some of them are very easy. Hunting and taming beasts are good thing. Celebrimbor -the ring maker- is a great character. We saw his story in this game and Sauron -The dark lord,traitor,the eye etc.- decieved him. And another character in this game is Talion. He is a black gate ranger. I wanted to tell everything but shortly story was great. Gollum, Sauron servants, beasts, orcs, master dwarf. Ah damned Saruman is trolling in this game too. Optimization is really good. Cons: Slave saving quests are the same. Maybe you get bored of killing orcs.(But i didnt)I played 40 hours story and did challenges %98. Now i'm playing lord of the hunt dlc. I will edit after i finish all dlc's and challenges. I will recommend this game %200. You wont regret it. Orcs must die. :DEdit: Lord of the hunt dlc is really challenging. Beastmasters are really strong they have only one weakness. Before you attack you should think a plan. New beasts are good. New carabor is swift and predator. And my dear huntsmate is Torwin. A dwarf has no fear of darkness and beasts. A dedicated huntsman he is. He is a traveler. You should read his journal.Hd dlc doesnt need 6gb video card. I have gtx 660 53 fps average.

												A cautious recommendation. So-So story which only appeals to major LOTR followers and fans. Riding mechanics seem a little bit choppy. Other than that, the game is a solid entry to the LOTR game universe, probably being the best LOTR video game to date. A great blend of Assassin's Creed and Batman Arkham, giving an excellent, responsive, and badass combat system. Nemesis system is a revolutionary mechanic that makes this game stand out. Two medium-sized open world areas, filled with stuff to do and orcs to slay. Plenty of fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 26, 2015
												Shadow of Mordor does only a few things, but does them definitive top quality. It cannot be denied that the game wasn's only inspired by Ubisoft's Assassin's Creed series, but it's largely identical. You have a sandbox in which you have several regions you gain full vison of by climbing to a high tower to "eagle vision / hammer something" it, after which a small region gets revealed on the map around your tower with various very repetitive sidemissions of the well known archetypes, such as kill them all, kill them all but stealthed, kill them all but with a bow.Shadow of Mordor however, spins this formula a little with it's core gameplay system the entire game is built around, called the "nemesis system". It's basicly a web of ork hierarchy and leadership, with several unique and endless generated ork bosses from local band leader to legion commanding warchiefs. They fight for power among each other, dominate the weaker to be their bodyguard, challange the stronger to take it's place, or even make fragile alliances. Anyway, they live their little lives without you, in an ever changing power-struggle. Each has unique strenghts and weaknesses that are really varied and for once I can say are really gamechanging and fun to play around (for example one can be immune to stuns, stealth kills, has strong armor and a squad of elite bodyguards, but is afraid of fire and beasts). So you have this little hierarchy here with unique orks in them, and you can manipulate the power struggle with turning them against each other, wiping the mind of one making him your puppet, manipulate the hierarchy around him in a way to get him ranks, you may get him as a bodyguard of a huge warlord and when the time comes to kill him, you can flick your fingers and get him backstabbed by your puppet. Or ride a warg to the middle of their fort, set it loose and assassinate your target in the middle of the chaos while he is separated from his elite squad, running and hiding because you exploited his fear of beasts. And it was just 2 examples, you can come up with many and do them however you like, with the exception of some key points in the story.Shadow of Mordor, is a great sandbox. It looks good enough (though faces definitly age faster), plays fantastic with the well known copypaste gameplay from Assassin's Creed / Arkham games, adds some unique elements to it that define the game (such as marking orks with your hand just like Saruman did, you can literally see the fear and terror in the poor ork's eyes when you force him to kneel before you with your burning palm on his face with an irresistable commanding otherworldy voice demanding obedience, it's so awesomely done you absolutely feel unstoppable and powerful).Buuuut, there are some downsides. For example, the story starts great, ends great (through it's a huge cliffhanger without sequel or explanation which sucks), but has almost nothing in the middle. Those "great" parts are good because something happens. And that's it. Not because it's outstanding or even logical, but this is the only thing you get that isn't sandbox artifact hunting or random ork killing. The main story is basicly a very long tutorial as the game gives you more tools to use, and teaches you how to use them on some random target, so on this perspective it's definitly mediocore or worse. It's also disappointing that when you finally finish a collection of any kind (weapons, moon runes, whatever) you barely get any satisfying rewards (like, a quote from some neverheardofhim and that's all for your long work of sword runes collecting). It is heavily advised to do most of the sideactivities and collections you want to finish before you finish the main story, because it's very discouraging to keep playing after that. It's a common problem of many sandbox games, some can surpass it, some can't. Shadow of Mordor definitly can't. But this is everything I can hold against it.It plays great, it runes great performancewise, it feels great because you don't have the good guy restrictions like in AC or Arkham. It's a slaugherhouse with spilling ork blood, badass "Mordorlike name chanting ork music", with stunning slow motions (and even a pause->photo mode with many tools!), the cold sound of steel as your sword slices the air towards some poor ork your blade strikes down like a thunder (quite literally, sometimes the cold reflection of light on your blade just lits up in slowmo and it's feels so great, it's full of little detail additions like this), the feeling of being the unstoppable, dark, unrestricted tragic hero with a combat system I cannot find more ways to praise, it's just... when you can't say more than "IT'S SOOO GOOOD".Shadow of Mordor is fantastic for it's gameplay, gives you a moderate sized sandbox to enjoy it, and it's definitly an experience worthy of it's price. The main story however quicky falls to boredom, is very predictible and unexciting with the exception of the cliffhanger ending that has no following.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2016
												This is great game, the combat is fun but it takes time to gets the skills to make it so. I played 4 or 5 Story Missions getting my♥♥♥♥♥kicked so I started to make side missions and it made a big difference.The story took a lot of time to get insteresting for me but maybe is why because I played side missions for about 8 hrs xD, still felt it was a little short.COMBAT:The combat was great but in the start is basically smashing the X and Y buttons but then you get the skills and if you don't use them and just keep smashing you're gonna have a bad time, and you'll feel like a badass for killing them with many techniques.BOSS FIGHTS:The weren't many of them (besides the obvious fights with the warchiefs), many of them were meh but there were some pretty good ones.NEMESIS SYSTEM:The Nemesis System is really interesting and for me it succeeds in making you hate the Uruks when they kill you many times and they get Power and you feel the satisfaction of killing them. But I got to admit it was kinda annoying sometimes having to get information from the Uruks.LEVEL DESIGN:The map I got to say was kinda disappointing, It felt very same at times and only certain areas had room for strategizing, and talking about the map there were certain wall where you could get kinda stuck, you have to climb down and then climb up again.RESUME:For me this game was great, the story was good and the combat excellent. It is worth every penny because I did 22 hrs and made 68% and I am planning on playing it again. I would give it an 8/10. The things holding it back were the lacklockster boss fights (not all of them) and the story being kind of weak at times, specially being LOTR related could have been better.SPOILER ALERT!!!!!Even though the final battles were amazing and felt epic I think they could have been harder and don't even get me started with that freaking final boss battle with the Black Hand of Sauron, it was bullishit. The fact that you were (kinda) the forger of the Rings of Power was pretty awesome  because I haven't read the books (and not sure if this is them), only seen the Extended Edition of the LOTR trilogy (like 8 times haha) and it let me seem some of the back story of the forging of the ring and of couse the one ring but still felt Golum was a little bit forced in the story.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Shadow of Mordor is a hybrid Batman/Assassins Creed game set in the LoTR universe. It looks lovely, plays wonderful and is very addictive. Fans of any of these would probably like it.The combat is very similar to the Batman games. bar some key mapping changes I would go as far as to say it's almost an exact copy infact, so anyone familiar with the system will be right at home here. It's smooth, engaging and rewarding. A button-masher this IS NOT. Stealth works nicely alongside this system to give you several options for taking down the enemy. You even get some ranged weapons in the form of your elven counter-part's bow - using "Elf Shot".The story seems fairly well devised and sits nicely within the LoTR universe. it oozes Tolkien from the get-go and it's wonderful to be playing a LoTR game that is actually good. Voice acting is also top-notch, which really benefits the game.The nemesis system is a wonderful little addition that makes deaths more meaningful to you. When you get killed, the enemy gets promoted in Sauron's army, making him stronger. The next time you meet you will then get a little jab from them about when they previously killed you before battle ensues for revenge. There are some other really nice touches here, like if you choose to run away from one, they will comment on this the next time you meet. It makes the battles and deaths seem more personalised to your game and is a welcome addition.All-in-all, this is a very solid game that I would recommend to anyone that likes Batman or Assassins Creed and LoTR.Jimbo Rating: 8/10

content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Clunky and awkward keyboard and mouse controls combine with hyper twitch happy fighting gameplay. That said, the game looks amazing, and the is incredibly engaging. My first foray went 6hrs, of which I should have been asleep 4 lol. The story and gameplay engage you right off the bat and you pretty much immediately fall into a 'just let me get this one more thing done' mindset. The fighting mechanisms are pretty impossible to master, unless you take enough speed to dilate time, but at the same time, are simple manage to be simple enough to allow you to succeed in most combat situations.The nemesis system is easily the most interesting and frustrating aspect of the game. Letting an Uruk kill you two or three times can make them nearly unkillable, combine that with their frustrating ability to mob you with 3 or 4 of these captains all at once and it can get really obnoxious. Even captains that aren't anywhere near your fight seem to magically teleport to you. That said, it really helps to engage you and add to the satisfaction of finally putting them down hard. As icing on this rather delicious cake, we get to explore an area and time frame previously never expanded upon in Tolkien lore. In this the game offers several methods to increase the immersion factor, finding artifacts with memories bound to them, NPCs, even the wraith you're bound to. The player is constantly hit with in game conversation, and information. All in all this is one seriously damned fine game and can be equally fun and infuriating. DEFINITELY a worthy buy on a decent sale price.(I'm cheap I wont spend $50 on a digital copy of a game for anyone)

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Well, i had been looking forward to this game for quite a long time, it looked like it would be a mixture of assassins creed and the lord of the rings, which was always good.. The scenery looks amazing, the music is nice, and the story keeps you interested... However that said, the story is very, very short... and then when finished, it does feel like you have only played about half of the game, DLC from the season pass should come out soon, but it does still leave you wanting more. So after i finished the game after about 6 hours, i decided i would try and get the achievements, which are your standard, collect so many of this and kill so many of that, with the odd tricky one thrown in, freeing slaves is boring after the first island, as it is literally just going in and doing the same thing over and over again.The nemesis system is all very well, and yes it is cool that if you are killed by an orc they become a captain and can then become a war chief, and still remember you and insult you like everyone else in the game, but the novelty soon wears off, and can be a bit of a pain if wanting a specific captain to go to a certain position, which you need to do on more than one occasion. I do think that it is a very good game, if short, and DLC should extend the fun, it's just the landscape is all a bit samey, and it can seem a bit repetitive after a while.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												I will say right off the bat, that I mostly play MMOs. Not many single player games can pull me in. The other day I sat down, turned on this game, and for 6 hours I could not exit. I didn't want to get off. I figured I should sleep so I did. I don't play it every day, but when I do I can't put it down. The Arkham series was my all time favorite single player game, but this one has taken that over. I am crappy at reviews but here ya go:First off, I heard the last boss fight sucks, that its to easy. I haven't got that far yet as of typing up this review. But honestly,  I don't really care. The game is extremely enjoyable, the amount of content for a single player game is awesome. The story seems to be fairly short as there is only 20 missions in it, but if you do all the side stuff, its very lengthy. Would I recommend this game to someone that only wants to do the main story and none of the side stuff? I would say No. This game really feeds off doing side missions, messing with the nemesis system  and whatnot. Building up your weapons, purchasing abilities, etc.. Its just all around a great game to get lost in.Speaking of purchasing abilities, the system is good and all, but almost 14 hours in I think and I almost have all the abilities purchased that is available. The only reason I bring this up, is because I think that its bad. It reduces customization options. What I mean is, it don't really matter where you put the points cause you will end up having them all anyway. Know what I mean? At this point I just slap a point in, see what I got and go on my way. I just love deep customization, but that won't knock points off from me.All around its an amazing game. Would I change anything? Honestly no. I do hate stealth and am TERRIBLE at it (terrible hardly explains it) but in this game its rather easy so far. It may get more difficult, I don't know, but its not a hard system in this game. Its very simple and straight forward. At this point, the Arkham series had harder stealth areas than this game does and I managed that one fine.Ok ending this here. Hope it helps out some, probably not :D

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												I am happily surprised with how satisfied i am with this game. I'm not a Lord of the Rings fan at all, but just bought this game on a whim. It was the hype game of the month and i said why the hell not, and took a leap of faith, and it paid off ten-fold. I love it when i by a masterpiece on accident. The game's story isn't really what keeps me engaged, but it is compelling enough not to want to skip. The voice acting by Talion is spot on. The game plays like Batman Arkham City meets Assassin's Creed, and builds on both formulas both in traversing the environment and combat. Like in the batman arkham games, the combat is extremely simple with some extremely complex mechanics buried within it, that makes for an intriguing and addicting thing to get into. I know there are story missions, but there's just something about simply killing hundreds of uruks all day and all night that just loses me. The game runs beautifully too, this is by far one of the most gorgeous games I've ever played. It makes Tomb Raider look like an old Xbox 360 game. My only minor gripe is with Warner Bros and their blocking of posting content published by them on YouTube, but if you don't mess with that kind of thing, then that doesn't even cocern you. This isn't the most innovative game in the world, but it feels like it's own game. Despite it borrowing mechanics from other games, it borrows them the right way, taking what made them fun, and throwing some middle-earth spice in the pot. This hands down one of my top games of this year, based on my first few hours of playing the game alone. You know this game is a masterpiece within the first hour of play. For a game that i never even remotely considered buying until it showed up in my queue a few days ago, I'd say this was the most satisfying blind purchase of $70 (with the season pass) I've ever spent. Buy this game now. Saving up for another game? Who cares. Buy this anyways. There's a 75% chance this game will end up being better than whatever it is your saving up for. The best part is, you can tell this game wasn't intended to be as good as it is. It's ironic that we live in a world where overhyped games are just that, overhyped, while the ones that fly under the radar turn out to be some of the greatest games you'll ever play.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												Highly enjoyable, if a bit short.PROS- Very good, modern graphics.- Fun combat, similar to batman (combo and parry) but much smoother.- Fun exploration / sandboxing, similar to assassin creed but more natural and less repetitive.- Kinda original with the nemesis system. (Dynamic orc captains with varied modifiers.)- Nice dialogs. Never heard anyone repeat the same line twice, which is quite the feat.- Nice achievements, fun to pursue, all doable in reasonable time. None of those usual "kill a gazillion zombies" kind of mindless grind achievements.- Really nice polish and attention to details. The developers know what they are doing.CONS- Only about 30 hours, including 100% completion and getting all achievements (and quite a bit of fooling around), in fact you can probably beat this in under 15 hours if you are not a collector and just beeline the story mode. - The is a time / score race mode that can get you a few hours on top of that. But seeing as people are posting 500 000 scores while the max i was able to do is about 10 000, I conclude there is cheating involved so you can't really play it competitively, only see how you're doing compared to your friends.REVIEWWell, to me this is a mix of assassin creed, batman, Risen (the first, not the abomination that followed it), and dare I say it, skyrim. In fact this could have been a worthy successor to skyrim if it wasn't so short... I felt like they did a good job creating the overall gameplay, world, settings, creature and enemy diversity, and so on, they just need to have bigger areas and more content for this game to truly shine and create a "must play" IP.Value wise, it is a bit overpriced for it's length. I feel like 30$ or so would have been more reasonable, seeing as it is a lot shorter than games in the genre (their fault for claiming being an sandbox RPG, games in this genre go for hundreds of hours) and they seem to plan for DLCs which probably should have been included in the game to give it that much needed longevity. Highly recommended to grab this in a sale, but paying full price is not a horrible idea if you can't wait. I'd aim for the game + season pass for 50$, that would be a decent price for what you are getting.
