content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Just going to forewarn you, if you don't like games that you constantly die in, then this might not be the game for you. BUT THATS PAST THE POINT.Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor is a beautiful game full of immense stories and side missions, absolutely outstanding graphics, (might I add that the game is  THIRTY FOUR GIGABYTES!!!! The nemesis system is my personal favorite feature of the game. It combines frustration with extreme joy whenever you either lose to a really terrible enemy which was by accident or just lost, which is really frustrating, OR whenever an enemy you really despise gets beaten in a duel BY the enemy that you just lost to. You can pretty much climb ANYTHING between a pillar and 100 foot mountain. I have been saved by scaling rocks and such countless times, thats not including the caragor, the caragor makes it so if you're sprinting then well you can climb anything...Whats really frustrating is that there is no difficulty settings so you are stuck playing on 1 set setting. Hence my forewarning. This makes you either die a lot or makes the game a fun challenge and you die a lot which is a good mixture. With Arkham Origins, its really disappointing since the enemys are so easy to defeat but with the Shadow of Mordor, either you counter right or you die.I honestly don't see a reason to dislike the Shadow of Mordor. Although I would love to see difficulty settings implemented, I still recommend this game :)

content:
Posted: February 28, 2015
												Top Tip:This game has an odd learning curve.  Initially it will feel fluid, natural, and simple.  You will quickly become weak and outclassed.  The trick is to do ALL the white missions you possibly can before doing anything else.  Use your points to buy rune slots and health upgrades.  And make sure to learn to block attacks using right click when prompted.Pros:-Graphics are very good.  There is also an HD texture pack but I couldn't get it to work.-Combat is fun, much better than in Assassin's creed.  There is a lot of talent and skill and even strategy that goes into taking out your opponents.-Being able to "brand" (hypnotize) Uruks, captains, and war chiefs over to your side is really awesome.-PC controls work REALLY well.  I commend the developers for figuring it out.  Your pinky will get a little tired of holding shift but their is no reason to break out a controller for this game.-Save system is totally automatic and competent.  Most of the missions won't last longer than 5-20 minutes so their isn't a need to save while in progress.Cons:-Music is too heavy to have playing in the background while you are hacking away at Uruks for hours.  Luckily you can easily silence it-IMO the story was really boring and I couldn't care less.  I enjoyed the LOTR movies and the Hobbit is one of my favorite books.  However, I'm not a big LOTR good.-The DLC that just came out makes you feel like you didn't get a full game.  Especially considering that their is no online play and the game isn't very long.  The story isn't very immersive either, so it doesn't have a ton of re-playability.Overall this game is fun and that's what really counts.  If you see a future version on sale with DLC included it will be a great value.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												This game...Oh my God.Hory♥♥♥♥♥♥♥It is the most epic thang evah,Who doesn't want to teleport into 5 orcs and kill them all with a wraith in amazing graphics and brutal deaths?It is an insane game, though the story is 10 - 15 hours, there is a lot of other stuff to do, brand all the Warchiefs/Captains etc.Besides that there are multiple challenges to complete, such as hold a bridge from constant waves of enemies for 3 minutes without letting a torch bearer through. With a 550 Mirian reward; such challenges really make you push for those 2500 upgrades, which I have one of. You would think that getting those upgrades would make the game too easy, in a way it does, but it makes it so much more epic. Before you were worried about those spear and shield guys, and those dual-wielders right? Not anymore, activate the Sword of Urfael and brand them all instantly and have them turn on the Captain and other orcs (who then get rekt).While it makes it easier with those upgrades it also gives you a much larger set of options to complete certain tasks and missions. No longer do you have to sneak about and kill EVERY archer before you go in, for fear of getting shot. Go around and brand a few then charge in and brand everyone with the ability, making it a 15v1 on the Captain :PThis game is amazing, after so few hours I still have a lot to do and cannot wait for the DLC's where you can play as Celebrimbor and the extra missions.

content:
Posted: August 6, 2016
												A fantastic game that emerses you immensely in the game world. With solid Arkham style combat that contains brutally amusing finishers. The story is decent with a lacklustre end game boss battle which is a real shame because it had so much going for it. A neat feature about the game is the nemesis and orc system. The nemesis system allows orcs who have killed you or have encountered you to remember the past experiences you had with them. This also leads to the occasional orc captain who will return even after you apparently killed them. I can see how this could be annoying for some people but it ends up quite entertaining. The orc system allows orcs to interact with eachother in the world without your input, whether this interactions are duels or riots for power and domination, or a simple feast to increase the morale of their troops. All in all it's a fantastic game that truly deserves more attention. Not a masterpiece, but very deserving of a go. A strong 8/10 (I recommend you purchase the game on♥♥♥♥♥as it's very cheap there).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												*This review will be lengthy, so please, if you want a simple review, scroll to the bottom.*This review will include the following:- Open World- Graphics- Nemesis System- Combat- Stealth- Movement- Campaign (No Spoilers)- Runes and Upgrades- CharactersOpen World: The open world of Shadow of Mordor is very well made and detailed. Stealth spots are easily seen and fit well in the environment. There is a fast travel system to towers you've been to. There are two different areas. One area is near the Black Gate, which is where you start, the other area has a lot of grass and beautiful scenery. Both areas, however, are absolutely beautiful.Graphics: With my R9 280X, this game was a candy store to my eyes. This GPU is not required, but it runs the game on Ultra at 60 FPS. Even on lower settings, the game is visually stunning. I cannot express my profound love for the scenery and detail that is worked into this game. There are so many different factors that contribute to the graphic fidelity of this game that I can't list them here. Long story short, this game is gorgeous. Period.Nemesis System: Besides my gushing over the graphics of the game, the Nemesis System is my favorite part of this game. This feature basically gives you an almost endless replayability. The main enemy faction, the Uruks, have a heirarchy of captains that increase in rank until they become warchiefs. The lower captains USUALLY are easier to kill and find, and won't drop very good rewards. There are some changes in this statement where the lower captains spawn with REALLY good qualities that counter your fighting style so perfectly, that you have to reevaluate your every attack. Some are immune to range or stealth. Some can't be scared off by a specific creature. It varies greatly from captain to captain, but they all can be quite formidable. When you kill a captain, that's it right? Wrong. Every time you kill a captain, a new one will take it's place, whether it's an already known, lower captain that wants to advance, or if it's a new guy that hasn't been seen before. Captains must be discovered individually, along with warchiefs. Warchiefs aren't necessarily super strong, they just are higher up. I personally had trouble with one captain that was in the second tier, and I killed a warchief in the first five minutes of being in his stronghold. If a captain kills you, or any Uruk for that matter, they will be promoted, or fight for a higher spot in the heirarchy. When you come back, they remember you and will  mostly mock you. Names are random and names depict what their unique personality is like. Some sing, some are slow witted, so on and so forth.Combat: I wish it was more than what I'm about to say. It honestly isn't very new or innovative. It's, click to attack, click to counter attack, tap f to execute, that type of stuff. Very much like Batman.Stealth: The stealth isn't really challenging. The Uruks are slow to detect, and have a bad case of tunnel vision. Hiding spots can be used to stalk Uruks. Cages with Caragors inside can be broken to release the hounds out. That type of stuff. It is, nonetheless, fun to play stealthily.Movement: Fast, and very fluent. The animation of clothes and weapons and all of the movable objects around you are so well done. Talion is very fleet, Caragors are VERY fast, and everything is satisfying to say the least.Campaign: The campaign is a good length, and is an interesting story. It is VERY worth it in my opinion, and it leaves you wanting more.Runes and Upgrades: The runes and upgrades are in depth, and detailed. They add a very interesting twist to the normal skills of a ranger, besides the wraith thing. All of your weapons could be extremely powerful, and give you bonuses for doing specific actions.Characters: All of the characters are well voiced and are well represented. They are interesting and varied, and will spark a fascinating intrest to talk to a character through their mission regularly. You'll soon find yourself playing the missions to talk to the characters. At least I did that.Here is my overall impression of Shadow of Mordor. The game is fun. Just outright fun to play. The movements and animations are pleasing. The nemesis system is just fantastic, and adds endless replayability and variation in enemies. Combat could have been better, but ended up being pleasurable. The characters and the campaign are both very well done and very engrossing. The open world is stunning and vivid with details and action to partake in. Overall, the game is a must buy. This type of quality with LOTR themed game? Come on, it's a no brainer. Any information I excluded in my summary here, consult the novel above this.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Pros:+Good graphics (runs pretty good as well)+Nice scenery+Fun combat+Awesome animations+Fun mounted combat+Lots of sidequests and other stuff to do besides main quest+Decent main quest+All bosses etc are unique, giving the game better replay value+Badass cape physics+Great soundtrack+Fun talent and leveling up system+Large open worldCons:-Some visual bugs like rainbow textures (no gamebreaking bugs, a restart usually does it)-Repetive enviorments (same ruins everywhere, same animals etc) Lack of unique things to discover-Super easy boss fights (Finished them all on my first try), in fact so easy that warchief/captain fights are harder than the actual bosses-Short main quest-Boring/forgettable characters-Only two unique zones, which really rustles my OCD, either it should be 1 or 3+-Annoying Orc voices, every other Orc sounds the sameOverall:I rate this game 8.5/10! It's amazing and although I bought it on full price, I wouldn't recommend doing so unless you have money to spend. It's still an amazing game and I haven't had this much fun in almost a year!

												This game...Oh my God.Hory♥♥♥♥♥♥♥It is the most epic thang evah,Who doesn't want to teleport into 5 orcs and kill them all with a wraith in amazing graphics and brutal deaths?It is an insane game, though the story is 10 - 15 hours, there is a lot of other stuff to do, brand all the Warchiefs/Captains etc.Besides that there are multiple challenges to complete, such as hold a bridge from constant waves of enemies for 3 minutes without letting a torch bearer through. With a 550 Mirian reward; such challenges really make you push for those 2500 upgrades, which I have one of. You would think that getting those upgrades would make the game too easy, in a way it does, but it makes it so much more epic. Before you were worried about those spear and shield guys, and those dual-wielders right? Not anymore, activate the Sword of Urfael and brand them all instantly and have them turn on the Captain and other orcs (who then get rekt).While it makes it easier with those upgrades it also gives you a much larger set of options to complete certain tasks and missions. No longer do you have to sneak about and kill EVERY archer before you go in, for fear of getting shot. Go around and brand a few then charge in and brand everyone with the ability, making it a 15v1 on the Captain :PThis game is amazing, after so few hours I still have a lot to do and cannot wait for the DLC's where you can play as Celebrimbor and the extra missions.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Just going to forewarn you, if you don't like games that you constantly die in, then this might not be the game for you. BUT THATS PAST THE POINT.Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor is a beautiful game full of immense stories and side missions, absolutely outstanding graphics, (might I add that the game is  THIRTY FOUR GIGABYTES!!!! The nemesis system is my personal favorite feature of the game. It combines frustration with extreme joy whenever you either lose to a really terrible enemy which was by accident or just lost, which is really frustrating, OR whenever an enemy you really despise gets beaten in a duel BY the enemy that you just lost to. You can pretty much climb ANYTHING between a pillar and 100 foot mountain. I have been saved by scaling rocks and such countless times, thats not including the caragor, the caragor makes it so if you're sprinting then well you can climb anything...Whats really frustrating is that there is no difficulty settings so you are stuck playing on 1 set setting. Hence my forewarning. This makes you either die a lot or makes the game a fun challenge and you die a lot which is a good mixture. With Arkham Origins, its really disappointing since the enemys are so easy to defeat but with the Shadow of Mordor, either you counter right or you die.I honestly don't see a reason to dislike the Shadow of Mordor. Although I would love to see difficulty settings implemented, I still recommend this game :)

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												After playing some of the other Lord of the Ring universe based games, I can say this is by far the best. Such an immersive world driven by a great story and plot allows for a player to be completely swallowed into game playing endlessly for hours.The game boasts a lot of base content compared to many games with tons of side missions/quests, exploratory rewards and means to better yourself by learning game play mechanics or by earning experience and earning new runes!Graphically (PC - Ultra Settings) this game is stunning, with beautiful environments and fluent 'level design' I find my self often running around and taking in the world that was built. There is a fast travel system yet I never seem to use it, the map is fairly large, but not large enough to become a pain to travel across, especially with all of the various side content or a fight with one of the 'bosses' of the games, which thankfully are fairly common.SoM has a very much 'Assassins Creed' style of gameplay and is a must buy if you are a fan of those games, or J. R. R. Tolkien universe.The only bug bear that I personally have is I find games like this rather repetitive, this is the reason I stopped playing AC. As long as they don't try and milk this games style and universe it will be fine, but I would be willing to make purchase of a sequel if one does ever get released.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												I normally don't write reviews, as normally people have already said what needs to be said about games. That is probably the case with this game as well, but I enjoyed this game enough for me to put my 2 cents in.I didn't think I would like this game. In fact, when I first seen that this game was another LOTR game, I was turned off instantly. I can only think of one other good LOTR game (personal opinion of course) as games that pull from this IP or any movie / book IP always seem to fall short on quality. This game is a huge exception.Watching the trailer I got excited. It really seemed like a solid mix of Batman / Assassin's Creed, and I love both of those games- at the same time it looked like a rip off. How could this game be mechanically better than either of those games? While not necessarily mechanically better than either, it is different enough from both and what they do offer as far as combat mechanics is satisfying and feels great.Stealth elements are not as fleshed out as assassin's creed, so don't get hyped over stealth mechanics. They are not bad, but the meat of the gameplay comes from the solid combat system which is where this game truly shines. When you enter combat, combos are smooth and flashy, and the system succeeds at making you feel like a true badass. That last point is probably where this game really hits the nail on the head for me. No other game lately has made me feel so unstoppable- so powerful and badass. I can go into fighting a hoard of Orcs right in the middle of a stronghold and have a blast just battling waves of enemies. It has yet to get old! The combat is something I enjoy with a passion. That being said, while earlier in the game it can be more difficult than later on, I do wish there were ways to increase the overall difficulty. The core of the game revolves around fighting Captains and Warchiefs which have different stats and abilities. The game gives you tools which can make fighting strong captains and warchiefs easier, but most of the time you can do the same combo to take them out. Sometimes they can block your initial stun, but then you just role over them and hit them from behind with your stun and continue your combo. Sometimes they can block your stun and block your roll over them. Then you have to start thinking outside the box, especially if they have the Combat Master buff. The truth is, once you unlock more abilities and skills, combat becomes more of a slaughter than a battle or challenge. I wish that there were stronger Captains / Warchiefs that were so strong that you HAVE to use their fears or other mechanics against them.Overall I would say that this game (FOR ME) is a no brainer. I would buy it again- in fact, I will probably get the season pass just so I can enjoy the upcoming DLC. There are not many games I go back too- especially in this day and age where I have 100 games to play and only time for a hand full of them. This game however, I will be finding any excuse I can find to play more of it. I have already beat the story mode, and I am now having a blast going through self made scenarios or goals that I make. Do I feel like killing every Captain / Warchief on the map? How about mind controlling all of them? How about I go get revenge on a captain who happened to get a cheap kill on me earlier? The story is really yours to craft, and that's probably one of the biggest highlights of this game. The Shadow of Mordor sandbox has all the tools you need to make your own fun. My last point will be regarding what the game calls the Nemesis System. This is probably one of the cooler aspects of the sandbox and truly brings a lot to the table. It adds a lot of personality to the Orcs, and gives every Orc / Captain / Warchief a little uniqueness and personality. Captains will remember you and mention past encounters you may have had. Orcs don't always look different, but there are certainly many varieties of Orc to keep it mostly random, and each have their own quirks that makes them one of a kind. It's something that I really appreciate, and one of the reasons I wish the game was harder. I hardly got a "rival" or an Orc that was too hard for me to beat. I would say there was only one Orc in particular through my entire playthrough that killed me twice, but that was before I knew you could upgrade your max health!Overall this game was completely worth it. I had a great time playing it, and I recommend it for those of you who enjoy the Lord of the Rings setting, and a good action game. The only true improvements I could think of is adding difficulty options, mod support, and more customization, but what we do have is excellent. I think many would agree.

												Like Lotr? If not, then why are you looking at this reveiw? Many people say Shadow of Mordor is just a re-skin of a Batman Arkham game. That's because it was supposed to be a batman game, but obviously it isn't. Why do I say this? Because the combat is exactly like Batman and Assassin's Creed, but Shadow of Mordor is much bloodier. It is set after the Hobbit and before Lotr, and without giving away too much, has a dark and brutal but fun story which fits in with Tolkien's lore very nicely. There are also two great maps to explore, tons of abilities, side missions and collectables to keep you entertained. If you're a Tolkien fan like me then definately give this amazing game a go.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												I played this game with everything maxed except high shadows and textures (3GB gfx card), but I improved visuals further  with SMAA/Lumasharpen forced through SweetFX configurator since there is no AA option in game, I got a steady 80-100 fps and the game looks great. The game benchmark averages 99 fps. Forcing SMAA really helped, but the game looks smashing without it too.I ran it on a 4770k @ 4.5ghz,  evga 780 SC acx @ 1310 mhz.The game is definately worth the money if you're looking for a good 15-25 hours play through with a good engaging story, a lot of customization and abilities, and a stunning beautiful open world. Feels like a mix of assassin's creed and batman arkham city with amazing fluid controls, and with the story taking place in the lord of the rings universe. A good experience and money well spent, no regrets.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												First of all ı'm a big Lord of the Rings fan but this is game is not much relevant to it. Maybe..yes you see gollum a couple times and learn better about Sauron and his supporters. Story 9.5/10 : In the begining (let's not give some spoilers) you get a little sentimental ..erhmm maybe couple tears.. then you know why you kill thousands of uruks and orcs for no reason. In the begining of the story you get some kind of corrupt from and elf and you live with him. The elf (Celebrimbor) has his own special moves and a bow. Long story short the story is great but it could have been little longer.Gameplay 9/10 : Game is based on a system where there is from lower rank to higher , standart uruks-the ones with the shields-berserkers-captain-master captain exc..-Warchiefs. In the esc menu you can see a ranking of the captains and chieftains. But first you need to learn some intel about them from the one less ranked soldier, for exp ıf you want to learn something about chieftain , you need to interrogate the captain and if you want to learn something about captain , you must interrogate a standart uruk. After you learn their location you go to kill them. Its almost easy to kill every captain but ıf you die one of them, they get stronger, maybe even promote. But the chieftains is hard to kill. When you go the place where they rest in the map. They wont show up at the first place. At first you must complete some kind of little game. exp : kill this , this and that guy , so the chieftain show up. You have 3 weapons at total. A sword which you can use to kill the uruks in combat and execute them. An arrow , you can only use your arrow when you're in elf mode, you dont have a quiver but when you drain a uruks life. It will give you 4 arrows. A dagger , which will help you to kill enemies from the behind below or above. Dagger is most used for sneaky attacks, and its deadly for standart uruks and gives extra damage to the captains and chieftains. The game has a level system , where you can upgrade your weapons, your hero or the elf side of yours. Also game is a little bit like Assassins Creed because , your jumps, running style , and free-style parkour runs in the castles is a little bit similar to it.Atmosphere and Map 7/10 : The biggest lost in our list is map. The map is pretty big..yes..but it doesnt contain much stuff in it. Yeah , there are castles. mountains. uruk camps exc.exc. But after some point its monotone. Same stuff all over it. The atmosphere is good , it reflects the middle earth as it is, relevant to wasteland because uruks burn the tree's and stuff.Total 8.5/10 : In total game is worth it's money for the storyline and gameplay and gives you slightly 30-40 hours of fun with couple of dlc's . Whether you're a LOTR fan or not you must try this one.Thank you Monolith productions :)

Uruk captains and warchiefs are generated every time you kill them or when they are fighting each other to advance in ranks and take over place of their leaders. Each has his own personality, weakneses, strengths. It adds tons of replayability. Not to mention you can dominate uruk minds and send them to fight each other, thus you can build an army of your own uruks. I branded an uruk captain and made him a bodyguard of a warchief by sending mine to kill his bodyguard in duel, then I sent him to betray warchief. And there is more to Nemesis system, it is but a glimpse of this deeply elaborated system. The combat system is very decent.The story is very fitting and lore-wise, even if it is short, the quality of main missions is very high. There is much to do without story, even after completing it, you can continue to take out uruk captains/warchiefs and explore collecting artifcats, runes.The world map is big enough to explore hours and hours. I believe Monolith will add new regions of Mordor beside Udûn and Sea of Núrnen once a DLC comes out (hoping to visit Plateau of Gorgoroth and Morgul Vale someday).And there is this feel and immersion. The feel you are in Mordor and Middle-Earth.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
Combat Pros: Whether you choose stealth or the walking mayhem approach You always feel like a powerful combatant. Arkham esque. Brutally violent. Every execution could be it's own Slayer album cover.Combat Cons: After several hours of playing it can become a bit dull and repeatative.----Story Pros: It's brief and unobtrusive. Often in games that let you choose your playstyle the story parts have your character doing things that you've avoided doing for hours of gameplay. (in farcry 3 I played very stealthy and yet in every cut scene this kid was running around screaming his head off like an idiot)Story Cons: The story is generic and kind of flat. Which isn't to say it's bad but some people may be expecting a lotro/hobbit epic adventure and it's not really that.----Why should I not just wait until this game is $10 on steam sale?: Quite simply, the world they created is stunning. The Nemesis system is by far one of the single most interesting mechanics added to the Assassins Credd/Batman games since they added boats to the Assassins Creed series. I completed the game in just over the minimum completion time which is not a feat by any means but what is impressive is that after I did that I spent the next 5 hours watching how the nemesis system played out. Sometimes I would kill my own guys to create a power vaccum just to see who took over. It's truly fascinating. Sometimes you'll find a weird little Orc that you just have to back in their power play because they're such a weird dude. When one guy kills you it beccomes a personal vendetta. Unlike quick time events I hope the Nemesis gets picked up by every game maker because it just helps give the player a vested interest in the world they occupy.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Generally I find "open-world" game design to be a crutch-- an excuse for not designing any good levels or writing any decent content. With Shadow of Mordor, the game's core concept wouldn't work in any kind of linear construct. It's the only game I've seen that actually makes positive use of the open-world concept.The fighting system is basically the same as any of the Batman: Arkham games. It gets it right, though; stringing together the combos and prioritizing targets is fun and addictive. The combat is entertaining and works just fine with a mouse and keyboard.There is a traditional main line of quests, but for the most part these serve as tutorials for doing the real work of the game, which is trying to gain control of the army of Orcs by interfering in their political struggles in ways that benefit your plans. And they really are your plans, not ones the game has fed to you; you have to get control of a captain and set him up for success by helping him cheat at duels, gain prestige by throwing good parties, and so on.Another amazing feature of this game that I haven't seen nearly enough about in the gaming press is the facial expression engine. Orcs look angry, confused, and utterly terrified in the most convincing ways. It's a small thing that has an emotional impact that isn't immediately obvious and simple. Bravo for this.As for problems, I only really noticed two. First of all the environments are boring. It's all just the same decaying stone buildings, mud, and scraggly plants. I realize it's supposed to be Mordor, but I still feel they could have worked harder at this, maybe by varying the architecture, putting more wildlife that isn't caragors and graugs, adding a swamp, or whatever. There's no real excuse for how identical everything looks.Secondly, I get stuck a lot on weird little jutting pieces of the wall or tiny rocks I should be able to easily step over. The fact that I can climb a 100-foot tower by walking next to it and pressing spacebar, but get stuck on tiny rocks the size of a baseball is maddening. It is an intermittent problem, but it crops up just enough to be irritating.In the end, it's a really fun game about a guy with cool super powers killing a lot of Orcs in fun ways. It has unique gameplay mechanics, a solid enough story, visceral violence, and no god damn crafting system. Buy it and play it. It's worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												So I’ve put about 40 hours in the game thus far, it says I am 53% through the game. Now I’m not one for doing a lot of side quests, but this game is just so amazing there is a real incentive to do everything in the game, you find yourself running around collecting artifacts listening to memories and freeing the slaves. You find yourself going out of your way to save slaves. The enemies have some real context, they feel real. When you are slain he becomes a captain and can become more powerful. You’ll find yourself scouring the countryside for these captains to get your vengeance, and sometimes he will even kill you again, make that eventual victory even more potent. You’ll find yourself just killing off captains. There is so much to do in this game, and all of it stays fresh from the runes you get and the abilities you unlock really makes this game a fairly unique experience even though its mechanics are shared with the Batman and Assassins Creed series. Unlike those games this game gives you a real reason to do all the content in the games and get completely lost in them. Music: Ok, I’ve never felt more epic in a video game. When you are facing captains or are locked in an epic battle, the music starts taking cues from what you are doing on screen. You will punch a captain and the trumpets will start blaring and makes a string of combos feel more cinematic. Graphics: I haven’t had a single issue running this game and boy does it look amazing, I am running everything on ultra, it’s nice to see how far the lithtech engine has come from the days of F.E.A.R.. I’ve had a few issues where some U/I would disappear making it hard to complete some missions where I just had to quit and restart the game. Controls: This game feels very much like batman with the sword fighting. But I believe it feels much more fluid in this game and as you unlock more moves and finishers in the game the more fluid it becomes. I am playing with an xbox 360 controller and I felt a bit limited. I’d be using the bow and ill be using my right index finger to pull the bow and find myself needing to hit the right bumper to shoot a fire arrow which took some finger acrobatics. NOW I did have some issues with the way the game handled navigating the world, sometimes I wouldn’t jump a wall when I should have been which could get annoying when you are trying to evade enemies. Also sometimes the screen will tell you to push a button to do an action and the game will do a completely different action when you press the button, which can really suck when you are trying to jump down but instead you jump on top of someone in the middle of a pack of Uruks. But these minor control issues don’t make the game any less enjoyable.Story: Play it, there are a ton of great characters and well-acted dialogue. The word is even enriched by the enemy soldiers when you are sneaking around and you hear them talking about you as your legend grows.	There isn’t too many bad things about this game. I still haven’t beaten the story, so I will update this review when I have completed it. But for now this is very much worth every penny and I have to recommend it to everyone even if you aren’t a fan of Lord of the Rings, I think this game has something to offer everyone.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Just going to forewarn you, if you don't like games that you constantly die in, then this might not be the game for you. BUT THATS PAST THE POINT.Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor is a beautiful game full of immense stories and side missions, absolutely outstanding graphics, (might I add that the game is  THIRTY FOUR GIGABYTES!!!! The nemesis system is my personal favorite feature of the game. It combines frustration with extreme joy whenever you either lose to a really terrible enemy which was by accident or just lost, which is really frustrating, OR whenever an enemy you really despise gets beaten in a duel BY the enemy that you just lost to. You can pretty much climb ANYTHING between a pillar and 100 foot mountain. I have been saved by scaling rocks and such countless times, thats not including the caragor, the caragor makes it so if you're sprinting then well you can climb anything...Whats really frustrating is that there is no difficulty settings so you are stuck playing on 1 set setting. Hence my forewarning. This makes you either die a lot or makes the game a fun challenge and you die a lot which is a good mixture. With Arkham Origins, its really disappointing since the enemys are so easy to defeat but with the Shadow of Mordor, either you counter right or you die.I honestly don't see a reason to dislike the Shadow of Mordor. Although I would love to see difficulty settings implemented, I still recommend this game :)

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												This game...Oh my God.Hory♥♥♥♥♥♥♥It is the most epic thang evah,Who doesn't want to teleport into 5 orcs and kill them all with a wraith in amazing graphics and brutal deaths?It is an insane game, though the story is 10 - 15 hours, there is a lot of other stuff to do, brand all the Warchiefs/Captains etc.Besides that there are multiple challenges to complete, such as hold a bridge from constant waves of enemies for 3 minutes without letting a torch bearer through. With a 550 Mirian reward; such challenges really make you push for those 2500 upgrades, which I have one of. You would think that getting those upgrades would make the game too easy, in a way it does, but it makes it so much more epic. Before you were worried about those spear and shield guys, and those dual-wielders right? Not anymore, activate the Sword of Urfael and brand them all instantly and have them turn on the Captain and other orcs (who then get rekt).While it makes it easier with those upgrades it also gives you a much larger set of options to complete certain tasks and missions. No longer do you have to sneak about and kill EVERY archer before you go in, for fear of getting shot. Go around and brand a few then charge in and brand everyone with the ability, making it a 15v1 on the Captain :PThis game is amazing, after so few hours I still have a lot to do and cannot wait for the DLC's where you can play as Celebrimbor and the extra missions.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Easily on my Game of the Year list for 2014. Shadow of Mordor is a fantastic game adapted from an outside product. Lots of other movies/books/comics to games etc, tend to fall flat on their face with poor production and simply lack of passion for the characters to make a good game. And you can't help but feel like it was just a cash grab to profit from the hype at the time.I mean seriously, how many comic book/movies inspired, and other games have come out over the years and were mediocre at best? Shadow of Mordor does not fall victim to this treatment. It really feels polished with lots of little details that really give you the feeling that this is Middle Earth. The team working on this seems to have been big Hobbit/Lord of of the Rings fans making a game they wanted to play.If you've played games like Batman Arch or Assassins Creed, you'll be right at home here. There are a ton of little side missions, collectables, challenges, and extra distractions that add a lot of quality, not crappy fluff, but quality fun to the game.The Nemesis system is by far the coolest feature of the game and one of the most entertaining I've experienced in a  long time. With every win or loss in the battles against the forces of Mordor, there is a shift in power. And either you're growing more powerful, or your enemies are. Beautiful voice acting, graphics, gameplay, music, cutscenes, pretty much everything here is great looking and it seems unnecessary to pick on the little minor problems with the game.The only thing that I would say is a negative, no new game plus. But even then, if gamers wish for a new game plus, then that in itself is praise for the game isnt it? A number of DLC content is on the way and I honestly, can't wait. Few games have ever made me look forward to DLC content, and that says a lot to me about how much I love this game! If you're a fan of Middle Earth, don't miss Shadow of Mordor. If you love Assassin's Creed style of open word gameplay with lots of side content, don't miss Shadow of Mordor. If you want a fun new challenge with the Nemesis system, don't miss Shadow of Mordor!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
 Killing Orcs Has Never Been So Fun! I have to admit I come into this game knowing nothing about the The Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit series. So the universe and the lores behind the movies or the novels mean nothing to me. I have to say, when I bought this game I did not buy it for the story, I just wanted a fun action game with tons of content and very addictive gameplay. I am happy to confirm I got what I wanted and it was more than overdose.The first thing I want to address is that this game was made by Monolith Studio who also made the popular WWE series. It is strongly portrayed in the game by the way characters walk, tackle and performing actions which is really cool as it work perfectly well in a game where the world is dominated by the Orcs. When a warchief is making an entrance you get all the lesser orcs chanting out their name making them look badass and you get the sense of satisfaction by cutting off their head at the end and claiming that epic rune.The game plays very smooth. It combines features from The Batman and Assassins Creed series but improves on the formula by having a deeper and better combat system, better stealth approach and wide array of interesting skills at your disposal. At certain point of the game I was actually really weak and was unable to defeat even an orc captain and was really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off about the game. However, as I dig deeper into the combat system and gained a few more levels I was able to finally defeat that nemesis that claimed my head countless of times. Speaking about revenge, the game introduced a very unique system called the 'Nemesis' system in which as player and time passes and evolves, the ranks within the orc army will also change. You soon learn that enemy AI behave extremely smart by roaming from place to place, killing superior orcs to gain power, dominate fellow orcs to earn an army and even ambush you when you were fighting other orcs. There will always be one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that always kill you becoming stronger each time and eventually raise in power to become a warchief. Furthermore, this system makes the AI memorise you so that the next time they meet you they come prepared with bodyguards as well as better equipments.The game was also very intense from time to time with some battles lasting way longer than 10mins as waves of orcs swarming in I find my self unable to escape or rather, the manliness inside me tells me to face them head on and after killing near hundres of orcs and gained a few powerful runes it results in a very satisfying warm little fuzzy feeling inside.After 20 or so hours into the game, the epicness is really showing as the world  totally opened up to you and you pretty much gained most of the abilities helping you to dominate the orcs in any situation. You can ride a caragor into battle and you can even ride a Graug to siege an entire orc fortress which was absolutely mind blowing. On top of this the game graphics looks absolutely beautfiful with very detailed graphics options. However, to have the graphics setting set to ultra high you will need a high - end pc to play it. When I was using a Razer blade with GTX 765m I can play on high setting with about 40-50 fps. With a Alienware m18x dual GTX 560m I get about similar results and with my desktop with R9 290X I can play on ultra with 60fps no problem. So it is fair to say that this game is well optimised. To top it all off, the game comes with a photo mode helping you to capture every moments of glory and it has many features that you can play around with to capture some really beautiful eye candy.Final verdict 10/10 I believe that this game is my game of the year 2014, as 2014 hasn't been a great year for gaming I think that shadow of Mordor really do stand out from the rest and it is packed with tons of content as well as delivering a satisfying experience to fans of the series or action game lovers alike.tl;dr+Fun combat mechanics+Satisfying orc slaying mayhem+interesting set of skills / passives+blend stealth with action really well+Gorgeous Graphics+Tons of content+Addictive and challenging-skins offer no new voices (Every skin uses Talion's voice)-Season pass doesn't offer much contentP.S. I have played about 30hours some were played in offline mode because I had no internet for a few days so the record on steam is wrong. within the 30hrs of game time I completed all the main missions, side quests (except killing all orcs), found all collectibles and learned all the skills as well as the passives.

												While there weren't a ton of good games that came out in 2014, this one has to be the best. I hear Wolfenstein: the New Order is great, but holy♥♥♥♥♥♥.. this is so good. It's good if you're a Tolkein fan as the game centers around familiar ground in an unfamiliar time featuring original and unsung characters -- and it's good if you're NOT a Tolkein fan because the combat is metal as ♥♥♥♥. Not to mention the innovative Nemesis/enemy rank system that makes things extremely personal. It's gorgeous, it sounds gorgeous, it's gratuituous, it's ♥♥♥♥ing great. Worth any price.Also brooding, grizzly protagonist that makes Aragorn look like a chump.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor, is a unique game. It is set in a great fantasy universe, with a focus on combat, and planning how to take down your enemies. The combat in this game (like all of the arkham games) is superb. If combat isn't your strongsuit, then the stealth will be. The stealth in this game is great, its a mix between the arkham and assassin's creed games. if you die in Mordor, whoever kills you will become promoted into a captian. It is an intresting concept, and makes death even more dreadful, as it will be more difficult to fight that random orc again, when he becomes a captain.All in all, this game is a great choice to buy. I purchased it for a low price during the Steam witer sale, but this title is definetly worth buying.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Despite underutilised characters and voice actors, and a story that reeks of terrible fan fiction, Shadow of Mordor is a solid (albeit on the smaller side) open-world experience. It's a great mix of Assassin's Creed parkour and discovery, and Arkham combat. The real meat and enjoyment of Mordor comes from the Nemesis system, a refreshing new gameplay hook that adds near-infinite replayability to the free roam (though you'll need to get through a good portion of the story to unlock every mechanic of it), which enables memorable encounters and rivalries with the multitude of randomly generated Orc characters.The biggest draw back of Shadow of Mordor (in my opinion): no difficulty options, and as such a solid player will bypass some of the most fun aspects of the Nemesis system (which incorporates your defeats). By the endgame and at 100% content completion, you may still be left wanting more, but the lack of difficulty at that point may be a deal-breaker to the otherwise great free-roaming under the Nemesis system.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Like Lotr? If not, then why are you looking at this reveiw? Many people say Shadow of Mordor is just a re-skin of a Batman Arkham game. That's because it was supposed to be a batman game, but obviously it isn't. Why do I say this? Because the combat is exactly like Batman and Assassin's Creed, but Shadow of Mordor is much bloodier. It is set after the Hobbit and before Lotr, and without giving away too much, has a dark and brutal but fun story which fits in with Tolkien's lore very nicely. There are also two great maps to explore, tons of abilities, side missions and collectables to keep you entertained. If you're a Tolkien fan like me then definately give this amazing game a go.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 23, 2014
												I played this game with everything maxed except high shadows and textures (3GB gfx card), but I improved visuals further  with SMAA/Lumasharpen forced through SweetFX configurator since there is no AA option in game, I got a steady 80-100 fps and the game looks great. The game benchmark averages 99 fps. Forcing SMAA really helped, but the game looks smashing without it too.I ran it on a 4770k @ 4.5ghz,  evga 780 SC acx @ 1310 mhz.The game is definately worth the money if you're looking for a good 15-25 hours play through with a good engaging story, a lot of customization and abilities, and a stunning beautiful open world. Feels like a mix of assassin's creed and batman arkham city with amazing fluid controls, and with the story taking place in the lord of the rings universe. A good experience and money well spent, no regrets.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												First of all ı'm a big Lord of the Rings fan but this is game is not much relevant to it. Maybe..yes you see gollum a couple times and learn better about Sauron and his supporters. Story 9.5/10 : In the begining (let's not give some spoilers) you get a little sentimental ..erhmm maybe couple tears.. then you know why you kill thousands of uruks and orcs for no reason. In the begining of the story you get some kind of corrupt from and elf and you live with him. The elf (Celebrimbor) has his own special moves and a bow. Long story short the story is great but it could have been little longer.Gameplay 9/10 : Game is based on a system where there is from lower rank to higher , standart uruks-the ones with the shields-berserkers-captain-master captain exc..-Warchiefs. In the esc menu you can see a ranking of the captains and chieftains. But first you need to learn some intel about them from the one less ranked soldier, for exp ıf you want to learn something about chieftain , you need to interrogate the captain and if you want to learn something about captain , you must interrogate a standart uruk. After you learn their location you go to kill them. Its almost easy to kill every captain but ıf you die one of them, they get stronger, maybe even promote. But the chieftains is hard to kill. When you go the place where they rest in the map. They wont show up at the first place. At first you must complete some kind of little game. exp : kill this , this and that guy , so the chieftain show up. You have 3 weapons at total. A sword which you can use to kill the uruks in combat and execute them. An arrow , you can only use your arrow when you're in elf mode, you dont have a quiver but when you drain a uruks life. It will give you 4 arrows. A dagger , which will help you to kill enemies from the behind below or above. Dagger is most used for sneaky attacks, and its deadly for standart uruks and gives extra damage to the captains and chieftains. The game has a level system , where you can upgrade your weapons, your hero or the elf side of yours. Also game is a little bit like Assassins Creed because , your jumps, running style , and free-style parkour runs in the castles is a little bit similar to it.Atmosphere and Map 7/10 : The biggest lost in our list is map. The map is pretty big..yes..but it doesnt contain much stuff in it. Yeah , there are castles. mountains. uruk camps exc.exc. But after some point its monotone. Same stuff all over it. The atmosphere is good , it reflects the middle earth as it is, relevant to wasteland because uruks burn the tree's and stuff.Total 8.5/10 : In total game is worth it's money for the storyline and gameplay and gives you slightly 30-40 hours of fun with couple of dlc's . Whether you're a LOTR fan or not you must try this one.Thank you Monolith productions :)

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Despite underutilised characters and voice actors, and a story that reeks of terrible fan fiction, Shadow of Mordor is a solid (albeit on the smaller side) open-world experience. It's a great mix of Assassin's Creed parkour and discovery, and Arkham combat. The real meat and enjoyment of Mordor comes from the Nemesis system, a refreshing new gameplay hook that adds near-infinite replayability to the free roam (though you'll need to get through a good portion of the story to unlock every mechanic of it), which enables memorable encounters and rivalries with the multitude of randomly generated Orc characters.The biggest draw back of Shadow of Mordor (in my opinion): no difficulty options, and as such a solid player will bypass some of the most fun aspects of the Nemesis system (which incorporates your defeats). By the endgame and at 100% content completion, you may still be left wanting more, but the lack of difficulty at that point may be a deal-breaker to the otherwise great free-roaming under the Nemesis system.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												If you're a fan of Middle-Earth and LOTR/Hobbit, then it's a "must buy"!!! ;) The story of this game is happening before LOTR and Hobbit, it is about a gondor ranger Talion who was murdered with his wife and child by the Sauron's most evil servants called black hands of Sauron. He was later then revived from the dead by a an Elf called Celembribor. His story is much like the ranger's. Sauron wanted Celembribor's skill to forge him the rings of power for the better world, but Sauron tricked him and in secret he created One Ring to rule them all. After that, Celembribor was betrayed and killed along with his fammily. Now he seeks vengeance. With finding Talion who suffered the similar fate, he will team up with him and plan to destroy Sauron! By doing so, u get an awesome single-player campaign which is portrayed in Mordor, killing orc captains and riding mighty graugs etc. ;)How much more do I have to say!! It is a MUST BUY!!!! ;))15/10 would buy atleast 3x more xD

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
Product received for free
 POSITIVE   Really good graphics  Canon, in terms of the books  The Nemesis system can really make you change your entire play style to defeat an enemy  Very enjoyable and smooth controls  Pretty bug-free from my experience  Lots of things to do for the first 15~ hours  Orc dialogue/voice-acting is really entertaining the first time you hear it  Nemesis system provides some replayablitity  Sword combat is very satisfying and lots of fun NEGATIVE   Pretty bland main character(s)  Not a lot to do alongside the main story  Some weapons/playstyles become insanely over powered near the end of the game  Fairly small map for an openworld RPGThis game is far from a "must have" but if you have the money and want to kill a few dozen hours, you won't regret it. The stealth is fun, the action even more; and it stays true to the feel of LoTR.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Shadow of Mordor is a game that looked back at the third person action games of last gen, namely Assassin's Creed and the Batman Arkham games, took what worked and polished them to a fine sheen. The Nemesis system is also something that will most likely be emulated from here on out. Overall Shadow of Mordor is  just a really fun game gameplaywise. When it comes to atmosphere it's really pretty too. The writing is unremarkable but there's nothing really bad about it, it's just serviceable for an action game like this. I definitely recommend it to third person action game fans, it's a quality game.

content:
Posted: March 16
 No spoilers I played this game basically because I wanted to explore more of the Middle Earth's lore and wanted to play this before Shadow of War is released. Let's get to more details about the game. Gameplay It is a third-person melee and ranged combat style with emphasis on timing your attacks and countering enemies. And the game delivers here absolutely. You can take no more than 5 or 6 hits before you fall. During fighting the stakes are always high as every death gives more power to your enemies and puts you behind. Shadow of Mordor gets a +1 from me here. Story As I said in the top, I wanted to get a good Middle Earth story. But it's not great by any means. Premise is pretty simple. Nothing compared to anything written by Tolkein. But a couple of references and cameos makes it interesting. A mere 10 hour campaign (without side missions) with a super anti-climatic end boos fight leaves me far from satisfied. +0 here Level Design Game is set in an open world map that is divided into a few regions. All of the regions are invaded by orcs and mostly when you encounter humans, they are slaves or dead. The scenery looks good and it looks to be inspired by the movie series and the books. +1 from me. Characters You play in the boots of Talion, a ranger (Much like Aaragon from the movies, but far earlier) who has lost his family and his life. He comes back to life with an elf smith who suffered a similar fate and together they set out to get revenge on the enemy. Apart from the main character and a dwarf, I found every other character pretty bland and did not care enough about them. +1/2 for characters. Replayability Game is only a one time playthrough and it was meant to be this way. When it comes to upgrading your skills and weapons, you can get basically most of them if you do a few side missions. Not too much decision making or planning required here. +0 Overall 2.5/5 Buy it in discount and rush through the main story-line if you want to play the game for the sequel release.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												Can't stop playing. The best Middle-Earth \ Lord of the Rings themed game out there so far.Nemesis system adds very unique aspect into gameplay. Uruk captains and warchiefs are generated every time you kill them or when they are fighting each other to advance in ranks and take over place of their leaders. Each has his own personality, weakneses, strengths. It adds tons of replayability. Not to mention you can dominate uruk minds and send them to fight each other, thus you can build an army of your own uruks. I branded an uruk captain and made him a bodyguard of a warchief by sending mine to kill his bodyguard in duel, then I sent him to betray warchief. And there is more to Nemesis system, it is but a glimpse of this deeply elaborated system. The combat system is very decent.The story is very fitting and lore-wise, even if it is short, the quality of main missions is very high. There is much to do without story, even after completing it, you can continue to take out uruk captains/warchiefs and explore collecting artifcats, runes.The world map is big enough to explore hours and hours. I believe Monolith will add new regions of Mordor beside Udûn and Sea of Núrnen once a DLC comes out (hoping to visit Plateau of Gorgoroth and Morgul Vale someday).And there is this feel and immersion. The feel you are in Mordor and Middle-Earth.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
Combat Pros: Whether you choose stealth or the walking mayhem approach You always feel like a powerful combatant. Arkham esque. Brutally violent. Every execution could be it's own Slayer album cover.Combat Cons: After several hours of playing it can become a bit dull and repeatative.----Story Pros: It's brief and unobtrusive. Often in games that let you choose your playstyle the story parts have your character doing things that you've avoided doing for hours of gameplay. (in farcry 3 I played very stealthy and yet in every cut scene this kid was running around screaming his head off like an idiot)Story Cons: The story is generic and kind of flat. Which isn't to say it's bad but some people may be expecting a lotro/hobbit epic adventure and it's not really that.----Why should I not just wait until this game is $10 on steam sale?: Quite simply, the world they created is stunning. The Nemesis system is by far one of the single most interesting mechanics added to the Assassins Credd/Batman games since they added boats to the Assassins Creed series. I completed the game in just over the minimum completion time which is not a feat by any means but what is impressive is that after I did that I spent the next 5 hours watching how the nemesis system played out. Sometimes I would kill my own guys to create a power vaccum just to see who took over. It's truly fascinating. Sometimes you'll find a weird little Orc that you just have to back in their power play because they're such a weird dude. When one guy kills you it beccomes a personal vendetta. Unlike quick time events I hope the Nemesis gets picked up by every game maker because it just helps give the player a vested interest in the world they occupy.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
Product received for free
												Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor, is an open world action game with RPG elements. Much higher emphasis on Action here, but enough here to consider it to be an RPG here. Some depth and choice in what you want to level up, although you will be able to max everything in your trees eventually if you so choose.TLDR; Its a decent open world action rpg that takes a lot from other games and builds on them immensely. It has lots of new additions as well on those systems, making it feel much more polished than the games it takes from. The RPG elements are nice, and you feel like a badass from start to end. The nemesis system and branding make this game have a lot more replay value than most, allowing for different results every time you play! Great game.NOTE: Since I've been planning to review tons of games I got this summer, I decided to review this one next.. Have too many games to play, and this is something I will definitely finish up and try to 100%. I really like this game a lot, although I will say I haven't bought too many games, or played that many AAA titles, so to those who have this will probably feel a little repetitive, or you've seen parts of it before. I will say however, this game does take mechanics from other games and might build on them immensely, or dumb them down a bit. Although it might be more of the same, it has a lot more to offer than what I just said. Just stating they did take styles of other games and made kind of a mega game here!. -Positives-     - Combat system    - Nemesis system    - Okay replay value    - Graphics are great, surprisingly.    - Good tutorials/beginning    - Good Optimization    - Branding(you can control your enemies, and make them fight against eachother and much more!)    - Tons of different approaches.    - This version comes with the DLC, meaning no need to have to buy dlc after this purchase.    - If you ever wanted to feel like a badass, you definitely can! Even at the beginning you feel strong, and capable enough to do whatever you'd like.-Neutral-    - Takes heavily from other games, such as Assassins Creed, Batman Arkham knight/city(sorry.. never played much of either, sorry if I get names wrong)    - LoTR Skin    - LoTR lore - Note; I put this here because they aren't really negatives, or positives. They can go either way from player to player. I love lord of the rings personally, and the skin makes it nice to me. (Watched those movies too many times honestly..)-Negatives-    - Can get repetitive    - Somewhat easy combat system, no depth. Although, the game can be as hard as you'd like due to the amount of   "customization" the game can have.    - Some mechanics were a bit dumbed down from what I've heard, and don't really feel right. This included the climbing mechanics, it just doesn't really feel great.    - Can be a bit grindy at times, especially if you want to unlock everything. If you followed the story completely, you'd probably get to the end of it in about 20 hours, which isn't half bad compared to some games. Although collecting and doing everything would probably take ages.   P.S Thanks again mike! @.@ so much to play, its hard to decide what to launch anymore!

content:
Posted: January 24, 2016
												Middle-Earth: Shadow of Moar Door has got to be one of my favourite games that ive played it the last couple years, i've found it very engaging and compelling to play. The game works best for me using a controller rather than the keyboard but it is definately playable with either. One of my favourite features in this game is that when/if you die, the enemy that killed you gains power and becomes a captain in the enemy's ranks. So rather than dying and feeling slightly irritated before trying again, you know have a nemesis, and can plan your revenge which feels oh so good. Or alternatively, you could be more sneaky and help your adversary climb the ranks until they become a warchief, at which point killing them makes it even more tasty. I found out very early on that this game has a unique twist to combat, usually in these kinds of games its very easy to take on a whole bunch of enemies at once (Assassins Creed, looking at you), however in this game, it may be wiser to run away than to engage an entire stronghold by way of blade. If your a fan of Stealth, blade and bow action, creating your own army, gravely voices or picking herbs and flowers, than this game is definately something you should look at!

content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Shadow of Mordor is a pretty decent stealth/action game. It plays a lot like Assassin's Creed, with a focus on parkour and wall-climbing with QTE-ridden hand-to-hand combat mechanics but the various upgradable skills and runes give it it's own flavour in terms of gameplay.The much-toted Nemesis System is pretty solid, too. While it occasionally spits out fairly unremarkable opponents, it's also provided me with some very entertaining rivals. There's something about turning the cannon fodder enemy that happened to snipe you as you were making a clean getaway and turning him into an unstoppable leader that provides a very unique thrill. Unfortunately, I did notice an unfortunate tendency for my rivals to die horrifically shortly after I brainwashed them into joining me (RIP, Dush the Caragor-Slayer, whose post-duel fanfare was cut tragically short by a giant rock monster), and frustratingly while enemy Orcs can respawn under the right conditions there's no such luck for allied ones.There's a fairly decent campaign and a large number of optional quests, too, though some are definitely better than others. The slave rebellion missions in particular play out nearly identical to each other, which is very jarring since the "Legend" quests usually have a unique gimmick or two to make them stand out. There's also a few dozen relics to hunt down and elven symbols etched into walls that provide a neat little diversion as well.I did have some performance issues at times-- I had a recurring crash on launch that required me to restart my computer every few sessions in order to fix it, and the framerate does tank a bit during particularly busy sections. Shadow of Mordor is also fairly buggy at times-- I had several dozen instances where orcs randomly flew into the air, the ziplines had a tendency to make me clip into the scenery (forcing a reset) or fall out of the world entirely, and on two seperate instances the game crashed immediately after a lengthy quest forcing me to redo it.But while Shadow of Mordor is definitely rough around the edges at times, there's just something about being able to turn five of a general's bodyguards against him without him suspecting a thing, having them gang up and kill him in his home fortress, then causing all of their heads to explode with a single keystroke so that the sole remaining captain in his regiment, who was also under my control, can take his position in the enemy army. Or the time I let a random enemy kill me, then converted him and made him the most powerful Orc in all the land before luring him into a cave where he was eaten alive by the undead. Or that time where...And really, that's Shadow of Mordor in a nutshell. A fairly entertaining, if flawed, means creating the type of stories you'll share with your fellow gamers around the water-cooler. And then getting weird looks from your other co-workers because you explained, in great detail, how you let a "Slave Taskmaster" get torn apart by tigers.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												I would describe this as a cross between the Batman games and Assassin's Creed, with a bit of interesting new stuff thrown in.  First, it looks beautiful, the graphics are a joy to behold.  The combat is fun, similar to the Batman games.  As you progress, you pick up enough new abilities, that slicing through a horde of Uruks just never gets old.The Assassin's Creed reference I mentioned is how your character moves though the areas.  There is a lot of climbing and perching above your prey and attacking from above, which, like the combat, never seems to get old.But what really makes this game shine is the Nemesis system.  You really feel like these are real Uruks you are killing, all with different weaknesses and strengths and widely varied appearances.  You can join in on a power struggle between Orc captains and influence who wins.  As the captains and warchiefs gain power, they get promoted and move up in ranking.  Also, if some random orc kills you, he automatically gets promoted to captain, and has a name and gains a little armor to alter his appearance.  You can then kill him for a vendetta.  It is a very engaging system and honestly, I had a great time just trying to kill the captains and wreak havoc among their leadership.  It's great fun!

content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												I just finished the main campaign in this game, and started touching on the DLC missions, but this review will focus on the basegame. There's a reason this game received the GOTY award from multiple reviewers and journalists.It brought a couple of unique features to a genre that was sorely needing something fresh.1. The unique AI engine that made enemies remember you, power up to battle you again if they lost previously or if they won boast in your face as they attempt to best you again. Each enemy had unique properties and rarely would a direct approach help you much. Especially in the beginning.2. The weapons were basic and simplistic, but offered a lot more and had a deeper narrative if you knew where to look.3. The environments were lovely with some interesting characteristics and many hints at the books and movies.4. The art direction, specifically with the Uruks and their armor, weapons and scowls were just superb. That green skin textures used in game made them look real. I was in awe when I first saw it.5. The playstyle, with a unique concequence to death and to leveling up. The stealth mechanic worked nicely, but added some difficulty ot the game as well.The storyline is not amazing, or new or unique. But it is a very proper LOTR lore. And they made proper use of the characters. In the end, what more can we ask for?The only real negative point comes in the learning curve. If it's your first time playing it, there's a lot of detail going on and a lot of reading to understand everything. However the tips and tutorials are properly documented and are helpful all the way to the end.I would absolutely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: January 29
												I bought Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor to get rid of my post Witcher 3 depression. I was pleasantly surprised to find myself with a hugely underrated game. The story is a little bland admittedly, and the world is quite small and plain. However Shadow Of Mordor offers the best combat experience I've ever had in a video game, with responsive and intuitive controls, fun mechanics and the most satisfying cinematic takedowns I've ever seen. The developers clearly poured a lot of time into creating the nemesis system in this game, with Urukai captains and warchiefs you can target and take down. It's very fun to see captains fight, feast and gain more experience, and even more fun to take them down.Admittedly I haven't played through enough of the story yet however it seems pretty mediocre. I also haven't started either of the two DLC yet so I can't comment there. Additionally the visuals in this game are quite striking, with the protagonist, Talion, looking particularly spectacular.So far I'm loving this game and would give it a 7.5/10.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Overview---According to the game, I'm 12% through the game. This game is filled with Assassin's Creed-like parkour, Batman Arkham Asylum/City/Origins-like combat, and it's more entertaining than ever. It's a hack and slash with amazing elements that you will most likely not find in any other game. Not only is this a Lord of the Rings game, which is a selling point for most fans, but it's combat is fluid and systems in the game is faultless. I believe that this game will never get boring. The endless nemesis system is awesome, as many new captains come in, kill/hunt with each other, working their way up to legendary captains, which is their ultimate goal. Along the way, not only do orcs get attacked by your character, killing them after their fruitful efforts to reach the top, but also competing orcs. If an orc gets to a high enough power level, he will try to move up in rank...but some of the times that doesn't work, resulting in the loss of their lives and making the winner a target for the player.You can get upgrades for your weapons in game, and also upgrades for your character and wraith abilities. You do missions to gather a currency to purchase more health, shots for your bow and arrow, and slots for your weapons. You have three weapons in the game, which all play crucial parts; the sword, the bow, and the broken sword, which functions as a dagger. The sword is for most melee combat, the bow is for taking out ranged troops and grunt ground troops, and the sword is for stealth kills.Also, if you have friends who play the game, when you progress through the storyline, you unlock Vendetta waypoints. if you go to one of these, you have a chance to murder your friend's nemesis, which is the 'Uruk' that killed them most. This feature is awesome.Pros and Cons---Pros--Great graphics, even on low-Fantastic combat, gory and different every time, also challenging depending on your advantage in stealth-Brilliant mechanicsCons--The storyline's don't really line up. In the game, it takes place in between the end of the Hobbit book and before the Lord of the Rings trilogy. However, the enemies you encounter in the game are called Uruks, short for Uruk-Hai, which is Saruman's creation. This is before Saruman has begun working for Sauron, therein these 'Uruks' shouldn't be in the game. I hope you appreciated my review, and I hope you buy the game. Add me if you do so I can avenge you from your nemesis! :)EDIT:Upon completing the game, I just wanted to warn you. The final battle isn't exactly a battle...You just press buttons to block attacks. But the rest of the game is great, there's two different maps you can travel around, adding to the adventure.Graphics: 9/10 Beautiful scenery, gore, and orcs.Gameplay: 8.5/10 Engaging Combat, Interesting Systems, Disappointing Last Boss Fight.Controls: 9/10 Good Controls, easier with a keyboard and mouse than a controller. Keyboard Recommended

content:
Posted: November 21, 2014
												<Semi-Spoilers?>+Voice Actors - Really good job with Talion, the pain in his voice was truly superb+Gameplay - Loved it being open-ended+Combat - I loved the mixture between the stealth approach and the direct approach+Character involvement - I felt for Talion as he felt broken near the beginning and then slowly regain purpose back in his life+Hordes - Made me feel like I was actually fight an army+Cutscenes - Also had great graphics+Upgrades - Plenty of them to last you from start to finish+Graphics - Were great+Landscape - Was beautiful-Main Storyline Length - If you only play it for the main quest it will tell you there are only 20 main missions, which actually doesn't take "that" long. -The Ending - Although it wasn't as "bad" as Thiefs ending. . .It's still kinda up there. You feel like you are going to finally face the Big Bad Sauron and all you get is a Quick Time Event and that's it. Not to mention "not to long" before this was a boss fight against "The Tower" which wasn't a fight at all. <--I played on max difficulty so trust me when I say that.-----Now aside from those two points (Which I do find imporant mind you). I wouldn't rate this game any lower then a 7~8. The game does what it was supposed to do which was being fun and making you feel like you actually could fight Sauron himself but again the ending really made it take a blow for me because there was no Epic Finish, which if there was, I would have given the game a solid 8.5~9/10. The one point being how fast the game is to finish but I guess that's more or less me wanting to have a longer storyline mission. . .
