content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												I was fortunate enough to play Shadow of Mordor through the steam family sharing system. Although I would not have been disappointed had I purchased the game at full price. I enjoyed every last second of it from start to finish and actually looking forward to more story based DLC.Let me just start by saying that I love the combat system. It's very similar to that of the Batman Arkham games. In fact it's just like that really. So it'll be very familiar to those who have played those games. Killing orcs in this game is incredibly satisfying and I sometimes get caught up in big battles and forget what I was trying to accomplish in the first place.The game itself has a decent story. It's nothing that will really blow your socks off but I think any Lord of the Rings fan will appreciate it for what it is. Uncovering all the lore collectables and stuff throughout Mordor is interesting as you get to learn more about Middle-Earth and the type of creatures and beings who reside within Mordor. The game itself takes place right before the events of Fellowship of the Ring. You play as Talion, a ranger of Gondor who meets an unfortunate end, but gets his body possessed by a friendly wraith who helps him get revenge for himself and his family. However this mysterious wraith has an agenda of his own that you will discover throughout the story. Interesting stuff.. .MMMMYYYYYEEESSSS!Lets talk about the new nemesis system. I love this thing. Defeating an orc captain just to have him come find me later with a piece of metal in his head to replace the big ol' wound I gave him in our last battle.. or he's burned... or he's mad that I spooked him by throwing bees at him... it's really cool. The orcs remember you, some of them hold grudges, some of them fear you. There was one that even sang to me, it was lovely. Another orc just asked if I had any snacks. I decapitated him very quickly. You'd really have to see the nemesis system in action for yourself to see what I mean. Easiest way to describe it would be to say that it makes your enemies seem more real. It makes things much more interesting when you're defeating or being defeated by them.I can't think of much reason to dislike this game. I suppose it did get a tad too easy in the middle of the game. I did feel way overpowered throughout most of the game and was pretty much impossible to kill near the end. I guess I don't like some of the stealth missions that would cause you to fail if you get spotted. They don't make any sense to me. The idea is that you'd be overwhelmed and killed if you're spotted... but I kill entire armies in that game. I am a harbinger of death. I chop off orc heads for fun, what do I care if I get caught? Oh well. Final Verdict: (4.8 out of 5)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
												Shadow of Mordor is a pretty decent stealth/action game. It plays a lot like Assassin's Creed, with a focus on parkour and wall-climbing with QTE-ridden hand-to-hand combat mechanics but the various upgradable skills and runes give it it's own flavour in terms of gameplay.The much-toted Nemesis System is pretty solid, too. While it occasionally spits out fairly unremarkable opponents, it's also provided me with some very entertaining rivals. There's something about turning the cannon fodder enemy that happened to snipe you as you were making a clean getaway and turning him into an unstoppable leader that provides a very unique thrill. Unfortunately, I did notice an unfortunate tendency for my rivals to die horrifically shortly after I brainwashed them into joining me (RIP, Dush the Caragor-Slayer, whose post-duel fanfare was cut tragically short by a giant rock monster), and frustratingly while enemy Orcs can respawn under the right conditions there's no such luck for allied ones.There's a fairly decent campaign and a large number of optional quests, too, though some are definitely better than others. The slave rebellion missions in particular play out nearly identical to each other, which is very jarring since the "Legend" quests usually have a unique gimmick or two to make them stand out. There's also a few dozen relics to hunt down and elven symbols etched into walls that provide a neat little diversion as well.I did have some performance issues at times-- I had a recurring crash on launch that required me to restart my computer every few sessions in order to fix it, and the framerate does tank a bit during particularly busy sections. Shadow of Mordor is also fairly buggy at times-- I had several dozen instances where orcs randomly flew into the air, the ziplines had a tendency to make me clip into the scenery (forcing a reset) or fall out of the world entirely, and on two seperate instances the game crashed immediately after a lengthy quest forcing me to redo it.But while Shadow of Mordor is definitely rough around the edges at times, there's just something about being able to turn five of a general's bodyguards against him without him suspecting a thing, having them gang up and kill him in his home fortress, then causing all of their heads to explode with a single keystroke so that the sole remaining captain in his regiment, who was also under my control, can take his position in the enemy army. Or the time I let a random enemy kill me, then converted him and made him the most powerful Orc in all the land before luring him into a cave where he was eaten alive by the undead. Or that time where...And really, that's Shadow of Mordor in a nutshell. A fairly entertaining, if flawed, means creating the type of stories you'll share with your fellow gamers around the water-cooler. And then getting weird looks from your other co-workers because you explained, in great detail, how you let a "Slave Taskmaster" get torn apart by tigers.

												Middle-Earth: Shadow of Moar Door has got to be one of my favourite games that ive played it the last couple years, i've found it very engaging and compelling to play. The game works best for me using a controller rather than the keyboard but it is definately playable with either. One of my favourite features in this game is that when/if you die, the enemy that killed you gains power and becomes a captain in the enemy's ranks. So rather than dying and feeling slightly irritated before trying again, you know have a nemesis, and can plan your revenge which feels oh so good. Or alternatively, you could be more sneaky and help your adversary climb the ranks until they become a warchief, at which point killing them makes it even more tasty. I found out very early on that this game has a unique twist to combat, usually in these kinds of games its very easy to take on a whole bunch of enemies at once (Assassins Creed, looking at you), however in this game, it may be wiser to run away than to engage an entire stronghold by way of blade. If your a fan of Stealth, blade and bow action, creating your own army, gravely voices or picking herbs and flowers, than this game is definately something you should look at!

content:
Posted: March 16
 No spoilers I played this game basically because I wanted to explore more of the Middle Earth's lore and wanted to play this before Shadow of War is released. Let's get to more details about the game. Gameplay It is a third-person melee and ranged combat style with emphasis on timing your attacks and countering enemies. And the game delivers here absolutely. You can take no more than 5 or 6 hits before you fall. During fighting the stakes are always high as every death gives more power to your enemies and puts you behind. Shadow of Mordor gets a +1 from me here. Story As I said in the top, I wanted to get a good Middle Earth story. But it's not great by any means. Premise is pretty simple. Nothing compared to anything written by Tolkein. But a couple of references and cameos makes it interesting. A mere 10 hour campaign (without side missions) with a super anti-climatic end boos fight leaves me far from satisfied. +0 here Level Design Game is set in an open world map that is divided into a few regions. All of the regions are invaded by orcs and mostly when you encounter humans, they are slaves or dead. The scenery looks good and it looks to be inspired by the movie series and the books. +1 from me. Characters You play in the boots of Talion, a ranger (Much like Aaragon from the movies, but far earlier) who has lost his family and his life. He comes back to life with an elf smith who suffered a similar fate and together they set out to get revenge on the enemy. Apart from the main character and a dwarf, I found every other character pretty bland and did not care enough about them. +1/2 for characters. Replayability Game is only a one time playthrough and it was meant to be this way. When it comes to upgrading your skills and weapons, you can get basically most of them if you do a few side missions. Not too much decision making or planning required here. +0 Overall 2.5/5 Buy it in discount and rush through the main story-line if you want to play the game for the sequel release.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
Product received for free
												Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor, is an open world action game with RPG elements. Much higher emphasis on Action here, but enough here to consider it to be an RPG here. Some depth and choice in what you want to level up, although you will be able to max everything in your trees eventually if you so choose.TLDR; Its a decent open world action rpg that takes a lot from other games and builds on them immensely. It has lots of new additions as well on those systems, making it feel much more polished than the games it takes from. The RPG elements are nice, and you feel like a badass from start to end. The nemesis system and branding make this game have a lot more replay value than most, allowing for different results every time you play! Great game.NOTE: Since I've been planning to review tons of games I got this summer, I decided to review this one next.. Have too many games to play, and this is something I will definitely finish up and try to 100%. I really like this game a lot, although I will say I haven't bought too many games, or played that many AAA titles, so to those who have this will probably feel a little repetitive, or you've seen parts of it before. I will say however, this game does take mechanics from other games and might build on them immensely, or dumb them down a bit. Although it might be more of the same, it has a lot more to offer than what I just said. Just stating they did take styles of other games and made kind of a mega game here!. -Positives-     - Combat system    - Nemesis system    - Okay replay value    - Graphics are great, surprisingly.    - Good tutorials/beginning    - Good Optimization    - Branding(you can control your enemies, and make them fight against eachother and much more!)    - Tons of different approaches.    - This version comes with the DLC, meaning no need to have to buy dlc after this purchase.    - If you ever wanted to feel like a badass, you definitely can! Even at the beginning you feel strong, and capable enough to do whatever you'd like.-Neutral-    - Takes heavily from other games, such as Assassins Creed, Batman Arkham knight/city(sorry.. never played much of either, sorry if I get names wrong)    - LoTR Skin    - LoTR lore - Note; I put this here because they aren't really negatives, or positives. They can go either way from player to player. I love lord of the rings personally, and the skin makes it nice to me. (Watched those movies too many times honestly..)-Negatives-    - Can get repetitive    - Somewhat easy combat system, no depth. Although, the game can be as hard as you'd like due to the amount of   "customization" the game can have.    - Some mechanics were a bit dumbed down from what I've heard, and don't really feel right. This included the climbing mechanics, it just doesn't really feel great.    - Can be a bit grindy at times, especially if you want to unlock everything. If you followed the story completely, you'd probably get to the end of it in about 20 hours, which isn't half bad compared to some games. Although collecting and doing everything would probably take ages.   P.S Thanks again mike! @.@ so much to play, its hard to decide what to launch anymore!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24
												8/10 - A highly entertaining killing frenzy amongst funny looking creatures with silly names.This game takes some of the highest-grossing elements of action-rpgs that came up in the past years and combines it with the successfull franchise of LotR. A good idea, that was realised almost perfectly. ME:SoM has much to offer for ARPG and Tolkien-Fans. Also, if you liked climbing on things and stealth-killing enemies in Assassins Creed or beating the living hell out of thugs in the Batman Series, this Game is likely perfect for you. Besides the familiar and well balanced gameplay, this game has to offer a pretty good storyline with a nice character development. The only downsites here are the endless upcome of sidemissions, that distracted me too much from the story, the lack of different races and characters of the LotR universe and a pretty lame bossfight at the end. The atmosphere is quite nice, but the two large sections the game offers are fastly explored and get boring after a while. Nevertheless the nice soundscape and the enemies and creatures roaming the lands of ME:SoM result in an immersive atmosphere. The graphics are very good: a low amount of loadingscreens but a stable framerate at high settings on a average system. The mainstory is quite short, but there is plenty to do in the world of ME:SoM. The DLCs offer some more information about characters of the story, some more gameplay features (sadly even more quicktimevents) and a more challenging alternative gamemode.Gameplay - 9/10Atmosphere - 8/10Storytelling - 7/10Graphics - 9/10Playtime - 7/10Total: 8/10 - Middle-Earth: Shadow of Morder had everything to offer I missed in the Assassins Creed Series. The gameplay mechanics are entertaining until the end.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												There are literally thousands of other reviews, so I'll keep mine concise.+ An excellent storyline. The story follows Talion, a Gondorian ranger who is stationed at Black Gate. He is later possessed by a very important and very powerful figure in Middle Earth's history. The story's pace is quite good, though it feels a bit disconnected towards the end.+ The lore is greatly enhanced by the artifacts you find. Collect all the artifacts if nothing else. I especially loved the ones where they delve into lore of Blue Wizards.+ You get to see lots of important characters from the Middle Earth's history, and also many characters from the movie trilogy. I'm an avid fan of LOTR mythology, so this game was a very good opportunity to refresh my memory.+ The voice-acting and sound effects are incredible. It really feels like you are watching a movie during cutscenes.+ For those achievement hunters, the game is choke-full of collectibles and challenges, though none of them unlock anything in the game (This may be a negative point for some).+ Towards the end of the game you become something like a demigod. If you unlock all abilities and find all the epic runes for your weapons, there is nothing that can stand in your way, be it Graugs or hordes of orcs (This may be a negative point for some).+ The nemesis system really makes you want to go take your revenge.+ I loved the bit about Ratbag. I think all the quests related to him were hilarious.+/- The graphics are not ground-breaking. They are nice, for sure, but not mind-blowing.+/- The combat is nothing special. It uses the same system as Arkham games. It is less fluid than Arkham, but more lethal. You need to be more careful. With a little reflex, you can beat 20+ men easily as Batman, but you will die a lot if you try to take on 20+ orcs here (until you unlock epic runes and abilities at least).- Throughout the game I had frequent sound glitches. It may be my system (I'm using a Sound Blaster Z and I play with heaphones. I chose "headphones" in the audio options menu). The problem is, after a while all speech sounds come from the left speaker, some speech sounds are very muffled, and some sound effects are completely muted. Restarting the game fixes the issue.- There are tons of challenges and collectibles but none of them unlock anything.- If you don't rush thorugh the game and do all the quests and everything, you become nigh-invincible towards the end and the game loses all challenge (This was not a negative for me but it may disappoint many people).- There are some rare bugs in some missions which forces you to restart them.- The unskippable little cutscenes you have to watch every time you face an Orc captain or Warchief start getting boring after a while.Verdict: I think this game is a must-play for everyone, even if you are not really interested in the LOTR. There are some negative points to be sure, but the positives far, far outweigh them. Definitely recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												Only a few minor setbacks prevent this game from being a perfect 10/10. First, the positives: It's got a really good story, the characters (protagonists and the people around them) are easy to empathize with, which makes you want to complete the game and have some sense of justice on behalf of them. The open-world mechanics work well to draw you in the game, combined with the beautiful graphics makes the whole experience an immersive one. I like the fact that the many side quests are somewhat shaped depending on your actions as well as the procedurally generated enemies creating an atmosphere of uniqueness to the game. Your choices, while they may not really matter in the larger story line, help shape and influence the smaller stories within the story by interacting with the player. The fight dynamics are simply fantastic, it almost becomes an art form to slay the Uruk-Hai, which are apparently in endless suppy. Least but not least, the stealth actions bring a whole new dimension to the already rich-in-mechanics game. The negatives: Controls aren't up to notch for some of the more intense combat situations, you will feel them working against you and not for you. For example when surrounded by 30 enemies, including a warchief and two captains in some random stronghold and you're backed into a ledge, having very little health, you might want to jump off the edge and get a breather and shoot a few head-shot arrows to scatter a couple of these wretched creatures... Well, the game doesn't agree so. For stealthy actions, this is not a problem though. Second, the tactical and strategic elements of the game are served too up front with side missions. It would have been a lot better if the game gave us  a clue as to what the greater goal is and what kind of strategy and tactics we might want to employ towards that goal and left us alone to gather our own intelligence and cultivate our own side missions from the ground up. That would have suited the great open world atmosphere of this game a lot better. To conclude, this is a must have/play game, even if you're not a fan of the LOTR books/movies, the former of which I am not. I highly recommend this game for hours of fun. Now, I must go back to the tons of DLC I bought for it.

												I played this for close to 40hours. That included the main story and all the side quests the game has to offer. I cannot get enough of this, seeing them win and die eventually. I don't know, but having my own Uruk prize fighter, it's like playing game of thrones with a strap on.Furher more I spent some time collecting all the epic runes in the game, building the Uruk army up and busting a cap after they are fat with potential for an epic rune. It's almost like running my own Uruk farm. feed them, slaughter them, Collect my prize. I am even considering buying my own farm and have epic battles with cows to get their meat. But no, seriously.Then offcource there's a little regret, I like my games not hard, not damn hard, no.... ♥♥♥♥ing hard. Thats what I expect of my games, but even with the difficulty not being merciless with me, I would say from time to time, there's this one uruk chieftain that slaps the snot 7 times around your face. If I had to compare this to something I like in life, it would be like getting a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. it's that good. No but really. It's better than good. It's a mix of majestic and epic. Called.... Epijestic. My friend created the word so:"Werner™, battries not included, T&C's apply."I don't play a lot of RPG games, I am only starting out now and between The Witcher and Mass Effect Series, I hope they pop more Shadow of Mordor out because of it's immense replayability. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2016
												I just finished the main campaign in this game, and started touching on the DLC missions, but this review will focus on the basegame. There's a reason this game received the GOTY award from multiple reviewers and journalists.It brought a couple of unique features to a genre that was sorely needing something fresh.1. The unique AI engine that made enemies remember you, power up to battle you again if they lost previously or if they won boast in your face as they attempt to best you again. Each enemy had unique properties and rarely would a direct approach help you much. Especially in the beginning.2. The weapons were basic and simplistic, but offered a lot more and had a deeper narrative if you knew where to look.3. The environments were lovely with some interesting characteristics and many hints at the books and movies.4. The art direction, specifically with the Uruks and their armor, weapons and scowls were just superb. That green skin textures used in game made them look real. I was in awe when I first saw it.5. The playstyle, with a unique concequence to death and to leveling up. The stealth mechanic worked nicely, but added some difficulty ot the game as well.The storyline is not amazing, or new or unique. But it is a very proper LOTR lore. And they made proper use of the characters. In the end, what more can we ask for?The only real negative point comes in the learning curve. If it's your first time playing it, there's a lot of detail going on and a lot of reading to understand everything. However the tips and tutorials are properly documented and are helpful all the way to the end.I would absolutely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												B4 i start i just want to say that i am 100% totally and completely biased, as i am in love with the world of Middle-Earth...As soon as i saw the very first teaser of the game, i fell in love. Like most others i loved the idea of killing hundreds of orcs at a time and the idea to use Batman's combat style seemed like a perfect fit which would avoid clunky combat and make u feel and look like a total badass while preforming the great kill animations.When i got my hands on the game my love only grew further, as i didnt expect the orc society to be so personal. I remember dying the first time to what would later be my "arch-nemesis" throughout most of the game. However seeing his head fly off into the distance was well worth the planning and patience it took to kill him for good. However there is one "negative" that i found at the very start of the game, and that is the difficulty. This game is just too damn easy with all those visual cues on screen. Thankfully they can be turned off for a more immersive challenge at the start of the game, that being said once your character gets enough skills he is pretty much a god that can keep a kill-chain going till u start to feel sorry for the orcs. All in all i had a super fun time with the game and even 100% it (which is rare for me) and definitely consider it my GOTY of 2014.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												I had huge expectations from this game considering most reviews rated the game like it's a masterpiece giving it top ratings.However the game feels like an average action game with a lot of wasted potential.Let me explain myself:Combat is pretty much the same as it is in Batman series - you build combo streaks, you use special attacks, you crit on well timed attacks. The combat feels fluid, mostly fun and even challenging. Things can get sometimes ridiculous - captains / warchiefs get resistance to pretty much everything and you can only kill them in a single way. For me it's 8/10Story felt mediocre - it's clear it wasn't the focus of the game. People leave as quickly as they are introduced. Some main points aren't even explained. For example - why was Talion the one chosen by the 'wraith'? Why was his family chosen by the black hand?Not to mention boss fights were ridiculously easy. At the end of a second boss fight all I thought was only THAT'S IT? I had bigger problems with Uruk warchiefs and even with some Uruk captains than that pathetic boss fight. Expected much stronger story from LotR game, so for me it's only 5/10Side missions / collectibles are a good way to earn currency to unlock rune slots on your weapons or to increase general stats of your character. You will most likely do them only at the beginning as they quickly become repetitive. Killing 5 marked uruks while not raising alarm / not being detected can only be interesting and fun for first few tries. As for collectibles - artifacts add some lore and or emotions to certain state of the place or time. I honestly didn't find them interesting enough to collect them all. Rune spots however felt a bit more interesting though I hadn't finish them too. To me it's about 5/10Some thoughts: Variety of enemies is absolutely awful. About 99% of the time you fight uruks, and the rest of the time you fight wildlife (caragors / graugs / ghuls). You'd think you'd get to fight cave trolls, 'evil' humans, goblins (aka orcs - uruks are stronger orcs), wargs or other fantasy creatures from LotR universe yet all you do is fight Uruks equipped with different weapons - swords, crossbows, spears, shields,... The game isn't as long as many other reviews say, however if you are willing to continue with dlc, it can make up for it. The base game is about 10 hours of playing unless you drag it around by slaughtering uruks for fun / run around instead of using fast travel / do many unnecessary side missions or collect all the runes and artifacts.ConclusionWhile I complain about a lot of things in the game, I still enjoyed it and that's what matters the most.If you are looking for a good action and don't care much about story, this game is definitely worth a look. Total score: 7/10

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Shadow of Mordor:Graphics - On a decent computer it looks amazing, the scenery, the texture details the lighting, everything is really top class.Character detail and animations -  are fantastic, the physx hair and cape sway around in the breeze, the characters mouth movements sync up really well with the characters voice, not just in the cinematic cut scenes but the in game talking when you pick up a specific item etc. The looks on the orcs faces when you about to stab your sword into their face, the look of their friends is also really well done, you know, the look of horror when you brutally stab them all over the place. The animations for combat is flawless as well, the different types of kill possibilites for not only basic attacks but for executions and dagger kills as well.Voice acting + cinematics - really amazing job for every character, the stand outs for me was the guy the does for voice for Talion the main character I thought was absolutely fantastic, beautifully fits the character and also all the orc voices are amazing. Every captain has a different personality which affects how they fight in some cases. Cinematics obviously are gonna be great, I suppose its kind of expected in this time of technology, but Shadow of Mordor has more cutscene cinematics then pretty much all other games that I've played. There is basically one for each step of the main story which includes about 20 parts so. Yea really great job on the voice acting and cutscene cinematics.Immersion - So for me one of the greatest things about this game was the immersion, I guess games that come out now are gonna be more and more immersive because the graphics become more and more realistic but this game especially. It really gives you the drive to keep playing and to not only finish the story but complete 100% of the games content as well. The story for me was really quite good, the dialog that the characters had really made sense, it was logical which in some games is hard to find. And what I mean by that is some games have the character make really stupid decisions like not wanted to have help or not completely killing a person and its just to drag on to the story, similar to horror movies when its very dark and there is obviously someone hiding in the dark room with a knife but the idiot walks in anyway and gets mauled to pieces, when in reality, you would probably run out of the ♥♥♥♥ing house drive away get on a plane and ♥♥♥♥ing move to an entirely different location. Another immersive part of the game was the collectables part of the game, usually in games they make you pick up little items to extend the game a little bit. Shadow of Mordor gives you a logical reason and rewards for getting this items, they give you backstory of the item you just picked up or dialog between the Calabrimbor and Talion discussing what they found. There is also a bunch of rescue quests which involve you going to free human slaves from the orcs. Each time you accept the new rescue quest it tells you what the slaves did in order to be tied up and tortured and then that story affects the bonus part of the quest. For example if a bunch of slaves tried to poison the orcs 'grog' which is basically their alcohol, you have the bonus quest of finishing the job and poisoning the grog.My rating + should you buy the game - So my rating for the game is going to be a 10/10, I stayed up for 38 hours and I played the game for 37 of those hours and I enjoyed every minute of it. I was waiting for this game for a long time and it really delivered more then I expected. I think they did an amazing job and I'm really looking forward to what DLC's they're going to bring out. Now about buying the game for youself, I highly recommend doing it. It's an open world game with so many possibilites on how you would like to play the game. The captains and warchiefs are all different and you can choose which ones you want to control and which ones you want to kill, you can create your own unique army of orcs which is a really cool idea in my opinion. So definitely go out and get it, seriously one of the best, if not the best game ive ever played.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Great gameplay, although a little on the easy side once you get most of the upgrades. The gameplay can also start to feel old as you progress towards the end. The story is something that you feel is lacking as soon as it begins. Very predictable and stereotypical, not even the addition of lore through artificats and such can save the story for me. The gameplay can be described as a combination of the free roaming mechanics of Assassin's Creed with the combat of the Arkham games. It makes for a very satisfying experience, as you roam the lands of Mordor hunting down Uruks and bend the armies of Mordor to your liking. However, the pace of the game could be better. Before the game allows you to use all your wraith powers, even story missions feel like a tutorial that introduces you to the nemesis system. The game holds your hand most of the way, its obvious, and yet doesn't take away from the experience. Which speaks to the polish of the gameplay and mechanics.The story really is just a back drop for the fantastic mechanics this game has to offer. It will be interesting to see other developers take the nemesis system and place it in existing IPs and beyond.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I would recommend this game but would say that you shouldn't expect too much out of it. I bought this game with really high hopes, hearing how great the combat system, and the nemesis system were, and had a blast for the first few hours or so. About halfway through the game really started to drag on for me. I like to try to do everything before the main quest, so I kept trying to kill all of the chieftains and warlords, and you can't. It's horribly frustrating to keep trying to kill everything off, and then logging off and coming back on just to have everyone be replaced and you no longer have intel on them. And the combat is so easy it's boring. You can just crouch and suddenly you're invisible and can do whatever you want, and if anyone does see you, you just pull out your sword and kill them in a few quick hits. The character just feels too over powered for the world, other than caragors. Caragors were the bane of my existence in this game, and I would rather fight 3 warlords at the same time than deal with a single caragor. Worth it if you can get it cheap, but I wouldn't pay full price.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Great game.  It takes place between the Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit, with Sauron coming back to Mordor as the backdrop for the plot.  Enough Tolkien to immerse yourself in, without it completely destroying the lore to make a playable game.  Don't get me wrong, there will be several WTF moments where it appears to go directly (or indirectly) against the mythos of Middle Earth. Generally speaking, however, it is excellently done, and you can tell the creators had a love of Middle Earth.    As has been mentioned before, the gameplay is combination of Batman: Arkham Whatever and Assassin's Crap.  The fighting mechanics are lifted almost directly from Batman, and I consider that a good thing.  My only gripe is that the combat is a bit easy, and although you will die, towards the end of the game death will only occur if you're just not paying attention.  The final mission was a blast, although the final boss was a let down.  (When you can tackle 30+ orcs at a time, how do you make a 1:1 fight interesting?  I don't know, and neither did the developers).  The game takes awhile to complete if you aim for all the side missions.  I rarely felt bored or like I was wasting time when going after the side missions, and the main missions were well scripted, interesting, and thoroughly enjoyable.  If you're a Tolkien fan, you'll love this game.  If you're not a Tolkien fan, well...I don't know what's wrong with you.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Goddammit Mordor, why did you kill my save file? Why can't I save manually to DIFFERENT SAVE SLOTS? arghGameplay:That said, this game is quite good. Fighting feels similar to the Batman games, and the nemesis system really adds to it. Character is quite mobile, and an interesting balance is struck between stealth, ranged and melee attack. You are not a tank, though fighting well means you can avoid a lot of damage. Challenges and opportunities are generally good.Visuals:The graphics are pretty good, though some areas have had a lot more attention paid to them than others. Character models and skins are great, particularly the numerous orc types. Art design is generally good.Audio:Fine, not particularly memorable. Again, the orcs stand out with their conversations, taunts and other voice acting. Overall:Provided the loss of save games is fixed, or you work around it somehow, I recommend this game. As it stands today, I'd give it a recommendation with that important caveat.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Enjoyable, very satisfying third person combat in a setting with lore that's well handled, with abilities that make sense in context. The closest comparison i can give for this game is that it is a Tolkein version of the latter Far Cry games, even moreso than it resembles the Arkham series games from which it takes most of its combat dynamics.The nemesis system is very fun and as much as i hated dieing multiple times at the hands of my own personalised nemesis, it really drew me in.That said, beyond the open world fun and nemesis system, if you're aiming for 100% completeness as I did, this really is a game that runs out of tricks towards the end (an end no less where if you end up completely skilled up, you can do away with the challenge. As for the DLC, the Lord of the Hunt has been a bit of a let down. I hope the Bright Lord content makes up for that.

content:
Posted: March 4
★★★★★It was the 2014 GOTY of a lot of websites, which kind of says how disappointing that year was, considering that this game is not as amazing as the years around 2014. It's an excellent celebration of player freedom and control, which is somewhat undermined by it's unadjustable, low difficulty.By this time, I'm sure you know what you do in this game, and what the combat is compared too. The brilliance lies in its player agency and execution. The combat and stealth portions are satisfying and the player is free to tackle situations in anyway he/she sees fit. The game is also well-known for its 'Nemesis-system'. There are captains who are spread out over the plains of Mordor, each with their own randomized characteristics and traits. I don't know how many types of visual characteristics the devs have programmed into this, but 40 hours in and I was still fighting Uruks I've never seen before, like "Kubai the Drooler" who is actually drooling at all times. This is awesome, because you will remember some of them simply because they were successful in fending you of or perhaps even killing you. This is where my problem lies.This game is too easy, especially in the first eight hours. The nemesis-system looses it's value, because of the low difficulty. Unique to the system is that a captain that kills you, will grow in strength and power. Some captains will make a comeback at you at completely random times to take their revenge on you (with some new scars on their heads). Again, this is awesome, but most captains won't be able to defeat you, and you'll just plow through the Uruk army, taking captains one or three at a time. The low difficulty just negates the the system.The small amount of story missions is actually pretty nice. These are afterall somewhat restrictive and because there are a  massive amount of side-missions, the game entices you to play in bursts spreading out over a couple of weeks, instead of burning through it in a single week. Not that you get burned out with it, on the contrary, but it is nice that the game allows the player to take it's time with it; the positive effect of the casual playstyle.The DLC offers two more short stories set in the same landscapes. Some traits of the player and of other units are changed for the sake of variety, and the new achievements offer the right amount of difficulty for those who seek more of a challenge.You should give this game atleast a try, after all it's only 10 bucks during steam sales. It's well polished (no bugs at all) and well designed. It runs good on pretty much everything, meaning that some small changes in the settings can change a whole lot for you. The one gripe, the low difficulty, is a bummer but it is something to overlook.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												I was initially skeptical about Shadow of Mordor. I thought it was a blight upon a fantastic universe, and would ruin the lore. I thought it was a shoddy attempt at capitalising on a popular genre of "jump-drop-assassination-fun-times". Then I was convinced by friends to try it out.And I was so wrong. While the game takes liberties with the lore, it keeps certain elements the same. It maintains Celebrimbor, Sauron's deceit, Melkor, Numenor, and the likes. None of that is changed beyond recognition. It's not a reboot. It is, at worst, a side-spring; an alternative timeline. It stays loyal enough to the lore that it doesn't feel out of place, but it takes enough liberties that lore-puritans may take offense.But for those that don't, for those that can look past that? You're in for a wonderful surprise of orc slashing, ghûl chopping, caragor riding goodness. The game features a nemesis system that means if a regular bootlicking orc kills you, he can get promoted to captain on the condition he can defeat one of the already present captains. What's more? The orc can end up becoming your nemesis if you kill one another enough times.Orcs that survive being killed by you(a seemingly random chance) end up returning with visible scars and alterations. Observe case; Gorfel Blood-Hand. Dude was a regular foot-orc until he managed to kill me through circumstances I don't recall. He was promoted.In revenge, I sought him out and killed him. But that was not the end of it. He returned, this time with a massive metal plate across his eye. That was a visible disfiguration, considering he had been rather un-scarred before. I once again took the liberty of assassinating him, just because I could.Fast forward a few hours, and I had forgotten about him more or less. Than he appeared once again, as the bodyguard of a warchief. His entire face was covered with leather and a hood. You could see his metal plate under the hood, but his sanity had clearly drained from his skull. His motive? He apparently thought he was cursed, and killing Talion(the player character) was the only way to break the curse.I didn't let him. But it shows how small stories can form within the game's world, letting you drive an orc from their wits just by killing them over and over.The combat itself hearkens back to the Batman: Arkham games and is quite simplistic. The graphics aren't anything to write home about either, but the collectibles and nemesis system will provide enough fun in themselves.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												I'm writing this review completely biased as I been itching to get my hands on this game since it was first announced.  But I only got a chance to play it now.  This game hits every note for me personally.  Whether that makes it an amazing game or not is entirely subjective.  It takes most of its mechanics from other games.  The free flow combat is Batman with swords.... Which is just really cool.  Its faster and more fluid and less rythmic.  The parkour is a faster Assassin's Creed with everything climeable within seconds. the story is barely there but servicable and just offers more orc killing.Orc killing.... Thats the entire point here.  Orcs being used as fodder for your playground.  As you level up they become more and more laughably easy.  But where this game truly shines is the nemesis system.  Its everything I hoped it would be and more.  This allows for every player to experience something different in their game.  With orc captains having personality traits.Highlights for me has been a complainer who whines about everything.... I made sure to dominate him so I can keep him around :D and its been funny hearing his dialog.  Also a brain damaged captain who has trouble talking.  I had one random orc kill me and I jump off the tower respawning and kill a random orc only to find out it was the one that just killed me lol.  One captain refuses to die and keeps interrupting the same fight with a warchief.  How annoyingly delightful!Over all the game itself runs like a dream with no noticable glitches for me.  Again I admit my bias as these types of games are like crack to me and this one especially scratches every itch for me.  I haven't even finished the story and I don't care!  Shadow of Mordor is the perfect game as far as I'm concerned.  Minor nitpicks of the 2 maps being really small and how archers can sometimes get you very cheaply when your swarmed by a lot of enemies.  But I'm not even complaining about those.  this is a 10/10 for me.  Takes all the elements from other games and just makes it better in my book.  Just don't go in expecting some deep story to move you.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Shadow of Mordor is a surprisingly good open-world third-person action game that I can easily recommend to everyone.I guess not many have people expected Monolith to pull off a good open-world Tolkien game but they did and they did so amazingly. While nothing inherently new is on display, your character gains new moves at a great pace and the action never seems stale. You have a wide variety of ways to deal with your foes and when you add the nemesis system to this mix,  you not only enjoy the opportunities the game gives you but also feel invested in the inner dealings of the Uruk hierarchy.I have not felt so "enjoyably" lost in an open-world since Just Cause 2 and this is no small feat in my eyes. During the 25 hours it took me to almost 100% the game, I always felt excited to step into the shoes of Talion and always had fun with whatever I was doing in the game: going through the story, liberating the outcasts, riding giant creatures into the hordes of Uruks, pitting Uruk Captains and Warchiefs against each other and so on.It's a pity that there wasn't more non-DLC content to the game but I easily got my money's worth. There were some things that held back Shadow of Mordor from becoming a classic such as the somewhat easy difficulty, the QTE bosses and the extremely weak endgame but overall, it is a must buy for the fans of the genre!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 28, 2016
												Personally i'm not a fan of Lord of the Rings which meant that i only had passing knowledge of the world and characters. From what i have seen in the movies a lot of things are referenced in the game and this should be a fans dream game. I had a bit of trouble keeping track of the different beasts and factions and such but the story was entertaining on its own. You could remove all things LOTR from this game and replace them with generic fantasy clichès and it would still work because the gameplay is fantastic.Shadow of Mordor is a truly open in it's gameplay and it's just a blast to play something like this. Main meat of the game is playing around with the hierarchy of the Uruk army. There are elite captains who command captains who command the army. Killed ones will soon be replaced by another as the captains raise in ranks. If they manage to kill the player then whoever struck the final blow will be raised to captain status and thus every enemy in the game can become one of the main villains. All the while this is happening the player can complete main missions to progress the story but the enemies you face in the story are affected by the situation on the hierachy board. It's a bit complicated system to explain and it took a while for me to understand whats going on, but once i did it brought a grin on my face. It is a really well made system.Captains can be found out in the open or they can be stumbled upon while killing someone else. Sometimes multiple captains just happen to be in the same place where the player is doing something else and everything just escalates into chaos. Additional action comes from luring Caragors (wolf-like pack beasts) and even Graugs (humongous all-killing mega monsters) into the situation. In the later part of the game player gets the ability to brand uruks to fight their comrades. Captains can be forced to fight eachother. After everything is set up you can either join the action or climb somewhere and let the AI battle it out. It's unique and so much fun!The game is a bit on the easy side with harder no difficulty levels available. This is not all bad since it makes playing around with the AI easier but on the other hand it makes many things optional. AI is blind and deaf and escaping or sneaking is really easy. Unless specifically required stealth is often meaningless anyway, because killing a dozen uruks is no problem. Finding out a captains weaknesses is also optional since they are quite easy to kill without that information.  There are things to collect but not hundreds which is nice for a change. Optional hunting challenges are also available and all of these can be completed while on other missions so the game flows really nicely.The game runs really well and looks amazing. It doesn's slow down at all even with 30 uruks on screen in a dense fortress. That is an achievement on it's own. The game crashed once but my sessions could be even 4 hours in one sitting with the game staying stable so it's well made. Autosaving is frequent and also the nature of the game is such that you never lose much progress anyway. I played with xbox360 controller which the game supports flawlessly. No idea how well keyboard controls work.It took around 20 hours to complete the story missions and do almost all of the side activities. This doesn't include DLC, which should bring few addiotional hours. Shadow of Mordor gets a bit repetetive towards the end, especially with locations and mission types but the AI keeps things interesting to the end and beyond. Recommended!

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												This game feels like one huge quicktime event, or a slightly interactive movie.The combat consists of mashing one button and watching the fight resolve itself in nicely done choreography. If you want to expedite things a bit, or add some moves to the choreography, you may spice up your button mashing with additional keys, as suggested by screen prompts (parry, dodge, etc.). It doesn't actually feel necessary though.The camera is annoying, the controls feel spongy and weird (no strafing, sneak is faster than walk) and the cutscenes are extremely frequent and feel interruptive. Also, this thing calls itself an RPG, but there is no loot, no alternate weapons/armor, no inventory, no character customization whatsoever.I regret this purchase, sale or no.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												Fantastic game.  It's got Batman's combat, but improved.  It's got Assassin Creed gameplay mechanics and format.  And it has a splash of the Skyrim atmosphere.  It's been a long time since I experienced such satisfying combat.  The Nemisis system is fantastic.  It makes losing just as fun as losing.  People don't understand it when I tell them I'm happy with being a loser.  I've got about 20 hours logged in the game at this point and I just finished act 1 of 2 acts.  Of course, about half of that is just from running around collecting things, picking fights with orks and side missions.  The slave missions with bonus objectives are my favorite.  So overall, I think it's going to be a long game that's replayable.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												This review is long, but please bare with me.  Let me start this review by saying that I am NOT an actual "fan" of LOTR, shocking I know, lmao!  I DO love fantasy and RPG elements though.  With that being said I debated on getting this game for close to a week before I clicked "Add to Cart" and hoped I wasn't disappointed.  MY GOD WAS I NOT!  This game, while not at all groundbreaking, has fantastic elements and in my opinion extremely fluid combat similar, AND BETTER, than the Batman Arkham series.  The story is in some ways original and your typical fantasy style but interesting enough to make you want to continue and see what's beyond the next horizon.  New abilities are given at a fair pace and are fun to see how many ways you can destroy your enemies.  I haven't had any technical issues or performance issues with the game.  I use an Xbox 360 Controller and it works flawlessly with no lag or issues.  The stealth elements aren't new to anybody but the penalty for being caught means you are SWARMED, with literal HORDES at times, for a simple miss step, and it can make for a very pulse pounding experience when you are in an Uruk stronghold trying to avoid an archer seeing you before you take him out so he doesn't sound the alarm and unload a metric f*ckton of Uruks ready to coat their weapons in  a few gallons of human plasma.  I give it an 8/10 as it does get a bit repetitive like most games these days, but I will edit this review after some DLC content comes out and it perhaps expands an already promising continued experience.  To put it in another way, I have been a gamer on Steam for almost 5 years and this is the first game I actuall felt deserved a fair and honest review.  I don't give a flying purple Smurf sh*t what anyone says, this game is more than deserving of a fair shake.  Happy gaming!

												Shadow of mordor is Badass to say the least the nemesis system works perfectly making every encounter different.This game has an enteresting story to tell and an emmensly fun open world to explore with badass orc strongholds filled with  little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, captains and sometimes even warchiefs. This game has in my opinion the best hand to hand combat system I have ever used taking Ideas like its instant parry from assassins creed and the combos from batman arkham franchise. It actually takes alot from the ac series like climbing and parkour, taking parts from batman arkham like the stealth and the bulk of the combat and it even takes from the new tomb raider with the collectables each thing telling its own story. This game was almost perfect and if they added these 5 things it could have been my favorite game of all time its already soo close.1. give the plants different uses for example the blue one refills the stamina, the green heals you, the yellow makes your weapons deal more damage and red makes you faster. Also adding crafting with scavenged materials would be awesome2. instead of having graugs and caragors use  different animals from the tolkien universe that are more popular like wargs and cave trolls 3. add dragons yes maybe alot to ask but you cannot deny the badass idea of it, a dragon in each part of the map how badass would that be like the ultimate boss battle4. have ally camps like three camps per location one for elves, one for dwarves, and one for humans. Each camp would have a blacksmith shop where you could by upgrades for weapons and armor that are not mystical but made from leather and metal these upgrades would change your appearance. Also each camp would have a mission that would help the camp making it upgraded and ready to take mordor.5. a third location, in this game there are 2 maps one the sea of nurnun and the other is uden but the third location would be really dark there would be volcanoes smoke fire incredbly op enemies a place drowned in evil this would be the last location you head tothe 5 things I have mentioned where things wanted added but where not needed to make this game great it is well worth the price and in a bit of time when more dlc is released it will be worth buying the premium edition. I give this game a 9/10

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Of all the LoTR games throughout the years, this one definitely tops them all.  From combat, to story, to skill mechanics, the game beats out all previous installments.  SoM does a great job putting you in the world of Middle Earth while also keeping you specifically out of the direct story line of the LoTR, breathing into it a fresh perspective on the game.You play in 3rd person mode and wade through waves of Orcs as you seek to uncover the past behind your ghostly friend who constantly appears and shows you how to use your newly unlocked powers.  The world is divided into segments that you can fast travel between in order to complete various quests (divided into two types, story and level up).  Each quest unlocks new runes and skill points.The game is gorgeous, its graphics are some of the best and the combat mechanics are smooth.  There's very little awkward disconnects in the movement, so you will rarely find yourself looking at fights and wondering how an orc swung his axe 2 feet off from where you are and still hit you.  That being said, the difficulty becomes broken once you're leveled your skills up to a certain point.  Skills like being able to counter by simply tapping the right mouse button when you see the icon means with a little practice you are mostly untouchable.  Add to this some very over powered combos that you can unlock and you're basically the bane of all orcs existence.  This is fun so long as you weren't hoping for a challenge throughout the entire game.  This also can add replay value if you just enjoy wading through enemies and seeing how ridiculous your combo can be.Overall, the game is engaging and learning how to link together your skills in order to master the art of slaughtering orcs is fun.  If you always wished you could be plopped into the epic battles you see in the LoTR movies, this is as close as you're going to get.  If the developers balanced the skills and added a little more variety into the world, this game would be a shining beacon for all other games in the series to aspire to.  Definitely worth the money!

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												"Hey, someone got Assassins Creed in my Arkham Asylum"I have nothing but good to say about this game, although a little buggy sometimes - it works well for a multi-platform release. 2 things struck me about this title, the graphics and the content. The graphics while at their base are quite nice, once you download the HD content pack it becomes quite stunning. It's a must if you host a mighty machine. Secondly, the content right out the gate is quite surprising. This game could easily keep you busy for 30 hours if you work your way through all the side missions. Another huge plus to this game is the multiple ways you can develop your character, offering ways to level Wraith, Talion or even your individual weapons with runes. While I'm still playing through the main quest line I feel comfortable enough to give this game a solid recommendation for most players.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												I finished the game in 25 hours, did all the survival challenges and hunts, collected all the stuff! And so on.My overall experience was very glitch and bug free, though I did encounter some here and there.The animations are extremely well done and beautiful to watch but after awhile, I had seen them all.Combat is fluid and far better than the combat in the Batman games which are known for its wonderful combat.That they are using code and animations from the Assassin's Creed series is blatantly obvious from the moment you start climbing, I even think I noticed some during combat. However, I don't care as the game is very enjoyable.Graphically, it was quite pleasing to the eye and I am very impressed with how incredible the game looked and ran on my computer. (I played on the highest setting)Now onto sound, which is more my thing:The voice acting is extremely good, but don't expect actors from the movies to show up with a voice role, which annoyed me for one scene when you get to...familiarize yourself with an Istari, without giving too much away.After awhile, I swear the same actor did all the Uruks and that annoyed me. I also began to hear the same voice being used for two different Captains amongst the Uruks. Overall though, the VO is top dollah, as they say.The sound design work is familiar to the work done on the movies which was a relief. I heard many references that the sound designer did to keep it in the same field as the films which was sounds that you heard for instance during the reforging of the tower, and the wraith world (Frodo puts on the ring and he enters that domain.)The sounds of the Caragor were great and a lot of detail went into making them interesting and overall believable. I think I hear a seal in there for them during their running animations.The combat sound work was a little bit disappointing as there is no power behind the hits of the swords, however, for the executions, there's some great work in both sound design and mixing happening from the engine, to emphasize the brutality of the animation.I enjoyed the various sounds for Talion's abilities that made you feel powerful and always in control, which is to me, the most important with good sound work.Music:They did not flat out copy or just slap on some Howard Shore and call it a day. There are some great original work in here channeling the spirit of Howard Shore but it goes way beyond that. I enjoyed that they combined musical stingers with the combat when you did well. I enjoyed the opening song the most, which I also think was the main theme of the game.A chant in black speech saying the oh so familiar phrases: "One ring to rule them -" etc.I hope to hear the composer work in other games, because he quickly rose amongst my favorites, just stop and take a listen.Gameplay:Though I enjoyed some of the side-missions at first, they become quickly redundant and boring, it is like they never learned to make good side quests from the mistake of others. That being said, the main quests were enjoyable in nature. I particularly enjoyed a part of the game where you meet a new character who lost his partner and is out looking for a nasty beast. That part was best due to the chemistry of the actor and that it took away from the awful washed out main story. If I played again, I would just avoid doing all the side stuff except the weapon challenges, though there is some interesting memory audio that plays when you collect the objects, you get nothing else from it other than some coins that you can use to upgrade your skills. I was fairly disappointed at that but I guess being able to upgrade stuff is good. Though I got coins by just killing Uruk, which was a far more enjoyable part.The nemesis system is where the game truly shines. I encountered an Uruk I had left for a Caragor to munch on, only to hear him moan about it later and hating me for it. This is a system I hope more games will learn from and use because it was extremely enjoyable to both see and hear the results of what you did to them.Another thing I enjoyed was that the Uruks became more powerful when you died and the political backstabbing they did to each other was hilarious. They rose in power and rank, it was glorious!Like I said, I hope other games incorporate the nemesis system because it was the best part of the entire gameplay experience.They got some stuff to learn in terms of side-quests but else, I think the gameplay was fun.Story:The story and the pacing of the story is, imo, horrible.When you begin, you are thrown into it so quickly, you have no idea why it is happening and it doesn't give you room to breathe which is very important in making a good intro.It is the typical revenge story we have seen so many times over and specially in fantasy. It doesn't try to stand on its own two feet by trying to tell a different kind of story, just rehashing tried and true formulas in story telling which is by now so overly done it smells like grandpa's old socks.I did enjoy that the story for the Wraith and figuring out who he was. He is a huge character amongst LOTR fanatics and I think it might be the reason he was picked for this part. He serves it well but keep in mind that it is off-canon.Very disappointed by the fact that the main character is a Ranger and that they didn't try to make him something completely different. Also the name Talion is horrid; in fantasy we find names that end with "ion" so often it is by now lazy writing in their part. I cannot write much about the story without giving too much away but the writing will sometimes rehash a lot of what the movie writers wrote. You will hear direct quotes from the films every now and again which is silly when they happen. Of course the obligatory: "Fly, you fool!" is heard, though that is copied directly from the pen ship of Tolkien, which I don't mind as much.It is a game  you don't go in for the story, but the background work which Tolkien gave his world. I really enjoyed seeing Morgai flies and hearing about it from the Uruks in their idle chatter.Overall: 8/10Great combat, sound, graphics and animations. Nemesis system is the best partBoring story, main character and side-quest designs.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												Having completed this game's story in 11 hours, I feel it's time for a worthwhile review. Spoilers below.I've been a huge fan of Tolkien's Universe since I was little; I've read the Silmarillion, the Unfinished Tales, all three Books and the Hobbit so many times I've lost count. I've also been privelidged to have been part of a very fine role-playing community on  The Lord of the Rings: Online where I wrote Elven RP guides for the community, and participated in server-wide RP events. Safe to say, I like my Tolkien experiences to stay true to the books. That goes for the games, too. Hence why I often take a wide berth from most, since they all diverge at some point away from the source material.Middle-earth™: Shadow of Mordor™ is one of those games that I wouldn't initially play; I've seen the gameplay footage trailers, and spoke with friends who got the game before me. Ultimately, I went ahead and purchased it because (against my better judgement) I wanted to experience a Middle-earth tale. On that subject I am quite...strained.You take the role of Talion, a Gondorian Ranger who was part of the Durthang-Morannon watch; a Númenorian 'guard' intent on keeping all the Evil of Mordor within the boundaries, since Sauron's defeat in the year 3441 of the Second Age. The Gondorian's have let their watch over the Dark Lands slip since the Kin-strife (a disastrous civil-war in Gondor), allowing the nine Ringwraiths to sneak back in and begin rebuilding their Dark Lord's domain. Sauron, after being driven from Dol Guldur in Mirkwood, returns to Mordor in the year 2942 of the Third Age - attacking the garrisons at Durthang and on the Black Gate, easily overwhelming them. Talion and his wife and son are killed in the assault, but a mysterious wraith appears to him - in Elven attire - announcing that he cannot die. With revenge in his heart, Talion seeks to strike out at the Dark Lord and all who follow him.At this point I must digress and critique the 'lore-friendliness' that Warner Bros. have built this game upon. While they do stick to certain accurate parts of the story, they take the liberty (for the sake of story-telling, of course) by reinventing the great Elven smith Celebrimbor, the Elf who forged the Rings of Power (all except the One, who Sauron alone had a hand in making). WB attempt to write Celebrimbor into the creation of the One by making him the smith that engraved the now-famous phrase in Tengwar along the rim of the ring. Furthermore, WB attempt to tell the tale of how Celebrimbor stole the One and used it to gather an Orc army, unnoticed, to challenge Sauron. For the sake of story-telling, I let this slide as it does give an interesting tale for the game to play - but it's a stark contrast from how Celebrimbor was actually tortured, murdered and his body paraded with arrows shot into it around Eregion (the Elven realm next to Moria).The gameplay is quite reminiscent of Assassin's Creed, but a lot more cruder. It has a specific 'action hack-n-slash' feel to it, but by combining the fun Orc Captains feature, makes each playthrough unique and unexpected. There's a lot of deadpan humour in this game, often from the Uruks themselves, but sometimes from Talion (berating a Dwarf, anybody?). Each enemy is unique, has such hated and are very well acted out that the game actually makes you resent them. Topped with a grand amount of side-quests and collectibles, it's easy to lose some hours in this game just by exploring.I've not ran into any bugs at all, surprisingly, for a game so new. Some of the missions are quite hard, and I've had to repeat them several times, but other than that I have no faults.Lore-friendliness: 3/10Story: 7/10Gameplay: 8/10

												One of the most immersive games I've played in a while. Story telling is good, very J.R.R. Tolkien like but still so far from it. It has a solid main story with very good voice actors behind it, they bring the story itself to life.The gameplay is lots of fun, combat system is like Assassin's Creed meets Batman. So expect very detailed, timing based hack 'n' slash experience while slaying as many Ûruk-hai Orc's as you want to. You can also wallclimb and unlock wraith towers similiar to Assassin's Creeds eagle points. Also as mentioned earlier, you can raze your way across Mordor if you wish to,- and believe me. It is damn fun.Graphics of this game are astonishing. I never seize to be amazed by the light effects that swindle across my sword all the time. It's hypnotizing. The whole in-game world of Mordor is beautifully made and the weather conditions are rude, but turn the world into even more darker place than it was before. I have not played this game with Keyboard + Mouse combo, so on that behalf I can't really tell you anything. But on controller the game shows it's true potential.5/5 would buy again.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Hello everyone. Time for me to go into another review!(This part might hold some minor beginning story spoilers.)Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor is an open world RPG style game in which you play as the Gondorian Ranger Talion, one of the only remaining soldiers to guard the Black Gate. The beginning story is a little sharded and fragmented as the game needs to hold true to canon, but hey that's what you get for having a game with an already pre-determined lore, right?Anyway, the Black Hand of Sauron sacrifices Talion and his entire family as a sort of curse for reasons I don't really understand...I mean he sacrificed you and your family to become one with the wraith himself but instead it went inside you, and now you have all of the skills that this king had in life. Why exactly did it go to you and not him? That's not explained, but whatever, the rest of the story's still good.Your job now is to, as an undying super soldier of Gondor, hunt down Uruk and Orc captains/warchiefs and use some super magic mind reader magic to find out what they know about other captains and warchiefs and the Black Hand, so you can find him and make him undo the curse so you can find rest.Now how's the controls and gameplay in the game? Honestly, I want to say good, but I feel they could've used A LOT of work! The controls are choppy and hard to manage, and require quite a bit of controller finesse in order to get you through a simple doorway. Considering how fast paced and merciless this game's combat is, I'd like to have some very polished, crisp controls to at least not make my controller be a handicap. That'd be great!Sometimes your character will also decide to just do his own thing; Lets say an enemy Orc is to your right on the screen, and there's another to the left. Let's say you want to attack the one on the right first. So you push the control stick to the right and push X. 8/10 the character will go for the right...But 2/10 he'll go up down or left...Now that might not be such a big deal, but when the aforementioned enemy on the right is charging up for an attack with you having only enough HP for 1 more hit, and your character doesn't stop him? That has made me throw my controller on occassion. It's a death,  which shouldn't have happened. Hardware should never be a wall between you and game progress.Your character also seems very fond of walls...There's a sneak feature(Really cool btw, I LOVE the Stealth in this game), which lets you slink around corners and stuff, and pull off some pretty impressive "Neener nee you didn't see me! *Sticks tongue out!*" moments, but sometimes you get a little ahead of yourself and you need to pull a super fast U turn and get back to your corner in the darkness to avoid being spotted by a guard. Well, chances are your characters' irresistable love for hugging walls gets in the way. If you're even an in-game foot or so off and end up running a little into the wall before getting around the corner, your character will hug it, and it's A LOT easier to get 'into' the corner hugging thing, than it is to get back out.This 'auto wall hug' feature has ruined several, otherwise flawless stealth runs in a stronghold, and has also led to some Controller abuse.The quest system can be a bit repetitive, the same objectives in different locations etc. However, as poor as I may think the repetitive quest system is? The execution of the missions, aka going from start to finish in them, can be insanely fun! You can choose to be all sneaky with a bow and be all Legolas like and strive for nothing but headshots etc, or you can go in stealth like with a dagger, or berserker style with a large sword. Sadly there's not really any magic in this game, no mage stuff for you *Sadface*Be that as it may, though. The game has a fantastic difficulty system lined up. There is no real 'easy, medium, hard' cookie cutter selection to choose at the start of the game. Instead of that, they seriously upped the bar of standards with the idea of giving the AI skills and abilities just like you! Some I can remember off the top of my head are:Fears(Such as fear of Carabors, or Ghuls, etc. The Uruk will pretty much flee at the sight of the specific unit in question. Alternatively, fears have a corresponding strength version)Hate(Such as hate of Carabors, or Ghuls, etc. This is the polar opposite of Fears. Instead of fleeing like a frightened cat, the sight of the specific unit will enrage them, making them harder to kill)Weakness/Critical Weakness(Such as to Stealth, ranged, melee, mounted attacks etc. If an Uruk has a weakness to something, it means they can take damage from it, however, if its a critical weakness, they can be one hit killed by the type in question. Say a Captain has a critical weakness to stealth, as well as a regular weakness to ranged. He can be regularly damaged by ranged, but a Stealth attack? Will instantly kill him. Very useful!)Immunities(Polar opposite to weaknesses. Immunities will make it impossible for you to ever damage them with this type. An uruk with immunity to Stealth attacks cannot ever by caught off guard. They are impossible to quietly kill.)The list goes on with Poison weapons, small or large warbands of supporters, bodyguards, stealth awareness, etc. etc. etc. The list is impressively long.These lists of attributes however, and here's the fun part: They're INVISIBLE TO YOU! You don't know exactly what strengths or weaknesses a captain or warchief might have, making it hard to plan a good assault! Of course there's a way to discover these attributes! remember when I mentioned the magic mind meld ability you can use to read their minds? Well it comes in handy here! You can use it on 2 kinds of enemies: uruk Captains, or 'worms'. Uruk captains need no explanation, but Worms are lesser Uruk with more knowledge than they should have. Sort of a 'messenger' if you will. If you can catch them off guard and read their minds, you get to choose an Uruk captain, and instantly learn his weaknesses and/or strengths! If it is an unknown Captain(An enemy you havn't faced yet), you can discover their identity, location, and weaknesses etc. rather than having to do it yourself. Intelligence and information are incredibly important in this game.The graphics are outstanding, the voice acting is par none, I mean this voice acting is some Grade A Epic Stuff, seriously. The people in charge of sound and ambience and voice acting etc. seriously needs a medal or something, cause it was believable, and it made the RP in the RPG seriously easier to agree with. Sadly you don't get dialogues though, so I guess it is more Action/Adventure, and less RPG, but eh, there aren't that many differences between the 2(3).So, how will I rate this game?Story:★ ★ ★ ★ ✰Room for improvement, and some fragmented bits here and there, but overall the story is solid, and merges well with the  pre-existing canon!Gameplay:★ ★ ★ ✰ ✰More room for improvement. Some aspects are cool and fun, but it just doesn't quite make up for how poor the controls are. Very frustrating, choppy character control, difficult to maneuver accurately.Sound:★ ★ ★ ★ ★Perfection incarnate. The sound in this game, and the voice acting, is simply perfection.Graphics:★ ★ ★ ★ ✰I'd give the graphics 5/5, but it gets 4 cause your average every day gaming computer will not be able to handle more than low settings across the board. It takes a high end machine to run it at high or ultra.Overall Score:★ ★ ★ ★ ✰A fantastic game with a few drawbacks and the occassional annoying glitch, but eventually fixed glitches aside, the game is worth it if you're a fan of Lord of the Rings and have some cash to spend.Do I recommend this game? Yes I do.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												Pros :Not bad, but don't misunderstood, it's a pur action game, like Assassin Creeds. Don't think you will play a role game like Skyrim, here you will have to fight, fight, and fight. But it's well rendered, very smooth, and well made, so like an action game, it rocks. You got powers trees, swordman, thief and bowman play style, and the ambiance is the dark mordor of lord of the ring, including lore story parts, golum, orcs, elves, and sauron. Cons :Just it's quite repetitive though, when you're dead, you will respawn at towers, and all enemies are back again. Even if you turn around for a while, enemies are back too, as you are in an undead area at start.  The orcs captain system is very strange, it doesn't add anything to the game : when you kill a boss, or an orc slay you, there's like an orcs boss tree map that is updated, but who care of orcs boss tree map ? Sometimes, the missions are really boring (like find some rare herbs in a small area). And it's a mess to play with keyboard, this game is really designed for consoles. For linux users, you will have to deal with a big bug of bodies not rendered : you should add "__GL_ShaderPortabilityWarnings=0 %command%" to the launch options if you got nvidia proprietor driver, as explain in a discussion topic.  So not a bad game, maybe to much repetitive, but around 20 bucks it worth it, as it's nice game though. I recommand it as an action game in a Lord of the ring univers, but don't recommand it if you wanna play a role game (unfortunatly there's no "mixte" recommendation). At full price, I don't recommand it though, as it's way to much repetitive. It's not a game you will replay when finished. So the recommend balance is going to No.
