												9/10A great action game. Geat LOTR lore. Great mechanics.PROS- Nemesys system. It's excellent and fun.- Lot of action. I'd say gameplay is like Assassin's Creed, but harder than the first 2 (Only ones I have played)- Lots of Lord of The Rings Lore. You can learn a lot of LOTR Universe.- It's really fun to kill Orcs. But you know what is funnier? To send an orc to kill another orc.CONS- As other have pointed out, the only think you can do in this game, is to kill orcs. In very different ways, but killing is killing. It suffers the same repetitive syndrome as the first Assassin's Creed. Let's hope second part of this game will bring  a variety of things to do, kind of what EA did with Assassin's Creed II.- Really short Main Campaign. You can beat it under 15 hours.TL; DR If you like LOTR and Action games, this is a must buy.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												First off i want to say that i love the LOTR world. Kind of a nerd about it so coming into playing this game i have had my biasness.Story (10/10)Story in any game to me in any game in paramount so therefore i must say this game does not dissapoint at all. The story in this game is one of the best if not the best i have ever experienced. As i progressed throught this story i wasnt just the avenger but rather i felt like a key player in the LOTR world and how the story would eventually play out (if you read and watch LOTR movies). So the story did not dissapoint at all.Gameplay (8/10)This is where i kind of feel i am nit picky (only because its LOTR). The general combat mechanics are easy to get used to and get very proficient at. That being said you feel as though you are a baddass fighting multiple eneimes at one go and kicking the $hit out of everyone. Now killing the more difficult bosses and instances thats a different ball game, you need to do your research (intetrogate minions). You want to use every advantage you can get. So gameplay wise really well done, what i would like to see different would be the ability to maybe use different swords in the LOTR world.Graphics (9/10)One of the better looking game to me, i played it maxed out at 1080p. Enviroment looks nice, background looks really really nice. Animations are smooth and play out nicely.Overall: Buy this game its cheap as of now and well worth the time to play it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												I'm making this review after finishing the main storyline. (Which took me around 15 hours of gameplay)The game is amazing,  Every action scene in the game are just wonderful. Gameplay is just like Batman and Asassin's Creed combined so if you have played any of these games before, you'll get familiar pretty fast. Storyline is enjoyable, honest, it was good, especially if you're a LOTR fans, you'll appreciate it. Now back to gameplay, actually i'm quite impressed with the world system. Hunting and and plotting to whether assassinate or rules the captains of each area is fun and is the main attraction for me in this game. Claiming your territories, expanding your army and finally Fight and make the warchief submit to you is just satisfying to do.  The battle sometimes can be very unpredictable. Once when i was fighting this one captain and all of sudden 2 other captains arrive and i was completely overwhelmed and ended up killed, it was hard. But sometimes it also can be very easy. Each captain or warchief has different set of weakness and power. Some can be killed instantly with stealth kill or some will run in fear in the sight of what they fear, it can be caragor, a graug or even a fire (lol, scared of fire) . Either way the game is really fun to play.The only complain i get for this game, is the Final Boss....How the heck that is even count as one??!!??Figthing The Tower with Stealth Kill? Figthing the Black Hand with Quick Time Event ?? Oh c'mon!!I was so exited when i'm about to fight them, I was expecting a brutal, fierce, chaotic big war !! After all of my effort dominating all the 5 Warchief !! Dissappointed in that.... . .Figthing the 5 Hands is also easy.... . .Figthing the Hammer (middle boss) is way harded than that...That aside... i would recommend this game to anyone who wants to spend some of his/her time playing a good quality games. Good Stuff !!Now, i'm gonna do all of the side mission !!! (a lot of 'em, lol)EDIT :Now that i'm done doing all the DLC, let's talk a lil' bit more.I'm gonna be honest here, Lord of The hunt DLC is so so, a little bit harder than story mode, but end pretty quick, The new monster system are good though, so yea.. Nice little DLC.The Bright Lord DCL on the other hand is a masterpiece on its own. Seriously, we play as Celebrimbor and must conquer Sauron's Army one by one just like in the story mode, BUT HARDER (Most of the captain and warchief are above level 20). What's more challanging is that Cerebrimbor only had half of the stat from maxed out Talion on story mode and Can't slow time when shooting, making it harder to shoot when in Chaotic battle. That aside, after Building the 5 tower and Branding all the 5 warchief, we're gonna face Sauron and this time, it's not gonna be like the lame battle we had in story mode. But anway, i thought it's gonna be easy to face Sauron because i had 5 warchief on my side but after some battle going on, Sauron take controll of all the Warchief and we defeat all the 5 Warchief AT THE SAME TIME (MY GOD THAT WAS HARD) and after doing so, Sauron appear again and this time HE REVIVE ALL THE WARCHIEF I'VE KILLED. My God.. In the end, i must fill my One Ring gauge to defeat Sauron. In the end, It was the most Satisfying battle I've had in Shadow of Mordor, really, the best one turn out to be in the DLC.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												TL;DR Good game, grab it when it goes on sale. If you only do the story quests, it will probably take you about 6 hours to beat total.  There's a ton of content, but a lot of it is repetitive and the only satisfaction you get is getting closer to 100% completion.  The combat mechanics are very similar to Assassins Creed with the dodging and countering every attack, but it has quite a few added flares (as it should, considering combat seems to be the major focus of this game).  The stealth/climbing is similar to Assassin's Creed as well except there's not a huge amount of climbable terrain outside of strongholds.The story is great, but shortlived.  It seems like they took a story that could last five times as long and shortened it down due to time constraints or laziness.  Overall a good game, but definitely not worth the $50 they're asking for at release.  Get it when it goes on sale, if I had to do it again, I'd pay no more than $20 for it.

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												Visually the game is stunning, even on ultra high which is the best my gpu (7950) can manage before it gets very noisy. The story is very good although a bit shorter than expected, and the gameplay itself is, in my opinion a mix of skyrim and assassin's creed and mostly the best bits. My one niggle with this game which has caused me to stop playing on several occasions throughout the story and other missions, is the respawn rate and seeming power of orcs. Engaging 20+ orcs at a time is a given at several points in the game but when that number constantly refills despite firing an arrow at the orc running to the alarm and killing them left right and centre it gets very frustrating. Not only that but as the orcs constantly respawn, even if you have previously cleared out the area, several captains will 'happen' to show up making the odds very much stacked against you. Not only that but when you finish a mission to disrupt the ork heirarchy, the captain in question goes back to full health and orks, after killing all of the ones in the area, spawn out of nowhere.In conclusion, it is a great game both visually and in gameplay both story and side missions, but don't blame me if you find some of the ork respawn behaviour an absolute pain in the behind!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Assassins Creed + Arkham CIty + Far Cry = Shadow Of Mordor. BOTTOM HAS SLIGHT SPOILERS SO BE AWAREProsThe wonderful stealth and agility and movement system of Assassins Creed with the perfect combat system of the Arkham games plus the outpost captures and healing plants and strategy of Far Cry. All wrapped in the gorgeous and unforgiving dangerous setting of Mordor. This game is truely gold and everyone who has ever played any of the three series of games i mentioned will have a blast with Shadow Of Mordor. I enjoyed the nemesis system which brought purpose and replayability to the game. The extremely violent combat gave me a rush, especially when taking over outposts and capturing warchiefs.ConsThe shortcomings are limited but still need to be noted. at times it was hard to control Talion. A few times he wouldn't climb up unless i went down and back up again. The camera, though 90% on point, would sometimes make things hard to see in tight areas. But the main thing that annoyed me was the nemesis system getting in the way of itself and gameplay. Almost everytime i went to capture a warchief, there would be other captains that would see me and then the nemesis system would direct my screen away from Talion and to the captain for his quick speech saying he has seen me before. Though the system is great and above all other games' AI, it sometimes got in the way especially during intense battles where every move counts and the flow of the combat means everything, just to be thrown off by the nemesis system kicking in. It didnt ruin the game at all, but was annoying.VerdictThe few problems i had didnt turn me off to the game. it remains to be one of my favorite, definitely my top pick for games released in 2014. i only found one small glitch that made a few of the walls bright neon colors but that was literally the only glitch and it was during free roam so it didnt hurt gameplay. Overall i give the game a 9/10 simply for being able to blend 3 game mechanics from 3 different games into one beautiful looking game with plenty of satisfying gameplay. its not a 10 just for the nemesis system getting in the way of itself. Also not a 10 for the reason ill explain in the spoiler section.SPOILERS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!SPOILERS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!i felt the ending of the game was so build out through my 30 hour gameplay. the story of him avenging his family's death was so compelling, even if not unique. His friendship with the hunter and queen. all very well done but i feel like Mordor needed....well more Mordor. the world seemed a little bland and the story needed more scenes like when Talion and his minions stormed the gates, that was exciting and had such a Lord Of The Rings feel! one big team against another in an all out fight in an open field. I loved that part but it only lasted a few minutes. Also the end we so built up just to be a quick time event where you hit a few buttons and beat the dark lord!!! common!! Ive been wanting to fight him since i first watched LOTR!!!! i wanted a real awesome boss fight. the only real boss fight was in the cave with the hunter. but the ending did leave with sort of a cliff hanger, hopefully a second game will bring a more exciting setting, boss fights and epic moments of two teams just clashing in all out warfare!!! other than that, everything the game did, it did it right. it was fun and now i still have 63.5% left in the game even after the main story!. plenty of fun packed in, a real joy to play.

												Middle-earth™: Shadow of Mordor™ is not a game i would normally buy or play. The reviews compared it to the Batman Arkam games and they never appealed so why did i buy this title. Honestly no idea.I think i got it for 50% of during the steam holiday sale but my opinion now would be even at full price this game would be worth the money.The game runs smooth, the action can be breathtaking. The scenery can be a bit samey after a while but half way through it opens up anew area which is a tad greener :) There's a mission you can play early on where you go to one of the strongholds and you have to defeat 100 uruks, when i first tried this i got pumped big time but a few unlocks later and you look forward to those battles with relish.My biggest worry was the controls, as i'm getting on a bit now (middle aged is the term) I honestly can't be bothered with learning multiple button presses combined to create a certain type of attack or defense. Fortunatly the game glides you in gently meaning it's pretty basic early on and it's only as the game progresses that you have these additional features where a press of E here or R there pulles of some amazing manouver.I'm now over 30 hours in and about 70% through the game and i'm dreading the fact i'm closing in on the end.I can only say i highly recommend this, it's fun it's enthralling and it's worth the money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
TLDR: It is beyond phenomenal. My personal GOTY RPG for 2014. BACKGROUND & SYNOPSIS: This game builds upon the lore that Tolkien cemeted in history with his literature, while also adopting the dark, gritty atmosphere Jackson gave us with his cinematic adaptations. It is truly the best of both worlds combined. The story takes place in between The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings stories, so there is no trek to Mount Doom to destroy the One Ring - it is an all new experience. ME:SOM is a sandbox RPG with hack and slash fighting mechanics. The map is about as big as Arkham City, with your character being able to expertly maneuver around it with Assassin's Creed-like parkour. The setting of the game takes place in and around Mordor, not the entire Middle-Earth. That is an important point that many have missed upon purchase. You take control of a mortal Ranger named Talion, who after an immense tragedy has been banished from death. Unable to cross over into the otherworld, he forms an unlikely alliance with an Elven Wraith by the name of Celebrimbor, who along with no recollection of his previous life, also bears the same curse. Together you explore the Land of Mordor, recovering abandoned Forge Towers to act as your "Home Base". Each new tower recovered unlocks the map for that section, and thus allows you to fast travel between towers. Each story mission completed recovers new memories for Celebrimbor, and unlocks new abilites in your skill tree for Talion to master. Both Ranger and Wraith abilities are attainable.ENEMIES & EXAMPLE OF THE NEMESIS SYSTEM: The primary enemy encountered are Uruk's of all different sizes and features. The Uruk society functions with an entire militaristic ranking system consistently playing out while in-game. Everyone starts off as level 1 Grunts, except for the already established Captain and Warchiefs. If you are slain in battle, the Uruk who slayed you gets a promotion and gains a power level. This opens up multiple scenarios that can play out - one being the now level 2 Uruk gets promoted to Captain, but there are no available slots in Sauron's army..so he challenges a higher level Captain to a duel. More than likely the higher level wins, and the scum who just got promoted dies - permitting the victor Uruk to gain a power level. Each Uruk Captain has their own resistances and weaknesses, which can be exposed by beating another Captain to a pulp and interrogating him for another Captain's information. The ability to possess the mind of an Uruk develops as the game does, eventually giving Talion the ability to brand an Uruk, bringing them to your side to fight for you and betray their Uruk bretheren. This also opens up multiple possible scenarios for the battlefield. Other enemies include Caragors - four legged beasts that you can let loose on societies or tame to ride into battle on; Ghuls - deformed Elves that live in dark underground caves and can spit acid; and Graugs - giant amphibious trolls that terrorize land and water, you can tame and ride these into battle as well. Depending on how you play your game, the main campaign may take you anywhere from around 10 to 30 hours to complete. However you can get almost endless hours in if you are a completionist and you do all of the side missions, challenges, artifact gathering, monster hunting as well as just playing around with The Nemesis system - there are plenty of activities to do and two whole maps to do them on. Currently I have logged 60 hours into the game and have only completed roughly 35% of the main story.There are other game modes included if you purchase the season pass, including: Guardians of the Flaming Eye Exclusive Warband Mission; Trials of War Challenge Series: Play 4 challenge modes - Test of Power, Test of Speed, Test of Wisdom and the Endless challenge; Lord of the Hunt Story Mission; The Bright Lord Story Mission; and future content.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Before I begin, let me say that I am more than a little biased. I first read the Lord of the Rings when I was 8, right after I discovered and read the Hobbit. I've read just about every scrap of paper that had "Middle Earth" written somewhere on it (With the exception of Children of Hurin unfortunately), so you can believe I have heavily tinted nostalgia goggles on here. Please, bear this in mind.Let's start with the gameplay. I massively enjoyed just about every aspect of the gameplay in this game. Monolith took great game mechanics that had been used in games like Assassin's Creed and the Arkham series, and greatly polished, if not perfected them. The combat is extremely responsive, every time I hit a button, the correct action was taken (Unless I hit the wrong button, a problem I fumbled through several times >.<). There is nothing quite like the visceral feel of fighting a large number of orcs, especially in the later stages of the game where Talion is fully upgraded and taking heads off with a frequency that would make revolutionary France jealous. The animations were smooth, with the expected clipping and distance bugs very rarely making an appearance. Difficulty wise, I found that the A.I. was quite proficient in throwing mixed groups my way, to ensure I kept my tactics varied; inevitably making my fights look more interesting. Fighting ten Uruks? No prob. Fighting fifteen? There's probably some archers in there. Maybe some Beserkers. I'll have to keep my eyes open. Thirty Uruks? I should probably get out of there. The amount of times I had to run and hide instead of just wrecking my opponents was very refreshing. The Nemisis system also provided a good bit of difficulty by churning out Captains with interesting strengths and weakneses; most of which forcing me to carefully plan out my strikes before initiating with a distraction or sneak attack. Even the politics of the Uruk society were sort of difficult to keep under your thumb; with branded Captains losing to stronger or brighter Uruks while you're busy on other missions (or dead).My complaints with the gameplay stem mainly from the lack of variety. One could see that Monolith was trying to make the game more interesting with the hunting challenges, survival challenges, slave missions, and weapon legends (Which were all good flavour I'll admit); but at the end of the day, Shadow of Mordor is an orc killing simulation, and not much more. Granted it is a FANTASTIC orc killing simulation, but I would love to see some more content. Perhaps the DLC?Visually, the game is stunning. I had just upgraded my graphics card for this game, and I was not disappointed. Although there is only two areas in the game, there was just enough variety to keep my eyeballs happy. The orc fortresses were well designed and lent fantastic atmosphere to my sneaking/slaughtering. All of the locales were distinct, and most could be tied to a particular purpose by the gubbins alone. Finally, the story, and here is where is I will probably get some flak. I loved it. Now, remember what I said at the beginning of the review? Where I've read just about all the lore Tolkien pumped out about Middle Earth and it's citizens? I am fine with the writers taking a little bit of artistic license with the lore, and more importantly I believe Tolkien would too. His whole reason for writing the adventures of Middle Earth was that he wanted to make good stories, something for his children and friends to simply enjoy delving into. He grew up on tales like Beowulf, had friends like C.S. Lewis, and wrote stories that hinged on the unlikeliest of circumstances. So when I hear other hardcore Tolkien fans complaining angrily about the likelyhood of this game's premise, or screaming about the story not holding absolutely true to the lore; I can't help thinking how these fans are getting lost in the tradition of Tolkien's stories instead of getting lost in the spirit behind them. Shadow of Mordor gives us an intrigueing story that doesn't put on kid gloves. Like the mythos it's based on, Shadow's story is mature and epic in scope, with tonnes of potential.I would love to see extra campaigns added through DLC for this game. In my opinion, the only thing this game needs, is more content.

content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												What can I say? Finally we have a modern video game holding Lord Of The Rings IP, which is worth playing! This game is a must own for pretty much any gamer out there.I love the gameplay, It feels smooth and you really get into the character, regardless of the pretty all-out start of the story cinematic in the beginning. Combat is very similiar with AC and Batman franchise, so most of you will get in fast with the game. Combat is great, it's fun, it looks great and I love the variation in moves our character Talion holds. Also there are few approaches to combat and you can go for your own combat style and improve Talion alongside your style. It's great.Nemesis system is absolute killer and makes the true fun for the game. I love watching how Orc captains and warchiefs rise in ranks, fight each other. I love the fact that I can become a kingmaker and intervene a duel between captains, make one of them run away and spare his life, while I slay the other.Side missions are fun and I think the medium length is well-thought per mission.Exploring is fun, but I think there could be slight improvement in this regard, but this is just nit-picking.Final verdict: no severe bugs, lot things to do, nice features and all settings customisable to your liking. Must own game, buy it now when it is very cheap for the next 24hours!

												PROS:Good blend of Batman Arkham combat and Assassin's Creed open-world questing, nemesis system sets it apart from those games...perfect amount of content without feeling bloated/padded or consolidated too muchVery high quality graphics with good performance scaling (advanced options screen actually has explanations of what each adjustment does, which is a nice bonus), cinematics, sound design, voice acting...all around superb production valueCONS:No multi-gpu support (SLI/Crossfire) as of this review, 3 months after release which is pretty lame...highest texture quality requires 6GB(!!!) of VRAM on your primary card so multi-gpu support wouldn't help with that anyway...despite all this, game still ran just fine on my R9 290 with High quality textures, FXAA with motion blur @ 1920x1200, even during intense action so this is mainly a minor annoyanceINTENSE swings in mouse sensitivity/acceleration (particularly while stealthing/crouching) that is supposedly tied to framerates and sync with monitor Hz, possibly also with the motion blur...overall this game is pretty great for a console port but this seems to be one of the unavoidable compromises*possible spoiler* the last two boss fights with the Tower and the Black Hand are extremely disappointing and brief and this game uses very lazy QTE mechanics in all the parts that you are fully expecting to be the most difficultoverall this is going to make a lot of folks' Top 10 for 2014 lists and i feel it's well deserved, definitely worth whatever price it's being sold for

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												So let me start off with the things i like about the game (i assume you've played it and beaten it? if not-spoiler alert!)1. the graphics are AMAZING. the motion graphics and battle sequences are fantastic. the blood, the guts, the slashes, the jumping, the sneaking, the zooming in and out, even the quick camera shifts...all amazing. I was very impressed. i was also impressed the game didn't glitch or have trouble keeping up with the fast-paced hi-res sequences.2. the story line and background info is phenomenal. although some of the things that take place are fictional even in the Tolkien world (Black Hand? Celebrimbor mind-controlling an orcish army? this game forces Tolkien fans to dig up their "Tolkien Companion" and do their homework, because the game seamlessly mixes fact with fiction), it's nonetheless obvious that the game developers are Tolkien fanatics, and have read their LOTR appendices and the Silmarillion. I REALLY LOVED how this game took place in times and places NOT covered in the books and movies. The Second Age of Middle Earth was not developed by Tolkien enough, in my opinion, and you have to really infer and piece the history of it together, because entire civilizations rise and fall within a single paragraph in Tolkien's notes (like Eregion, Khazad-dum, and the Gondorian guard on Mordor. ahem). So i was pleasantly surprised to delve into an untraveled corner of Middle Earth.Also, the story of Talion was pretty cool, and drove the plot/game very well. and discovering that the wraith was in fact Celebrimbor was pretty darn cool. I expected him to be some other random made up character like the Tower.3. the sidequests are fun, challenging, and rewarding. Artifacts, Ithildin, and forging a name for your weapons are all great ideas, and i enjoyed bumbling around ignoring the main story for a while to pick up all the extras.4. the controls are SUPER manageable and easily master-able, and i enjoyed the challenge of learning how to press the right button at the right time. it's also much less cumbersome than scrolling through hundreds of items like on Skyrim.5. the Uruk chain of command is really quite an impressive system. I'm sure it will be popping up in other games soon, because it was super fun using the politics of uruks against each other, even without branding.I also liked that you could get into blood feuds with uruks who had defeated you, and your death set the changes of leadership in motion. pretty cool.Now i will tell you what i didn't like, or what i was confused about and would like feedback on:1. did i miss something, or is this game extremely short? i logged only 30-ish hours and i'd beaten 78% of the game, including the main quest. after the main quest, there's not much incentive to ramble around picking up the last few artifacts and fighting endless uruks without any ultimate consequence. and i didn't know that picking the flowers was actually a mission--but there's no way i'm doing that.2. i didn't see a difficulty meter, so i'm left to conclude that this game was purposely made very easy. although some captains were difficult to defeat (namely the ones with shields, or the Combat Masters), i rarely actually got into such a pickle that i couldn't jump up a wall and sneak around restoring my life before plunging back in. I expected much more of a challenge throughout the game, rather than just getting used to the controls.3. speaking of which, what happened to actually FIGHTING bosses? by the time you learn how to brand, war chiefs practically kill themselves, and the Tower and even the Black Hand were basically video interruptions. It was cool, but i definitely wanted a challenge, which made the end of the game a bit of a downer.4. I know that this is Shadow of Mordor...but we're not even going to SEE any elves? or dwarves (save Torvin)? or anyone? no misty mountains? no rivendell? no Gandalf? not even EAGLES? come now. Artifact references are not enough. I was impressed by some of the cool stuff they referenced with the artifacts, but I expected to have a full map of Udun, a full map of Nurnen, a full map inside Mordor somewhere, and at least one full map in a well-known place. Minas Tirith? Eregion?this flaw is easily fixable, though--expansion packs! but i kind of doubt they will.5. Why in the world did they feel the need to cameo Gollum? of all the awesome characters that could have cameoed, they chose Jar-Jar. I mean, Gollum. No Gandalf? not even Radagast? They could have at least SHOWN the two blue Istari!at least it wasn't Orlando Bloom.I think there are a few more for both pros and cons, but those are the big ones. there were some smaller things that didn't make much sense (like why there would be artifacts that tell stories? why Talion was chosen? how did Celebrimbor actually get fused with Talion again? what's with the random white towers? why do you pick flowers to regain health? what happened to the hot blond chick? how was Saruman in the Queen's mind?) but weren't too bothersome. and it's true that game developers have to take some artistic license, so to speak, with such things.Overall, I give the game a B+. I would give it a full A if these three things could be changed (and maybe future expansions/updates will change them?):1. Develop the full story. if i get to clock 150 Steam hours to contentedly finish Skyrim and its numerous side quests (discluding any expansions) just once, then Warner Bros can surely put together a game that lasts for at least a third of that time. I don't want it to drag on and on, that's not what I mean--I want them to take the story to its fullest potential, and be in-depth. There is SO much content in this game, but without a plot to drive it it gets monotonous. I would have been totally content fighting captains and war chiefs in 5 other map areas just to reach the Black Hand!2. Make it more difficult (and include actual BOSSES). i should be able to restart this game like Halo and play it on Legendary, where even a single slice or arrow will cause me to drop to my knees and survive a "last effort" attempt.3. Explore more than just two random, un-noteworthy areas of Middle Earth. It was original and cool, but i don't think anyone will be content to actually play out the entire game in the ruins of who-knows-what/where/why, and the jungle ruins of who-knows-what/where/why.

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												This game has surprised me a bit, since getting it. It has shades of Assassin's Creed about it, spatterings of Batman Arkham City, and little droplets of The Witcher 2 when it comes to combat at least. This means you have to use stealth, aggression and evasion in pretty much equal measures, althougfh the game doesn't really force you down a specific route. The abilities you unlock are very cool, as as the boosts to base stuff like the runes on your weapons (you can have up to 5 that enhance all sorts of things like % chance to gain health back on stealth kill etc), so there's a lot you can do to customise your character.Now, let's be realistic here, this game won't really win any medals for story-telling - it's fairly basic, with a bit of depth, nnothing more - but here's the thing, you won't miss it. The combat, unlockables, environments and the Nemesis sytem (allowing you to dismantle, meddle with, or topple Sauron's army of Orcs) supercede any lapses in story-telling. The game covers two very large areas and there are many side quests and things to get involved in. You don't have to travel by foot (running or stealthing etc), you can also use the fast travel system which unlocks when you capture towers, or just tame a wild Caragor (big angry dog type thing) and ride that, carving through any Orcs you might encounter along the way.The only thing I wouild add, personally, is a character creation part to the game. Although the game follows the story of one guy (well two atually, ut that's a spoiler, almost) once you start to see the story played out you realise it doesn't have to be him, look like him, act like him etc. I would've like to have seen the customisation present in pretty much every aspect of the game, also extend to the character himself. Given that the story, apprently, doesn't quite fit with the LOTR lore, it wouldn't matter if the main protagonist was a short, fat dude or a gigantic woman with a voice like Barry White. There are currently only two skins for the charcter too at the moment (the default one, and a custom one you get by registering on the WB Games site through the game), so even that would've added another layer of something. But I digress, the game doesn't suffer from its omission.Anyway, I got this when it was under £30, and have not regretted it one bit. I didn't really see much hype about it (unlike games like Destiny which seems to be another hype-♥♥♥♥♥ game - all mouth, no trousers), and have enjoyed every moment of it. Being the completionist that I can be in these types of games, I've found all sorts of stuff to do, and clocked up a pretty decent amount of time away from the main story developing my character on side-quests and the Nemesis System. I've heard from others the ending isn't all that good, but I'm not sure I care .. with 20+ hours in the game already (and I've just entered the second of two acts, it doesn't really matter when the journey is as fun as this.I should probably finish by saying that I am by no means a LOTR fan, in fact I think Tolkein is a horrific writer, and Hobbits can go screw themselves with their big feet .. so my views are purely based on the gameplay, without a sniff of fanboyism anywhere near them. With gameplay this in-depth, they could've called it "Shadows of One Direction" and I'd still enjoy it. Well worth a buy, perhaps once it dips below £25 for those unsure about fighting games.8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												After now completing the main game and collected all the collectables in the game and most other side mission stuff, I feel I should now write a review after having a lot of fun.The gameplay places you in a small but open world as you travel about killing Uruk. The game features a system where enemies that kill you get promoted and those captains that kill you get stronger. It's a really cool system as all these Uruk seem to have their own personality and will remember you. The combat is pretty much like♥♥♥♥♥Creed and Batman. If the combat in those games weren't to your liking then you're not going to like the fighting in this game. However there is nothing to differentiate the combat mechanics beyond the abilities you unlock. In short this is a frankly repetitive game. Imagine♥♥♥♥♥Creed, the first one. The dialogue with these captains are simply superb. Even the idle chat of just the normal mobs in this game made me grin a few times. The game is superbly voice acted with all the characters, Uruk and yourself. The gallows humour comes in thick and fast from the Uruk as they talk amongst themselves while you're sneaking about in their base.The story simply has you going about from Point A to point B to kill things. While following the main story you'll unlock story related skills, which helps encourage you to finish the story. However, if you were to just do the main story quests and nothing else, then the game can be completed in one sitting in about six hours or less. Also, it needs to be said, the ending is horrible. There is no way around it. It's frankly terrible. The ending finishes with three QTE events, followed by a short cutscene and that's it.The graphics in the game are nothing to write home about. It's beautiful and it sets the setting and theme well, but not the best in the industry. Frankly that's fine because the art direction is also beautiful. The game hasn't gotten boring to look at during my play time so that's a good thing.All told this is a game that got me to pull an all nighter for the first time in years. It drew me in to the Tolkien universe unlike any Lord of the Rings game I have ever played and I enjoyed every second of it. Repetitive, yet tons of fun and funny at times as well with the voice acting. Worth the current purchase price? Yes, if you don't mind the repetitive gameplay and the frankly horrible ending. If those things are not to your liking then I still recommend picking it up, but at a discounted price, as this is still an enjoyable game which got me and the rest of my Steam friends talking to each other as we played this game. All told, worth your time to play, even with a back log of games.Thank you for taking the time in reading this.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												This game is so good it almost makes you forget that the gameplay is a weird lovechild of the Batman Arkham series and the Assasins Creed series, to an almost ridiculous extent. However, even if you do notice this, is quickly forgotten by the overall epicness of Mordor. The story is appealing to hardcore fans, but also accessible to new players, but if you like LOTR as much as I do, then this game is a an absolute blast. The pros: Great graphics, epic supernatural combat and a great source material. The cons: no greater challenge for players that like hard games, Talion is not the most interesting character, and you can pretty much get OP soon and just run over half of the game. Overall, a worthy purchase, the best LOTR games I've played and one of the funniest RPG's I've ever played.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												SHADOW OF ARKHAM'S CREED ...I'm sure that I'm not the first person to point out how much this games plays like a mash-uo of the Arkham and Assassin's Creeds games, just set in Middle Earth.  That's not a knock on the game at all, though (at least in my book).  If you liked those series (and most people did), you're going to like this game.  Period.That's not to say there is nothing original.  The nemesis system, for example, is quite fun, especially when defeated foes come back at exactly the worst possible time.  I was running a mission to defeat a pretty tough dude (for my level at the time).  There I am slowly wearing him down, trying to pick off his elite guard, dodging hurled spears ... and two other orc captains show up for revenge.  What was already tough fight suddenly because hilarious and insane.The open world is also quite nice.  Sure, there are tons of side missions ... but never underestimate the sheer joy of just walking around the countryside at random, clearning out camps and strongholds on a whim.  There's something deeply satisfying about picking off archers from a distance, stealth killing your way around a small encampment, or just walking brashly into the middle of twenty-thirty orcs, and emerging victories several minutes later.  On a side note, this makes it a game that can still be very rewarding in 15-30 min segments, if that's all you can manage on a particular evening.If you're still not sold, this game is on sale quite a bit.  I got the whole GOTY shabang for $10.  That makes it one of my biggest steals in years.Finally, if you don't buy it, all the hobbits will die.

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Shadow of Mordor is an excellent game exhibiting high quality in almost all aspects of game design, including gameplay, mechanics design, and visual design. In essence, it takes the structure/premise of Assassin's Creed; couples it with combat from Batman: Arkham, and sets in a Lord of the Rings package. And that is a great combination.The greatest of the game's aspects is gameplay - the developers have crafted an experience that is fun to play and will have you coming back for more. It manages to instill a feeling of great power in the player, but acually has some great balancing that prevents the player from being overpowered in the game. Apart from this, the game is full of small, very intelligent features that add to the overall experience.The lore/setting is of course, fantastic. It's very deep and well established; it barely needs to be stated - The Lord of the Rings is *the* fantasy universe that all others strive to be.One criticism I can level at the game is its story. While the lore is deep and interesting, the story, for the most part, is shallow and quite unengaging. One character and subplot has depth and is interesting, but all others are not.This is actually overlook-able, however, because the rest of the experience is so solid.Overall, this is a very well-made game that is genuinely fun to play. I recommend it.

												Played for 2 and a half hours; died about 5 times and got about 2 nemeses. 10/10 would get killed again.Anyway, whilst the game seems easy at first, as the fighting is mostly just relentlessy clicking your mouse, it becomes more difficult just about the moment the prologue ended. Taking out a band of orcs isn't too difficult, as long as you keep paying attention and click at the right time. But as soon as some leader joins in, well, get ready for something you didn't expect. So whilst the battle gameplay looks simple at first, it gets harder quite soon, AND it looks terrific. All the buttons you have to smash, the small cut scenes, they all blend in perfectly. I think I'm off on a vacation to Mordor the upcoming weeks. Might as well start walking.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												HMmm The game is set some time between The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings, and Middle-Earth lore has been handled well throughout. The story feels considered, brand new elements mesh well with established canon, collectibles offer nods to the likes of the Istari, Quendi, Dwarves and Bagginses, and there are even a couple of Tolkien's ubiquitous songs and verses snuck in between loading screens. Shadow of Mordor offers a deft and studious adaptation of the character of Celebrimbor, too, who is mentioned only briefly in The Lord of the Rings books but explained in more depth in The Silmarillion - as are the origins of Sauron, who we see in his 'fair guise' as the Vanyan Annatar during Celebrimbor's memories, which return to him throughout the campaign with the help of a tricksy Gollum. We also glimpse, in greater detail than ever before, the forging of the Rings of Power.One of the most enduring themes of Tolkien's universe has been the corrupting influence of power, but this has almost always been explored through the eyes of individuals that refuse to abuse that power. In death, Talion is free to do what those characters were never able to, and you experience first-hand what an intoxicating high that can be. At the start of the game you're not much more than a lowly Ranger, sneaking through camps and silently slitting Orcish throats in the night. By the end of the game you're boldly strolling through those same camps, as terrified uruks whisper tales of the Ranger-turned-Gravewalker over fortifying gulps of grog. There's plenty to see and do in Mordor when you're dead; all that's left, in the words of a wise old wandering wizard, is to decide what to do with the time that is given to you.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												This game, along with Dark Souls 2, is in the running for my Game of the Year. The combat is basically the same as the Arkham games, although I felt that at first it wasn't as flowy but over time it became just as flowy as the Arkham series. The story itself is pretty good. The plot is well done and the cutscenes are gorgeous, and the amount of outside lore put into the game by Monolith is outstanding, and it enriches the world deeply. The nemesis system is the elephant in the room. It's definitely the most innovative system I've played through in a long time. I remember my nemesis Mugluk Graug Slayer would simply refuse to die. I must have "killed" (if you don't behead said Uruk, there's a chance that he can come back) him at least 5 or 6 times and he kept coming back with a vengeance. I also had a hilarious experience with an Uruk by the name of Gunza the Rhymer. I beat him every time he fought me, and every time he came back he look more and more messed up in his face. In our final encounter, he retreated, only to be promptly eaten by a caragor (the Middle-Earth equivalent of a lion). Encounters like this make the game super fun and super addicting. I give this game a 10/10. It fulfilled all of my expectations and has given me a great time. I look forward to scouring Mordor all over again!

Posted: October 9, 2014
												This game so far has ticked all the boxes.Combat - As many have said, its like batman/AC. After unlocking techniques combat becomes very interesting.You have your average slice and dice finishers, to branding (mind control) in the middle of a fight and even brutalizing orcs to make others run away in fear.Story - I won't say I know all the lore to say it doesn't trample on some things, but I'd say its a decent story. It had some nice surprises too.SUFFER ME NOW - Dominating the minds of orcs will never get boring. Ever. Especially after its one that messed up a previous mission for you or flat out killed you.Death/Captains - If you die to a Captain (or Warchief) they will mock you the next time they come across you. So not dying has become a matter of "not being insulted". I also noticed a Captain make fun of me for having low HP in a fight, so that was cool too I guess.I could say so much more, but then I'd end up rambling. All in all, you won't be dissapointed in this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												Critics have been raving about Shadow of Mordor, claiming it's the best Lord of the Rings game to date, which isn't saying much. However, Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor no doubt lives up to its franchise's name unlike certain past titles thatcrappymobacoughcough. The story is bland and lackluster, complete with the loss of a family and a revenge quest. All we need now is Talion, the one dimensional lead character, to wipe his troubles away with alcohol, and it'll be complete as a truly generic story. However, the gameplay is immensely satisfying. It's fluid, and surprisingly difficult at times; a stronghold alarm going off is quite possibly the most simultaneously thrilling and terrifying moments in gaming for me as of late. Being swarmed by orcs as you see familiar, scarred faces peer out at you with massive health bars and a roar to match, grants a feeling of both fear and excitement for the fight. Dynamically approaching combat through brutal executions, stealth kills, arrow headshots, drop down attacks, (or just plain out fighting,) is a gift that keeps on giving. The nemesis system is fun, and many of my worst enemies give me a continuous drive to hop back on and hunt them down. However, sometimes the orcs coming back can feel cheap, especially when you literally just killed them five minutes ago and now they're back with friends. Suddenly being hunted down by a past opponent can be enthralling and entertaining, but not if it's right after you killed them. Combat is accessible, frequently challenging, and fun to approach. The nemesis system is what I have spent most of my time in the game using, and I find it to be an excellent feature with multiple repetitive features, (flash back to the orcs coming back RIGHT after I killed them.) All in all, Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor is a highly entertaining game that draws inspiration from Assassin's Creed and the Batman Arkham series, all without directly becoming a clone of either one. Its flaws are numerous, but once Skoth the Friendly is chasing you down throughout Mordor, you'll be having too much fun to care.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												Have you ever wondered what it would be like if Aragon and Legolas merged into one kickass character and single handedly took on Sourons army of Orks? Well now you can with this title!!! If you have wanted to play a game where you can slay hordes of Orks for hours on end with style and finesse until your hands cripple from use of your controller, then I highly reccomend purchasing this game.Playing as a new character to the LOTR series Talion and his ghost elf counter part Celebrimbor, your job is to stop the Ork army in its tracks by infiltrating the sometimes hilariously weak and sometimes frustratingly hard Ork captains and taking control of their very souls. Meeting several characters along the way, most with short and unentertaining editions to the story line, evolve your characters skills to take on Sauron's evil henchmen.The game offers a simple fighting system which sees you easily killing enemies through out the game with incredible speed, skill and agility. With many smaller missions to upgrade your legendary weapons and skills along the way the only real struggles you will have come from the captains and warlords. This tends to happen in two ways. You either ignore the instructions on their immunities to different attacking styles and end up a cold corpse with no idea on how to destroy them or you accidentally end up stumbling on several Ork boss's in the area with no idea as to who they are or again how to wound them.The story line is progressive and offers a time filling engagement, though I would reccomend not focusing on the story line too much as the real fun comes from the feeling of invincibility of destroying Ork underlings.Pros:- Smooth fighting system feels incredible and slightly invincible- Game looks great and offers some candy for the eyes in the LOTR world- Offers a progressive back story in Ork heirachy and allows you to use this to your advantage- Has a good amount of unlockable skills to make you feel that much more invincibleCons:- Storyline is not as thorough and intense as could have been- Ork boss weakness system could have had a bit more depth- Main missions were reletively simpleOverall I enjoyed the game throughout. I have to admit I found myself slaying hundreds of bad guys in a row then struggling against a boss who wasn't wounded by sword or bow, so having to run away like a coward... or a smart tactician. The idea behind the Ork heirarchy can give you hours of gameplay and keeps the game entertaining until the end.If you want something to occupy your time and like the idea of mass genocide of a green race then this is defiantly the game for you.

content:
Posted: February 28, 2016
												This game has great production values, and along with the Batman Arkham series, helps to dispel the notion that licensed games linked to either movies or other media, have to suck. Everyone's already said what's great about this game, I re-iterate what they say so just read their's.One thing that I hope the sequel would help remedy, is balance the Nemesis system if the person playing doesn't die often enough. I'm not saying I am great at the game, but with the game gives you the abilities and tools to know what's coming, so if you prepare always, you are unlikely to actually die at the hands of a Uruk you're actively hunting, unless you are incredibly unlucky.The end result is I had no actual Nemesis by the end of the game. All the strongest Uruks I dominated or killed. I thought that my Nemesis was this funny Uruk who happened to have the "Fear of the Gravewalker" trait that made him just run away all the time so he kept surviving. If the game gave me him as my ultimate Nemesis in one of the battles of the final mission, it would have been hilarious and great.But instead it gave me this Uruk from over half the game ago, who I don't think I even died to. I think they picked the highest power Uruk whoever survived against me, and he was still about 12 Power or something.There is some scaling in the game, I did face a lot of Uruks with more strengths than weaknesses. But I was never in real danger, I only died about 4 times in the whole game, I even played with no prompts. I wanted the cool Nemesis personal narrative that I see YouTubers get, like TearOfGrace's Prak Jaw, or AngryJoe's Olgoth, and I never got that.I really don't mind in the sequel, there would be more actual difficulty options, or maybe more proper ambushes the like that would help better players get that Nemesis experience.

												I've only scratched the oozing, bubbling surface of this open world game and I forsee many hours being spent skulking through the ashlands of Mordor.  The combat is intuitive and fun, if not a little easy at times, and the climbing and running about the world are accomplished easily.  Your enemies have a lot of personality and someone took great care in developing each one into its own persona. The rune and stats upgrade screens are a little too small and unwieldy, as are a lot of the menu screens, which may be a result of the console port.It's almost like a nice meaty sandwich with high quality meats and cheese - stuffed between two pieces of generic bread.  The story cutscenes are beautiful, but you don't really have the connection with the characters and the plot just doesn't seem to stick.Outside of this, I see a future where much black Orc blood will be shed!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												I'm going to start off by saying I am a huge fan of the LOTR, so my review may be slightly biased. Well here it goesStory (slight spoiler if you've never watched anything about the game): You start off by reliving Talion's last day before his death/rebirth, and already you become somewhat connected to Talion. You are overrun by Uruk's only to have your family executed right in front of your eyes. You ultimately share that fate with them, but obviously you come back. But you don't just come back as a human. You now share your body with a wraith, who you find out is Celebrimbor, an Elven smith master who forged the rings of power. Even though I haven't played much of the story, it seems to be a pretty solid alternate reality to the actual storyline from the LOTR books. At first I was disappointed that I wasn't going to see Legolas, Aragorn, Gimli, or even Gandalf, but after spending a little time playing as Talion, I've come to admire him in his own way. However I can't help but feel like Talion and Celebrimber have sort of a Frodo/Sam relationship, especially when performing the missions involving Gollum.Gameplay: I really loved the fighting mechanics in the Arkham games, and this game definitely has that feel to it. Parrying is actually slightly easier than in Batman simply because you can block a move no matter what you're doing. You can be in the middle of a combo, finisher, bow shot, life drain, etc..and as long as you press the parry button while it's flashing, then you're good. However once you have about 30 enemies surrounding you, with archers and spear throwers firing from a distance, it gets fairly difficult. Granted you'll see the indicator showing when an arrow or spear is being shot at you, but at this point you're surrounded by so many enemies that it's hard to pay attention to everything at once.  Running, jumping and climbing feels more like an Assassin's Creed game, which I like. I wish though that they had put a little more effort into sneaking.  Graphics: While the graphics aren't the best out there, they are fairly exceptional and are the best I've seen in any LOTR games. Yeah I know there hasn't been much of any in the past few years, but still. My 780 handles everything on ulra, with the exception of the textures (set on high), and I get anywhere from 70-90 fps. Granted it dips to 30-40 fps once you have about 20 people surrounding you in the rain, but that's to be expected. While there are some texture smudges here and there, the bulk of the game is just a joy to look at. I especially love when it rains, as you can see water running down the walls, on the ground, and you'll be soaked as well.Voice Acting: Voice acting is superb! When someone is supposed to yell out of anger, that's exactly what they do. Yeah I know that should a thing every game does, but Commander Shepard in Mass Effect is a perfect example of a character with zero emotion. It's as if the guy the read the lines of the script without even knowing what's happening in the scene. You actually feel the emotion with Talion. It's not just him though, it's every character with the exception of a few Uruks. But they aren't supposed to potray much emotion anyway. I especially love the interactions between Talion and Ratbag. It's quite hilarious seeing Talion's patience with Ratbag grow thinner as Ratbag keeps ♥♥♥♥ing up Talion's plans; on accident mind you. All in all, if you're a fan of the LOTR, then you will not be disappointed with Shadow of Mordor. You'll find that the game doesn't have to follow the books for it to be a great experience. You end up getting to admire Talion as his own self, instead of trying to compare him to Aragorn; even though they do share some similarities.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												Assassin's Creed: Mordor.Shadow of Mordor is basically just Assassin's Creed with Orcs and a lot more blood. The combat system in Shadow of Mordor is basic. It's an Arkham City/Assassin's Creed type of system where you can basically just mash the counter button to protect yourself. In the early stages, combat is relatively difficult, and you might actually die. Later on, though, it just becomes an absolute breeze. You get all the right upgrades and all the right runes (essentially enchantments for your weapons) and you can be killing every single enemy in two to three hits. It's VERY easy.That being said, there's an option to turn off combat prompts which makes the game infinitely harder. This way, you won't have giant flashing lights and signs above every enemy's head telling you when to counter or dodge them. I highly recommend playing with combat prompts disabled to actually have a degree of challenge.As for the story? It's uninteresting and pretty barebones. It's another typical revenge plot, i.e. "This guy killed someone close to you. Go and kill him." About 80% of the main story missions were just tutorials to introduce new features and that's it. The boss fights are pretty poorly done, too. The first boss you fight is basically just a reskinned Orc with some extra health. The second one you fight is just a blind guy that you've gotta sneak up on three times. The last boss is just an absolute spit in the face to the player. It's literally just a quicktime event. I recall pressing five buttons when they appeared on the screen to beat this guy. That was it.The playtime itself is short. Story missions don't last too long and you could probably blitz through the game in about 8 hours on the story alone.So why am I still recommending this game if it's a handholding AC spinoff? Because of the Nemesis system, a pretty innovative feature which makes this game worth playing. The basics of the nemesis system is that Sauron has him own army, and in his army, there are actual ranks, and a chain of command. The Nemesis system lets you target individual Orc captains and warchiefs and go out of your way to assassinate them and screw with the chain of command. The system is laid out in a board game style, with lots of captains and five warchiefs taking up their positions on the board.You can target each captain and each warchief individually, search for intel on their location and their weaknesses and strengths, and then go out and kill them. Each captain has a dynamic set of weaknesses and strengths to catch you out. For example, "Bagabug Man-Stalker" might have a weakness to attacks from mounted beasts, or he might be scared of burning. So when I creep up on Bagabug, I can know these weaknesses in advance and use them against him. I could bring a mounted beast to the fight and savage Bagabug within seconds, or I could try to cause an explosion nearby in order to set him on fire and cause him to run away in fear.OR, if I don't try to abuse his weaknesses, I try to assassinate Bagabug from above, but it turns out he's completely invulnerable to stealth attacks and I did absolutely no damage. Now I'm locked into a battle with him, and the captains are  quite strong early on. Failing to abuse his weaknesses means I could die pretty quickly. To add to this system, each action you participate in has an effect on the army. If you die to a normal, scrub orc, he'll be promoted to a captain and start making his way up the chain of command as well. These orcs even fight eachother, and get into skirmishes between them. You can intervene in these skirmishes in order to prevent captains from growing stronger, or maybe a weaker captain is attacking a stronger one that you've wanted to kill for quite some time. You can intervene and hinder the stronger one, maybe by killing some of his subordinates so that he's outnumbered, or you could try to pin his leg to the ground with an arrow to leave him open to attack.And the system only gets better and better from there, but to elaborate would probably spoil it a little more. Point in hand, the nemesis system makes the game truly satisfying, and that's why I've wracked up so many hours already.Oh, yeah. The game also looks ♥♥♥♥ing beautiful and runs at 60fps, 1080p on my GTX 970. It even allows a borderless window and is generally just a pleasure when you're trying to multitask.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												(tl;dr at the bottom)It's an ok game... While I recommend this game, I'm not totally convinced it should get the praise it gets. Some elements of gameplay are very good and innovative (like the nemesis-system for instance) but I think there could've been more to it. I nearly 100%'ed this game in about 25 hours (with a few rescue missions undone). The biggest complaint I have with this game is that it's really repetitive at times. Especially the side-quests... Basically, if you don't care for the bonus objective of that mission, you just kill orcs... But sometimes you're forced to do it with your bow... Or you have to be in stealth all the time. At a later level you get a power called Brand. With it you can sort of control orcs. 'Control' meaning "go apesh*t on the nearest orc and create a distraction". Which can result in it attacking a whole different orc that you didn't intend to attack. While primitive it can sometime get me laughing when a branded orc captain who stood on the other side of the stronghold also starts to attack everyone in the vincinity and dies because it was a 1 vs 15... And I also made a booboo with the Dispatch-skill that way... Wasn't really funny then, though. Branding actually adds a whole new layer of gameplay and it's nice... but it's near end-game...There are 24 outcast rescue missions and next to that you have 10 missions each for your sword, bow and dagger. And everytime and I mean every single time you have to kill X Uruks. With a bonus objective being: "kill X Uruks in a way that you actually should do and you would have done if given the time to analyse the situation and thinking with your brain". Which doesn't really add difficulty to the already easy game. On the whole game I died around 10 times. And I died once on a story mission.Also: what's the point of these weapon quests if all you get from them is a shiny reskin of your weapon and an achievement... 2 even per weapon. I mean ok there are runes but couldn't they add a bit more damage or a skill that can only be unlocked by doing all the quests?Btw I hate games who forces you to play optional stuff without any reward but the achievement for it. It's good if it's a challenge. But don't put grindy repetitive quests in your game when it amounts to nothing but a reskin...Another complaint is that the game doesn't have multiple difficulties... Which means this game has zero replayability for me. Except the fact that you could encounter other goofy-named orcs (since they are randomly generated, except those who have a main quest tied to them).And my final complaint is: ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ending. With a poor excuse of a final boss (as you may have heard...). And feels like the whole game is a bit unfinished when everything adds up.ASIDE FROM THAT the game is really good!Main quests are good with great introductions to new powers. Graphics are phenomenal but I didn't really see a big improvement in the Ultra texture patch. Maybe because I'm still a 1080p peasant...Music is... ok? I don't recall much music... It was either your generic dramatic classical music or it was the tribal-like drums. Story is ok. While I'm not into LotR lore much (I've seen the films) I think I would've enjoyed it more if I knew more of the lore. Especially with the artifacts and such. Models are top notch with tesselation. Me likey. Animations are really good. Voice acting is very London. And what a surprise the dwarf is Scottish... (just kidding voice acting is great).Gameplay-wise, the game really shines with the nemesis-system. That your killer or the one who fled from you, remembers you and the fact that all that is voice acted, is awesome to say the least. It's fun to try and brand every orc to unify your army under one banner! It's also satisfying to lead a captain to become warchief with various events... and then kill him for giggles. The ability to order two captains to fight eachother is also awesome. The swordplay in this game is also very good. I like the batman's creed-style without being too much of 'zooming-20-meters-to-land-the-next-hit-and-back'-punch.TL;DRPro's:-Graphics and animation are top notch-Voice Acting is great-Batman-style combat (well it's a WB game after all...)-Combat skills are awesome-Nemesis-system is above awesomeCons:-Rather on the short side-Uruks must die!... like alot. Apart from collectibles it's all you do in this game.-Final boss (and final scene) is laughable.-Grindy side-quests that amount to... achievements... yay... errybody likes achievs... ugh...-Only 1 difficulty setting.-It says "rushed release" all over it.Verdict:7/10. It's a great game but falls a bit short on content. Combat is good with good abilities. Side-quests are repetitive, a tad grindy and amount to nothing but empty bragging rights. However what the game lacks in quantity it gets in quality. Graphics are superb and voice acting and animations are AAA. Ending sucks.I would recommend waiting for a discount before getting this game as it lacks content and has close to no replayability.P.S. It's my first "serious" review. So tell me wot ya think.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												I'm by no means a hardcore gamer.  I like to win and I like to gallavant around my digital world beating everything within and inch of its life causing great chaos.  I don't even like combat that much and get lazy when it comes to stealth.  Storyline is boring but it's clearly not what this game is selling so it's not really a dealbreaker for me.  It also has a playable female character (though in cutscenes you'll be shown as the default ManPain McAngst) which is always a plus. -Stealth kills easy to make and immensely satifying (but some enemies are immune, so watch out!)-Combat system very intuitive and the tooltips that can be enabled will walk you through it in-combat for the whole game if you want to in an actually helpful way -No real loot, but it helps me stay focused on my main objective- murder-Being able to brand animals like graugs and caragors means my potential chaos level is multiplied exponentially as I turn hordes of them loose in enemy strongholds and let them do the work for me. It can be a very challenging game if desired, but its' easy level settings are very well suited to a more casual style that just wants to watch Mordor burn.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 25, 2015
												While it uses the Batman combat system, the Nemesis really sets it apart.  With each "baddie" having a good selection of abilities and weaknesses as well as models and attacks, it makes the game feel more dynamic.  The fact you can influence the enemies chain of command is a lot of fun.  This game will push any current hardware to it's limits, as there are few video cards that have enough VRAM to actually use the highest quality textures.  Meaning while it looks great now, it should remain looking good for years to come (i.e., it should age well).  It's writing is alright, not great.  It banks on the notion you know the Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit stories.  Because without having that knowledge the writing would be considered fairly poor.  It's biggest weakness is it's use of QTE (Quick Time Event).   Towards the end of the game, combat with large bosses and indeed the final boss is reduced to just a QTE.Despite it's rather un-epic ending, when you beat the game, you are allowed to keep playing.  So if you want to do any of the optional quests at this time you can, or continue to mess with the enemies army, whatever.Overall, a solid game.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I must confess, I made it less than 15 minutes into assasin's creed 1 before I uninstalled and never looked back at the franchise. I have the first 2 Batman games, and enjoyed what I played of them, but lost interest fairly quickly. So after 5 hours of this, I might lose interest soon, but it's no fault of the game, I'm just very fickle with the genre. That said, I think I'm more likely to keep this one around than give those games another shot. The nemesis system really hits the spot for me. It really is the game's only trick, though, so if it isn't enough to grab you, you're going to get bored quick. Every single aspect of this game involves slaughtering orcs. Later on you can "brand" some of them to be your obedient slaves, but all they do for you is kill more orcs. There's a few other beasts, but usually you just avoid them or set them free so they can keep killing orcs. The story isn't very groundbreaking, but they did a decent job of manipulating the lore into an excuse partake in never ending gratuitous orc genocide. There's even a Gollum cameo. It's good dumb fun and at least worth it's sale price.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												<In-Depth Review>Now I haven't played any other titles that bears any reference to the popular fantasy series (aside from Lego Lord of the Rings) but I am certain that Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor will be one of the, if not THE, defining gem of LOTR-based gaming.Set within the Black Gate of Mordor, you are Talion: a ranger who was killed by an entity known as the Black Hand of Sauron. However, "you are banished from death" and paired up with an Elf-wraith who seems to have no memory of who he was in life. He senses a rising power that threatens the lands and together, Talion and the Elf must do what they can to get answers.It has been said in other user reviews and it will be repeated again (briefly): The essential gameplay style is akin to the Batman Arkham series. Combat consists of well-timed attacks and counters with a hit meter counting each blow and allowing players to invoke special take-downs and such. Stealth takedowns are highly encouraged and seem to never waver in terms of satisfaction. I've gotten plenty of joy stalking a small camp of uruks with nothing but my dagger. Instead of "Detective Mode," there is "Wraith Mode" where you can enter a state that identifies enemies and other items of interest.The best feature of the title is, of course, the Nemsis system. A continually updating roster of Uruk captains, generals, and warchiefs is available at all times and lets you see what the competition is. There are missions that will require you to take them down but you are also free to find them in your own time. However, you should NEVER charge into a stronghold with your sword blazing. You need to learn more about your prey; learn what they fear and what they can do before going in. Intel for all the Nemesis can be gathered from three sources: intel lying around in camps, Worms (certain uruks identified by green in wraith-mode), and any weakened elite (that is key; do not kill worms and elites before gathering intel). Sure, you can learn your opponent through trial and error or even luck but gathering intel is a non-daunting experience that doesn't present a great challenge.Experience points are gained from kills, freeing slaves, completing missions, etc. Nemesis kills equate to Power; the tougher the enemy, the more power is gained. Getting Power unlocks new tiers of skills that are applied to combat and to the three weapons: sword, bow, and dagger. Killing Nemsis will also award players with a rune for one of the three which can be customized to fit the preferred play-style of the player Graphics-wise, this game is goregous. An oxymoron: they are the cleanest, dirt-filled hellholes I've ever seen. Tailon's cape billows beautifully and you can definitely tell on nearly every surface when it's raining. Voice-acting too is top notch though I'd be lying if I said I could identify the actors besides Andy Serkis's always-beloved performance as Gollum.A deep appreciation for the Lord of the Rings is well apppreciated, but unnecessary. An in-game guide will provide details on everything found in the game. My only grievance is that the exploration of the land is not as enjoyable as the Arkham series. Understandably, Tailon does not have a cape and grappling hook. But sneaking and running does wear thin after a while. There are a considerable amount of checkpoints that can be discovered and fast travel to any of them is possible at all times but I repeat: sneaking and running does wear thin after a while.All in all, Middle Earth: Shadow of Mordor is an experience of anyone who has any amount of love and respect for the classic fantasy saga. A familiar game-play driven by a rewarding enemy system set in a (slow) exploring open-world is what awaits any undead ranger brave enough to set foot in it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												This is a ok game it's not great but it has all the elements of a great game. First off the nemesis system is a lot of fun it's one of the reason to play this game. It has good graphics I couldn't play it on ultra with my gtx 660 ti but I could play it on medium high, and it looks good. The controls with the keyboard and mouse leave something to be desired but it's playable which is more than I can say for some of the games that have came out this year. The main problem I had with the controls is that sometimes not always but sometimes it would not go in the right direction, which got me killed. The combat is fun the animation quality is good and most of the time it flows well, their was a few times in the game where an animations looked forced. The story is good but there is almost none of it, they voice acting is great but again they went with quality of quantity which is ok, not enough games do that. Now lets talk about the reason you buy this game, the nemesis system. It is good until the end of the game, towards the end around the last five hours it becomes trivial, as does the combat and any other elements of the game that add difficulty. The reason for this is branding, once you can brand orcs all you have to do is spam it in combat and you soon have an army fighting for you, which is awesome but it makes the game way too easy. The reason for this is simple and probably could be changed easily, when you use any finisher you become immune to damage, which means if you are any good at the game you can spam brand and never die. Now lets talk about the replayability of this system because it seems like it would be great, but it's not. The max power level of a captain/warchief is twenty witch is trivial after you finish the game. Without even using the most powerful upgrades you can take on five or more power level fifteen plus with ease. Again this is caused by the problems stated above. So in conclusion if you want a 20 hour game that has a lot of quality but not much content this game is for you if you would rather spend three hundred hours in a game settle for the lackluster combat ok skyrim instead.(Side note, if there was a elderscrolls game with this combat system but more fleshed out it would be a lot of fun.)
