number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												Let me start off with saying this: This game, for me, was the most frustrating game other than Dark Souls that I have ever had the rage-inducing experience of playing. That said, this game is incredibly fun. Shadow of Mordor takes what Assassin's Creed and Batman Arkham do great, and smash them together in the greatest open-world (and, actually, open-story) I have ever seen. Stealth, while not 100% necessary, gives you the ability to plan out and control situations. On the other hand, when you are in open combat, it feels fluent and powerful, without being unbelievably easy as in AC.  The difficulty is not set by the player, and rather determined solely on your approach to the game. This can be extremely frustrating, especially for less-than-skilled players such as myself. However, what this method accomplishes is making the player simply learn to be better, and giving an absolutely incredible feeling of accomplishment. The nemesis system enhances this element of the game. When I am defeated by an enemy, he becomes stronger, meaning that the next time I try to fight him, it's even more difficult. So if I am ever to strike down this foe, I have to think very carefully in my next confrontation.  Speaking of the Nemesis system, that is what makes this game shine among all the others. Your enemies all seem to have a strong memory in which they can recall details of previous encounters. While not every grunt is pre-programmed with his own personality, if he finds himself promoted to being of any importance, a personality will be generated for him. This results in every major character feeling very alive, and very personal. You are the creator of your own villains. Captains and War Chiefs fall into their ranks based on the players actions, and can be promoted for doing things such as killing the player. Killing Talion is only temporary however, leaving you the opportunity to have a very satisfactory revenge-kill in which the Orc that slayed you flees in terror of the very thing that he killed not that long ago.   Furthering that same concept, When you are victorious, this also remains in the enemies memory. If someone gets away, they will remember their fight with you before. And if you think you kill an enemy, but don't ensure it via methods such as decapitation, you just might find yourself face to face with a scarred up and very♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥captain. They will remember the general details of what you did to them. I found myself against a captain named Larn. After striking him down with my sword, he later returned as "Larn the Scarred" and told me that his men now called him "The Scarred" because of me, and charged me. In that fight, I accidentally threw him into some fire. After watching his body become an extra large torch, I presumed he was finally done with. I was wrong. Later he comes back with his entire face wrapped in cloth except his eye, and I have to admit, it was a terrifying sight. Here was an enemy that hunted me to his very end....           Well, I hope it was his end....  For those who care about scoring, I will give a number. 10/10. You may say that "This game is a long way from perfect" but to me a 10/10 doesn't mean perfect, else there would be no games that achieve this. This game is a 10/10 because it is an entrancing, fun to play, rewarding, and ongoing experience. It is along the same lines as Skyrim in it's ability to keep me powerfully connected and attached to this fantastic world it has created, and does one up from Skyrim and makes this world personal to me. No one will ever experience this same struggle that I did, no one will ever meet The Surgeon except me, and if they happen to meet someone with his same title, and even name, it will be by coincidence and it won't be the same character. This amazing level of depth and unique experience is what compells me to place a 10/10 score on this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Assassins Creed + Arkham CIty + Far Cry = Shadow Of Mordor. BOTTOM HAS SLIGHT SPOILERS SO BE AWAREProsThe wonderful stealth and agility and movement system of Assassins Creed with the perfect combat system of the Arkham games plus the outpost captures and healing plants and strategy of Far Cry. All wrapped in the gorgeous and unforgiving dangerous setting of Mordor. This game is truely gold and everyone who has ever played any of the three series of games i mentioned will have a blast with Shadow Of Mordor. I enjoyed the nemesis system which brought purpose and replayability to the game. The extremely violent combat gave me a rush, especially when taking over outposts and capturing warchiefs.ConsThe shortcomings are limited but still need to be noted. at times it was hard to control Talion. A few times he wouldn't climb up unless i went down and back up again. The camera, though 90% on point, would sometimes make things hard to see in tight areas. But the main thing that annoyed me was the nemesis system getting in the way of itself and gameplay. Almost everytime i went to capture a warchief, there would be other captains that would see me and then the nemesis system would direct my screen away from Talion and to the captain for his quick speech saying he has seen me before. Though the system is great and above all other games' AI, it sometimes got in the way especially during intense battles where every move counts and the flow of the combat means everything, just to be thrown off by the nemesis system kicking in. It didnt ruin the game at all, but was annoying.VerdictThe few problems i had didnt turn me off to the game. it remains to be one of my favorite, definitely my top pick for games released in 2014. i only found one small glitch that made a few of the walls bright neon colors but that was literally the only glitch and it was during free roam so it didnt hurt gameplay. Overall i give the game a 9/10 simply for being able to blend 3 game mechanics from 3 different games into one beautiful looking game with plenty of satisfying gameplay. its not a 10 just for the nemesis system getting in the way of itself. Also not a 10 for the reason ill explain in the spoiler section.SPOILERS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!SPOILERS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!i felt the ending of the game was so build out through my 30 hour gameplay. the story of him avenging his family's death was so compelling, even if not unique. His friendship with the hunter and queen. all very well done but i feel like Mordor needed....well more Mordor. the world seemed a little bland and the story needed more scenes like when Talion and his minions stormed the gates, that was exciting and had such a Lord Of The Rings feel! one big team against another in an all out fight in an open field. I loved that part but it only lasted a few minutes. Also the end we so built up just to be a quick time event where you hit a few buttons and beat the dark lord!!! common!! Ive been wanting to fight him since i first watched LOTR!!!! i wanted a real awesome boss fight. the only real boss fight was in the cave with the hunter. but the ending did leave with sort of a cliff hanger, hopefully a second game will bring a more exciting setting, boss fights and epic moments of two teams just clashing in all out warfare!!! other than that, everything the game did, it did it right. it was fun and now i still have 63.5% left in the game even after the main story!. plenty of fun packed in, a real joy to play.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												I have thrown 45+ hours into and am still playing it, the game is amazing. Shadow of Modor is insanely addicting and while some people say it is easy I (being an average gamer) find it to be a moderate level, for me it is perfect, not too hard but still challenging, I tend run when I alert a stronghold as I have a hard time fighting 50+ orcs with some captains mixed in. And it is not just orcs you have to worry about, the beasts of Mordor are also threating and dangerous. This brings me to the nemesis system it is very well done, I enjoyed grooming an orc up to a higher level by letting him kill me over and over, and while it was weird to kill the same guy more than 5 times (as apparently you need to chop or blow a captains head off for them to be gone for good) it is still enjoyable. There is also a feature in the game where you can avenge you friends (Steam friends) who die in combat, when you die a message gets sent out to those on your friends list who are playing, this message is a mission for revenge. Completing a “Vendetta” mission grants more rewards and the ability to gloat over your friend at his or hers failure.Now some people have also said that the combat is repetitive and dull, but I find it far from dull and repetitive, upgrading Talion with new and better abilities as well as changing out runes keeps combat interesting and always new. I have found the main story to be very enticing and interesting. The characters I have encountered have kept me wanting to play more. The game, like the movies, has humor in it too, just enough though, it is not childlike and I have found myself laughing out loud on several occasions. Overall my experience with the game thus far has been fun and eventful.

												First off the downsides: No character creation, no town hubs, no droppable item loot other then runes.  Game is lacking much of what one expects from a open world RPG. The Nemesis system does for boss fights and boss encounters what the Radiant Quest system did for Skyrim quests making the combat and boss fights are the best I've experienced, games utterly addictive for me personally. If you liked Batman /AC games but found the stealth or puzzle sections broke up the combat, this game solves those issues.Best game I've played this year.

content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												I'm sure you've heard people compare this game to the Arkham games, Assassin's Creed and all of that. There is no doubt it's "inspired" gameplay-wise by other games, but after playing this game I fail to see how that's a bad thing.The story is a pretty straight forward revenge-trumps-all revenge plot from beginning to end, where the main character experiences a big loss at the hands of some bad guys. It does have the aspect where an ancient elf ghost of sorts offers to help him on his way by giving him supernatural powers and in return the main character helps the elf find out more about his past, however. I was still not that engaged with the story, and the ending was... pretty underwhelming to say the least in my eyes.The gameplay is... well, it's an Arkham game with swords so lethal and brutal that Batman would certainly not approve. The free-flowing combat system where you slide between enemies to build your combo so you can unleash special attacks works as well as it did in Batman from my view, and the animation quality is pretty superb during all of it. It has the Arkham archetype when it comes to enemies as well, with everything from puny grunts to ranged specialists and big brutes you either have to hit in the back or stun before you can attack them. It's functional, satisfying and FUN! The stealth system is pretty basic with stealth takedowns and "attention icons" over the enemies' heads to let you know how suspicious they are, and you can indeed run away and come back when they calm down.The Nemesis system was hyped up pretty massively, and I feel like it works pretty well as a first dip into it. Including the normal enemies, you can also run into (or hunt) captains and warchiefs (even though even these guys are one of the "normal" enemy classes, for reasons that will be obvious soon) These guys are stronger and they have strengths and weaknesses. You'll meet the captain that counters all your finishing moves and can't be hurt by ranged attacks that can be instantly stealth killed if you sneak up on him. You'll meet the captain that takes damage from most attacks but can't be insta-killed, but is terrified by certain animals and becomes a clumsy little baby when he sees one... the list goes on, and there's a lot of combinations here! The warchiefs also often have captains as their bodyguards, so going for them often turns into a huge brawl.The mention of obvious reasons why these mini-boss enemies follow the normal classes is because a random grunt that gets the killing blow on you can over time rise through the ranks and become the next warchief. This game makes death both interesting and a tool at your disposal if you want to play around with the enemy officers, who constantly fight eachother and try to increase their influence. You gain the ability to "brand" them eventually, which lets you control them and decide their decisions. Is that warchief really giving you trouble? Seek out his 5 bodyguards and brand them, then turn them against him when you confront him again! It's all pretty fun even if it is somewhat limited, especially if you're like me and you enjoy manipulating game worlds and enemies. You should also try letting a random Uruk kill you and then indirectly protect him all the way to warchief rank simply by helping him in his trials, but not branding him... pretty sure that's an achievement, actually. And oh, they will remember if they killed you or you did something mean like burn them, and they will make sure to say it to you when you fight them again as well.I will admit that to many the game will probably turn a bit repetitive. The combat is fun, but once you get all your upgrades it does turn a bit easy. Get a 5 hit streak, decapitate two enemies, then repeat. If you want a bigger challenge you might want to consider limiting your upgrades, or maybe limiting how many health upgrades you get. The nemesis system does help quite a bit as you can jump in even after the story is done and make some riots happen, and a big messy brawl is never far away. That is most of the game though, it's a sandbox that in the end comes down to violently murdering Uruks no matter how you look at it. Or making them kill eachother on your behalf, but still counts!I had plenty of fun with it and I'm sure I'll enjoy toying with the Nemesis system for a while still, but just be aware that if you want a big amount of variety in the in-game activities it might lack here. But if you love the free-flow combat system of the Arkham games the potential repetitiveness is probably a good thing, as there's a lot of brawls to be had.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 22
												All of this is based on my opinion.GRAPHICS: 9.5/10 : This game is beautiful and the draw distance even on my computer setup is pretty impressive, there are a few in game *using game engine* cutscenes for the main story and a few pre rendered cutscenes. I rarely came across clipping or clipping issues, particles looks great. Not perfect but damn good.SOUND: 10/10 : The soundtrack , the sound effects, the echoing, the voice acting, and many other effects are used with great care in this game and give it a pretty awesome feel and pace to the game. Very much what you would expect from a LOTR games.GAMEPLAY: 9/10 :Fantastic climbing, responsive controls, just enough enemy variety to keep it interesting, with the opportunity to really just go into a group of Orcs and just start destroying them one by one. You get melee sword action, stealth gameplay, and ranged combat. This all makes for a fantastic experience that only near the end got a little stale for me. I am not the biggest fan of quick time events but this game used them in a decent way. Pros: Graphic, bloody, gruesome, fast gameplay, propped up with a great story that helped me understand the lore of the one ring how it was made, what happened to the ring maker, seeing another story unfold in a great way. This game will give you hours and hours of fun either creating a army or orcs or destroying every last one of them. Or you could just do both and still have amazing fun.Cons: at the end of the game the gameplay got a little stale as many of the things you have to do at the end are things you have had to be doing for the last 15 hours or so of gameplay. This for me meant that at the end of the main story I was really looking forward to playing another game. The middle ground: I bought this for 10$ and to me it was worth easily 2-3 times that amount in gameplay ,story, and fun factor and that is not something that happens too often. If you can get this game for less then 30$ or cheaper i suggest you do so as you will not be dissapointed. I find it really hard to find any real flaws this game has, considering i got almost 40 hours of playtime out of it and had lots of fun 95% of the time, and i still have some things to 100% still as at the end of the game i only had 80% of the game complete and that was without the DLC i have yet to play. Final say: If its cheap and you have been thinking about it just get this game, it will be a good investment in my eyes.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												I am only 5 hours into this game, but I love it.  The graphics are beautiful, the combat is smooth with a good learning curve, and I love the upgrade system.  The story is very fulfilling so far, with (spoiler alert) everyone's favorite Gollum in a very story central role.  I like how when you die the Uruk who killed you gets promoted (and stronger) but if you encounter him again he will actually remember killing you and will fight accordingly.  The AI is wonderful, with emphasis on reacting to your style of play and attacks.  I can't wait to finish this game! I will update after completion but at this time I cannot imagine anything other than  100% positive review.  Oh and did I mention the Graphics being Beautiful?Side note: The first time I played I set everything on Ultra (FX8350 + R9-280) and I noticed a little hiccup (frame stutter)  sometimes.  But after that I ran AMD Raptr and let it auto-optimize my settings. Still playing with almost all the settings maxed, but since then it has played smooth as butter with not even one single frame stutter.    Would Absolutely recommend 10/10

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Not really one for writing a review, but lets see.Shadow of Mordor is one of the few games in the last while that I've thoroughly completed, I have 100% on the main game (though not yet all the achievements) but haven't yet touched the DLC.The game for the most part is fun, though if you start getting sidetracked completing the side missions and collecting the pickups and completing the legends of the weapons, you become too powerful and the game largely loses any challenge. Indeed I would argue that I found the last 3 levels too easy. (Yet can easily start getting my♥♥♥♥♥kicked when swarmed by Cragors)The music is superb, it really does a great job of setting the mood and mostly doesn't end up feeling reptitive. The voice acting was also really well done, I was particularly taken with Torvin.Graphically its fantastic, even on my paltry 1680x1050, the diveristy in the Uruks really makes the world feel alive.That said, the AI is very blind! You could be standing around 30-40 feet away from Uruks in an open field and they won't see you. Its kind of awful, after a while unless a mission calls for it there really isn't much need for stealth.I enjoyed myself, but I felt after 20-25h of play that it just felt like it was a grind.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												Can't really say anything that hasn't been said but I'll give it a go...(TL;DR below)Basically the game takes the "Assassins Creed" and Batman "Arkham" series,looks at them and says "Meh...let's throw in some super powers for the hell of it!".The game seperates itself from both of those games however with how the gameplay is tied into the nemesis system.Every encounter feels new and different thanks to the nemisis system, which causes the enemies you fight to respond to you in different ways depending on how you've encountered them before. The system is really well implemented and I honestly hope more games use it, or some version of it, in the future. As it adds an extreme layer of personality to the game as a whole. Enemies feel like actual characters to you rather than cookie-cutter "soldiers" that are all the same regardless of what you do.Example: While fighting you throw a guy into a fire, but you get interrupted before you can kill him and have to bail, the next time you encounter him he laughs at you for your failed attempt to kill him, but has secrectly developed a fear of fire, (which you learn of through careful espionage), and you can exploit this to weaken him this time and secure the kill.Graphics and sound-wise the game is stunning, with some jaw-dropping animations.The voice acting is stellar with the dialog between the main character and the side-characters really highlighting this.HOWEVER:The game feels a bit on the small side. With only 2 main areas you will be re-visiting a lot of places, but the game will usually have you come at an area from different directions each time so it does feel less repetitave.TL;DRGameplay on its own : Good              7/10Gameplay PLUS Nemesis : Amazing  10/10Graphics : Fantastic                            8/10Sound : Great                                      8/10Overall: 8.5/10The game is really excellent, great fun, and different each time you pick it up. A must buy for any Stealth/Action Fan.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												An excellent non-canon adventure.  It's very similar to an Assassin's Creed or Arkham game (specifically, AC movement right down to reproducing the glitch where you can occasionally not grab things if you climb a wall at an angle, and Arkham's swarming enemy battle system.)  However, that definitely doesn't do it justice.  It circumvents most of the design flaws of both titles and adds a lot of brand new (to me) stuff.First and foremost, AC and Arkham games tend to be paced quite poorly.  They give you all these abilities in the first 6 hours or so of gameplay, and make a game that takes a good 50 hours or so to do everything.  Shadow of Mordor holds things back from you until something like the 4th or 5th last core mission of the game, so you don't get bored with the same old abilities.  Speaking of abilities, all those experience-earned abilities are paced superbly - I had exactly 1 big fight left when I got the last of those abilities.  Point is, AC and Arkham games are both big enough to outstay their welcome.  Shadow of Mordor doesn't.  Second, there's the variety of things to do.  Some of them aren't all that useful (why throw daggers for minor damage when I can pull out my bow, line up a headshot and get a one hit kill (and a chance to terrify a couple of orcs into fleeing in the process), but a lot of that is in playstyle.  (The guy who feels the bow/slowmo combo is cheating (and let's face it, it's totally unfair) might quite like those daggers I'm so dismissive of.)  Assassin's Creed tends to give you a laundry list of gimmicky tools when all you really want is your sword(s), pistol(s)/throwing knives, and hidden blade; Arkham Asylum (the only Arkham I've played to completion) gives you gadgetry that increases your mobility.  Shadow of Mordor gives you the ability to brainwash an orc, order it to kill its friend, then make its head explode when its finished.  Or the ability to hop onto a Graug (which is to trolls what gorillas are to humans - recognizably similar but significantly stronger, stupider and better at smashing things) and rampage through an orc camp.Speaking of the brainwashing thing, I think they made a significant error, at least in marketing.  They really played up the signifigance of this ability, but it doesn't appear until about the 3-quarter mark in the main game.  And you're quite limited as to what you can accomplish with your minions - rank and file troops can just be used in the area (which is fine), captains can only murder other captains, become a warchief's bodyguard, or backstab the warchief he's guarding.  Warchiefs, the top ranking orcs in the game, can murder Captains as before, and have the ability to challenge other warchiefs in a "riot" - 1 warchief and several orcs on each side, fight it out and see what happens.  Near the end of the game (SPOILER WARNING - LOOK FOR ALLCAPS), you can lead a group of possessed warchiefs in larger battles, (END SPOILER WARNING), but you can't do anything on this kind of scale ingame.  I'd love to take the Warchiefs and Captains of Nurn (who are, in my game, virtually all under my command) and march them up to Udun (the first area, where the command structure was rebuilt after I killed everything of rank in the first half of the game) and start a war between these two large groups of Orcs.  It would be great fun.  It would also probably murder my computer, but that's no reason not to include it - there are much better computers than mine.  It's still fun, it could just be better if they'd added a few more options.On the technical side, the game is largely brilliant.  The graphics are definitely excellent - Udun is a perfectly appalling place - a blasted ruin - and Nurn is eerily green and pastoral (apparently it's canonically the area of Mordor left fertile in order to provide food for the Orcs).  Only in the heat of the most intense battle in the game did I once experience a minimally noticable drop in frame-rate.  Load times are rare and take merely seconds (and include little snippits of Tallion's history to distract you from the fact you're staring at a loading screen), despite this immense level of detail.  By far the best implementation of background loading (and appropriate use of the extensive amount of RAM available on the computer).   The one unfortunate result of this is that Orcs spawn in at very short ranges.  While I never actually caught them popping into existence (except on the minimap), there were a few missions I was trying to accomplished by stealth (that is, silently murdering everything between point A and point B) where I was seen by Orcs in places I had cleared out seconds earlier.  Fortunately, the game rarely forces you to take a stealth approach, so getting caught just moves from the amazingly brutal (but stupidly easy...by a Metal Gear Solid fan's standards) stealth to the wild melee of a battle through an Orc stonghold on alert.  And when you're not in a structured mission, you can always just run away if things don't work out - strongholds often have so many orcs that fighting them all just becomes impractical.  In short - if you liked Assassin's Creed and/or Arkham Asylum games, but wanted to mind control enemies, ride troll beasts and creatures I can only describe as being the result of genetic experiments involving a rhino and a lion, this game is your chance.  Just don't consider it official Tolkein canon; even the basic premise of you and a dead elven wraith working together to cheat death breaks canon in many ways (death is absolute for men, wraiths are half-living creatures, not undead, etc.)

content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												Definitely the best lotr game I've ever played, and the Nemesis System I guarantee is going to be the new in-thing that every game dev is going to copy! It's hard going back to other games, now. I've been spoiled by Shadow of Mordor's excellent AI and all the little stories within stories. The game is quite fantastic, but there's a few complaints I felt I should voice:-Graphics- I couldn't tell the difference between low and ultra, apart from a performance difference-Glitches in the controls/parkour system would get me stuck inside walls quite often to where I'd have to restart the mission.-Almost impossibly hard in the beginning, by the end you are godlike so after you finish it there's not much motivation to continue collecting things/doing side missions-Controls seemed sluggish and laggy at timesThe pros, though, definitely outweigh the cons. However, if I could buy it again, I would definitely buy it for a next gen console, not the PC. If you're going to buy it for the PC, make sure you get it on sale, because it's relatively short (I'm at 90% done with only 37ish hours on it) and the controls can be wonky at times.Overall though, if you love lotr you'll probably love this game to pieces. It's an excellent addition to the lore. on a scale of 100, I'd give this game a 85.Review Update: It was so good I bought it again, this time on Xbox One and it performs much much better on the Xbox One, so if you have a PC that isn't top notch, consider getting it on PS4/Xbox One

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												This game feels like Arkham City mixed with Assassins Creed, and I love it. The Nemesis system is very refreshing and the captains are badass. The only bug I've encountered was an issue where I was missing certain sounds during a fight. All I could hear was my footsteps, but as soon as I did an execution it fixed itself. I would definitely buy this game if you enjoyed Arkham City or Assassins Creed, and you like Middle Earth. I've spent maybe half my time actually pursuing the story because just stealthing around killing Orcs is so much fun. The fighting gets more complex as you progress with new enemies and abilities, so the combat stays pretty fresh. The strengths and weaknesses of the captains and warchiefs makes you try different strategies and alter your playstyle to kill them. Every time you die the Orc or Uruk who kills you is promoted and they get stronger each time they kill you. This really makes you want to track down your nemeses, it also makes killing them very rewarding. I'd definitely reccomend this game especially if it is on sale. Side note: brutalized stealth kills are ♥♥♥♥ing sick

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												Well. I have played a little over six hours of the game and I feel that I understand the game well enough to make a review.In the six hours I have played, I have barely done any story missions, and that says alot. I am not implying that the story is bad, I just got so involved in the nemesis system which brought me away from the story.So, here we go.Story, 9.5/10. Personally, I'm finding the story very interesting, and I love the inclusion of golem. I find the idea of Talion being banished from death a very cool and fun way to explain what happens to him when he dies, instead of just respawning with no explanation.Combat, 10/10. All of the combat animations are very fluid, and the combat is very responsive, and I get enjoyment out of slicing Uruks' heads off. All of the executions are /VERY/ satisfying.Nemesis System, 10/10. This system is absolutely WONDERFUL. It is very important to look at your targets' strengths and weaknesses, you will know how you can exploit them. Multiple times, I have killed a target, and I stumble upon him once again, though he has metal in his head from when I shot him with an arrow. Another Uruk just refused to die, he kept coming back, though I gave him a large scar across his face. When you encounter enemies that you believed to be dead, some sort of hatred fills you, and it is very satisfying when you get to kill them a second time.Keyboard/Mouse controls, 9.5/10. The controls have worked very well for me, and I have had no real problems. They don't take much getting used to, either. Overall Rating... 10/10! This game is a solid contendor for Game of the Year. It is a wonderful game, with a wonderful story and gameplay. This game is worth purchasing at full price.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												This game is amazing, you can beat the main story in a day, or you can be cool like me and spend 100 hours to complete it. Why, you ask, did i take so long? because unlike most gamers i dont care as much about the story, the game play is amazing, the way enemies remember you time after time is awesome and i was having so much fun going around hunting caragor and graug that i forgot all about doing missions. The captains are pretty cool as well, They all have diferent abilities, fears, weaknesses, and hatreds. So with 1 captain you can shoot him in the head and kill him instantly, but with a diferent captain he will be immune to ranged and stealth attacks so you have to face him head on. The gameplay itself is pretty much the same as Assassins creed, when i described the game to friends i told them "Lord of the rings and Assassins creed had a kid". Even after completing the main missions its still a lot of fun to run around mordor expanding my army and taming Dire caragor. After all of that however, there is still one little problem i had, and its a big one! (if you get that joke you the real MVP)The final boss fight was extremely disapointing and, for me personaly, far too easy but i wont spoil details, play for yourself if you want to see why i feel that way.

content:

												  Here we have a game i can recomend to anyone who likes action games. It does not really matter if one likes the Lord of the Rings or not, this game doesn't require you to have prior knowledge or set you in any super immersive lore. Sure it has lots of stories to it, but it can be just skipped to play the game. The world is set up really well, i don't remember seeing something like the same stone in two places, so the overall layout is pretty unique.  The combat is very dynamic and leaves enough room to make your own fighting style.  The overall playthrough is great, though i'd like the storyline to connect the two areas better and the control over the character could be slightly better. Overall i'd give it a 91% rating.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												What attracts me:- Good varieties of Orc in terms of look, character. There is the brutal macho looking Orcs, the skinny stealthy archer, the greedy nerdy looking ones which adds to the fun of watching various cutscenes along the way- Talent trees upgrade makes you stronger of course but is not everything to the game. Some level of skills are still required (timely click / mouse movement / keyboard)- Weapon upgrade & runes allows mix and match to suit different play style and blends well with talent tree- You get to play warrior / stealth / archer to your liking- Commanding an army of Orcs felt really cool- Very nice graphics & smooth transition into cutscenes during game playCons (of DLC):- Rune farming is too random, and too many useless runes- Need the options of "Retry" on very mission as oppose to having us run a long way back to restart mission- Need difficulty options. Game is on the easy side after you learn the mechanicsConclusion:- All in all, extremely fun game and well worth even the full price. One of the most enjoyable games I've played- Must get if you like Dragon Age, Divine Divinity,  Elder Scroll Skyrim [Middle Earth comes top among them for me]

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												SHADOW OF ARKHAM'S CREED ...I'm sure that I'm not the first person to point out how much this games plays like a mash-uo of the Arkham and Assassin's Creeds games, just set in Middle Earth.  That's not a knock on the game at all, though (at least in my book).  If you liked those series (and most people did), you're going to like this game.  Period.That's not to say there is nothing original.  The nemesis system, for example, is quite fun, especially when defeated foes come back at exactly the worst possible time.  I was running a mission to defeat a pretty tough dude (for my level at the time).  There I am slowly wearing him down, trying to pick off his elite guard, dodging hurled spears ... and two other orc captains show up for revenge.  What was already tough fight suddenly because hilarious and insane.The open world is also quite nice.  Sure, there are tons of side missions ... but never underestimate the sheer joy of just walking around the countryside at random, clearning out camps and strongholds on a whim.  There's something deeply satisfying about picking off archers from a distance, stealth killing your way around a small encampment, or just walking brashly into the middle of twenty-thirty orcs, and emerging victories several minutes later.  On a side note, this makes it a game that can still be very rewarding in 15-30 min segments, if that's all you can manage on a particular evening.If you're still not sold, this game is on sale quite a bit.  I got the whole GOTY shabang for $10.  That makes it one of my biggest steals in years.Finally, if you don't buy it, all the hobbits will die.

												A short story.I met one Orc, He was a spear throwing maniac of the darkest regions of Mordor itself. He got a lucky throw and managed to kill me, making him a new Orc Captain. He gained a personality, traits and weaknesses,  I decided to get my revenge and hunt himn down.We meet. Grogbur the Flame MongerLong story short, I end up putting a dozen arrows through his face. VICTORY!or so I thought.An hour later, I meet another Orc Captain, his name Grogbur the Flame Monger"You thought you had killed me? Well you didn't! Now Im going to crush your skull with my hands!"Needless to say, me being an impeccable badass, I kill him again!VICTORY!Or so i thought. Another hour of orc killing i meet another Orc Captain.Grogbur the Flame MongerWHAT! By now he has changed completely, he has scars all over his face, new traits  (Invunrable to ranged attacks, THEY LEARN!)We fight..HE WINS!HE GETS MORE POWERFUL!I NEED REVENGE!.... He kills me again.....He gets stronger, now a top level Elite Captain.This ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of an orc starts hunting me down, Throwing his spears ( which are now ON FIRE!)He kills me again.This is it.He needs to die.A lengthy battle ensues, sweat blood and tears are spilt.VICTORY!for now, I've not seen him since. I miss Grogbur the Flame Monger. This is ONE ORC of of an infinite amount that can kill you and become Captain, gaining their own names, personalities, unique interations, weaknesses strengths. BUY THIS GAME!

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												This game feels like Arkham City mixed with Assassins Creed, and I love it. The Nemesis system is very refreshing and the captains are badass. The only bug I've encountered was an issue where I was missing certain sounds during a fight. All I could hear was my footsteps, but as soon as I did an execution it fixed itself. I would definitely buy this game if you enjoyed Arkham City or Assassins Creed, and you like Middle Earth. I've spent maybe half my time actually pursuing the story because just stealthing around killing Orcs is so much fun. The fighting gets more complex as you progress with new enemies and abilities, so the combat stays pretty fresh. The strengths and weaknesses of the captains and warchiefs makes you try different strategies and alter your playstyle to kill them. Every time you die the Orc or Uruk who kills you is promoted and they get stronger each time they kill you. This really makes you want to track down your nemeses, it also makes killing them very rewarding. I'd definitely reccomend this game especially if it is on sale. Side note: brutalized stealth kills are ♥♥♥♥ing sick

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2015
												The gameplay is pretty similar to Batman. It's very fun and not boring. The game might be hard at first but it'll get a little easier as you are familiar with the  game. It took me 20 hours of gameplay to finish the story and that is with exploration and doing the sidequest. The sidequest can get repetitive but its amazing how they have different settings or different ways to do the quesnt even tho you are using either only a sword, knife and bows (I'm not talking about the power struggle quests). I think its because of they gameplay itself. The story was quite good actualy, *SPOILER ALERT* Discovering the story of Calebrimor the ring maker or the wraith inside your body was pretty fun and the mini boss battle that you encounter after going deep into a cave or sneaking trough the orc stronghold  to find the "left overs" of Calebrimor's past was really fun compelling*END OF SPOILER*This game is pretty much similar to other games or you can say this game is a mix betwen Batman and Assassin's Creed in terms of gameplay. But what makes it unique? THE NEMESIS SYSTEM: this is a cool new system that is added to this game. Basically it give the orc or uruk captains and warchiefs different personality and the voice acting is very well done on those orcs and uruks.My only complaint is that the story and map is too short and small for a 40 GB game. also the last boss fight was a joke and dissapointing !-_- The only bossfight that i enjoy truly was the first boss "the Hammer Guy".Final Verdict : 9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												The Lord of the Rings game I've been dying for, for so long.The gameplay is epic, with like most people already suggesting, the nemesis system is a stroke of genius!The story is good, if short, but with a terrible ending. They have really done well researching a gap in Tolkiens lore and filling it in their own way which was incredible. The ending sucked! QTE to finish?! Poor! But i believe the real ending they made has been taken out as DLC (Celebrimbor vs Sauron?! sounds like it to me) In general it should have been a far more developed story as well. They really did have a good thing going but havent capitalised on the foundation they have put down.Its not perfect and it lacks in depth but as a first attempt its brilliant! They have layed a good building base to build up from. With the gameplay down to a tee they can now really bring us a game of epic scale should another be made. My rating will be a tad biased as I have been desperate for a decent Lord of the Rings game now for far too long!!!! But I definitely give it a solid 8.5, 9 of 10.Roll on number 2 where I hope they can improve upon it!Edit:So with all things considered my angle on this game has changed a bit. (It took watching the battle of the 5 armies to make me realise) As much as I do love this game, and I do. Its just not my vision for Middle Earth. Once again you take on the role of a man out of all the bloody brilliant races! The batman style of combat in my opinion is not suited for Middle Earth.... Its ok for batman simply because its a regular occurance that he would be fighting 5-10 opponents and beating them down, but Middle Earth is all about scale! Its about armies clashing, orcs by the thousand teaming over you like a wave of bloodshed! This game is just Batman Middle Earth.... You are constantly in control you constantly have the upper had and your more powerful than any of your enemies no matter the size. And it bores me! And the worst part is really your on your own. Tolkiens main message is about fellowship and overcoming an evil that is greater than you are. By these respects it misses its mark. Its still the best Middle Earth game in a very very very long while and the best we will probably see for just as long. But its just missing emotion. And that is what a Middle Earth game has to have to truely capture what I want to see.And YES I most certainly have high standards for the best lore I know and ever will knowIn terms of changes to how I feel about the game the I have in front of me... Well there is almost no replay factor. Side quests suck, collectables pointless, you become super man with all the power-ups you purchase and you just end up with a game of press 2 buttons together to watch the same old animation of Talon chopping an orcs head off totally destroying the stealth aspest. Warbosses become boring as they often have insta kill weaknesses such as stealth kill or headshot to the face. Either that or they are almost impossible to kill because they have a shield but you cant volt them as they block that and you cant use finishing moves on them and so you have a stale mate of wack, stun, wack, stun until eventually they die. It just does not have the depth or breadth to keep you entertained past the first play through. So far DLC has been more of the same old same old kill warchief stuff so nothing to note on that either. Still..... More than worth your money even for the one play through!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												I purchased this game as a fan of the story, and as a means to evaluate my new high-end PC. Both of these expectations were met with solid satisfaction. The combat and Nemesis systems are revolutionary; that said, the game is surprisingly short - even when aiming for 100% completion. Right away, the combat makes you feel like a badass. Later on, as you gain upgrades/abilities, this feeling is amplified until you become quite unstoppable - even when surrounded by HOARDS of orcs. Even the toughest enemies become painless to overcome. The story was pleasing to follow, especially if you're familiar with LOTR; perhaps even if you're not. Albeit strange at certain parts, I found myself wondering and delighted to uncover the "secrets" involved with this lore.In the final battle(s), you are of course pitted against what you expect to be the most formidable opponents; only to be slightly disapointed by the lack of difficulty. I felt like I really took my time with this game, exploring the landscape, creating conflicts, welcoming massive battles, and earning 100% completion. In all, I believe I put about 30 hours in to do so. If I were to for some reason start over, (this game offers no desire for replayability) I could probably go from 0-100% in half the time. I have not purchased any DLC yet as they all appear to be lacking.In closing, let me say that this game offered me one of the greatest experiences I've ever had gaming in the shortest amount of time. I am hopeful for a sequel, or at least some decent form of continuation. Overall: 9/10

Posted: October 4, 2014
												Shadow of Mordor is one of the best RPG's I have ever played. What would be a repetitive combat style is kept fresh and exciting by all of the new mechanics that get introduced throughout the game. The open world is fun to explore and full of just enough danger to keep you in check. The nemesis system is an extremely interesting new mechanic that is used extraordinarily well in this game. Shadow of Mordor, however, does have one major flaw [listed in spoiler text] that prevents me from alloting it a 10/10 score. That flaw is the final boss battle. It is literally a 10 second long quick time event and is extremely dissapointing given the drama, intensity, and tension that comes before it. An enormously bland ending to an otherwise masterpiece of a game.  Score: 9/10 would very much recommend to anyone who is a fan of the RPG genre.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												The story is mediocore and character development is way too sparse for me to care about its protagonists.  The nemesis system is interesting, but since there is a steady stream of new orc captains and no noticeable effect in the game world, it feels a little short of what it could truly be.  However, the combat system feels great and is fun to use and I find myself coming back to smash more orc faces.  Combat is the right mix of challenging and fun in the beginning, but becomes a little too easy later in the game when your character is becomes way too overpowered.  Even then, the unending swarm of enemies in a stronghold keeps the combat interesting.

The storyline is intriguing, the combat is brutal and animated so well, the finishing moves are some of the coolest I've ever seen in a game, and the way the game picks a finishing move on how an orc is positioned, it's just plain awesome to see them die in such a stylised and badass way.Overall, the game has it's bugs and it can be difficult to locate captains sometimes, but all in all the game is magnificent. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2014
												This game, along with Dark Souls 2, is in the running for my Game of the Year. The combat is basically the same as the Arkham games, although I felt that at first it wasn't as flowy but over time it became just as flowy as the Arkham series. The story itself is pretty good. The plot is well done and the cutscenes are gorgeous, and the amount of outside lore put into the game by Monolith is outstanding, and it enriches the world deeply. The nemesis system is the elephant in the room. It's definitely the most innovative system I've played through in a long time. I remember my nemesis Mugluk Graug Slayer would simply refuse to die. I must have "killed" (if you don't behead said Uruk, there's a chance that he can come back) him at least 5 or 6 times and he kept coming back with a vengeance. I also had a hilarious experience with an Uruk by the name of Gunza the Rhymer. I beat him every time he fought me, and every time he came back he look more and more messed up in his face. In our final encounter, he retreated, only to be promptly eaten by a caragor (the Middle-Earth equivalent of a lion). Encounters like this make the game super fun and super addicting. I give this game a 10/10. It fulfilled all of my expectations and has given me a great time. I look forward to scouring Mordor all over again!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												This game so far has ticked all the boxes.Combat - As many have said, its like batman/AC. After unlocking techniques combat becomes very interesting.You have your average slice and dice finishers, to branding (mind control) in the middle of a fight and even brutalizing orcs to make others run away in fear.Story - I won't say I know all the lore to say it doesn't trample on some things, but I'd say its a decent story. It had some nice surprises too.SUFFER ME NOW - Dominating the minds of orcs will never get boring. Ever. Especially after its one that messed up a previous mission for you or flat out killed you.Death/Captains - If you die to a Captain (or Warchief) they will mock you the next time they come across you. So not dying has become a matter of "not being insulted". I also noticed a Captain make fun of me for having low HP in a fight, so that was cool too I guess.I could say so much more, but then I'd end up rambling. All in all, you won't be dissapointed in this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												8.5/10It's a great game, well polished and the game mechanics are an awesome change of pace that gives the AI the life that most games never see. I feel like this IP has a lot of potential, a lot like playing the first Assassin's Creed. It just felt like there wasn't quite enough variety or secrets to the game. Everything was pretty cut and dry as far as story goes, though it was done perfectly. The voice acting and the dialogue was very well done.Perhaps it was the setting that they had to work with or perhaps it was that they spent a lot on the system and didn't have time to give it the extra umph it needed. Most firsts don't quite fill out and the same applies here. It's just missing a bit of mystery, a bit of story, and could use a bit more variety and challenge. I've played AC and games like it enough that the combat was easy to master. It didn't matter what was going on I became invincible about 3 hours in after I got used to the hints in combat.TLDR: 8.5/10 I would definately recomend this game. I think the franchise has a lot of potential to become something great if you just look at the gameplay and mechanics. I'm not sure how much they should continue the story though (won't work the further you go with it) The mechanics and AI can go into every game ever though. Please developers learn to envolope things like this into your AI.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												After paying basically no attention to this game pre-release I didn't have high expectations. Being a fan of AC and Batman AK a game that sorta combined the two while adding its own flavor seemed like something interesting. After watching some youtube gameplay videos I was hooked. Bought the game and so far I'm about 10 hours in and absolutely love it.The combat is fantastic and the ability to use your powers,sword,dagger,bow seamlessly is great. Movement is much like Assassisn Creed but a little rougher at some points.Using direction keys instead of where you look and pushing forward takes some getting used to but once you get over that its simple and smooth. THere is a pretty big lag of direction in the game and alot of the ins and outs you will need to learn on your own by playing. I highly suggest doing a search for "Shadows of Mordor" newbie tips to try and familarise yourself so you dont get smashed.Oh, and the nemesis system is pretty cool. I got mobbed by like 100 orcs and went down in a glorious fashion. Some random NPC orc got the killing blow on me and turned into a name nemesis with his own skills/rank etc just for killing me in-game. Pretty cool stuff.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												A better assassin game than Assassin's Creed, which a great implementaion of Arkham-esque combat. The Nemesis system is where it really shines, which allows Orc Captains to be manipulated or hunted down. In the event of them killing you or certain actions being acheived (escaped, burned but survived), they will remember you and in some cases the character model will be updated to reflect this. Graphics-wise, I can run it constantly above 60, textures can be a bit lackluster but it has some superb lighting and weather effects. Finally all of the voice acting is superb, with the original actor for Gollum being used to give it a real authentic feel. I give this 9 crazy elf wraiths out of 10.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												Simply put this is a great game. I have played 17 hrs and only 37% complete so there is lots of content for a single player game. The combat is a lot of fun especially when you start getting the upgrades. Nothing beats exploding an Orc's head and watching the others run. Well most anyway, some don't get scared of that stuff. The death threat system is tons of fun and gives you lots to do if you want to break away from the main mission. I think I played the first two hours and didn't even start a mission, there are tons of Orcs around to have fun with.The combat system makes the game more than just hack and slash. The stealth element gives you other avenues to explore and you will learn when use it and when to run in like a mad man.. You will most certainly die which will stir the pot among the Orcs and change the game. Kill one and change the game again. The gamaeplay is smooth for me on a GTX 770 and Intel i7, all settings high. I have encountered no noticable bugs and had no problems changing settings in the menus to get things how I want them.The game is a good mix of elements that keeps things interesting and fun. There is enough content to feel like you got your moneys worth and more. Two thumbs up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Free-flowing combat and an open world game, fans of Assassin's Creed and Batman games will enjoy this.The heirarchy system or orc captains and warchiefs made for a good few hours of assassinations and battles that seemed overwhelming at times.Difficulty seemed to decrease as the game progressed, as unlocking more powerful skills (in particular the brand) turned the tide in my favour. I suppose it'd be dissapointing if the MC didn't improve at all, but I believe a lot of the fun lay in plotting how to approach a situation and attacking at the weaknesses of the enemies. Near the end of the game I felt near-invincible and could charge in without much thought.Deffo worh a look if you like the genre, you may feel that you've seen the combat system before, but it's fluid and viceral, making it extremely satisfying to behead that pesky Uruk who had ambushed you. LOTR knowledge not really needed, I wasn't a buff on the books/movies myself but still enjoyed the story.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												After playing it for about 8 hours, I've come to really enjoy this game. It's tuns of fun. And I mean TUNS OF FUN! I still haven't really progressed in the story because I keep wanting to complete every side-quest/collectible there is. The combat is very fluid (think of the Batman Arkham series but now you actually stop your attacks to block enemies) and the challenges are well-made. My only complaints are aimed at a few clunky things when it comes to special enemies:1. Some Orc Captains seem to keep "evading death" in my game, a good example of this was this one time where I snapped a Captain's neck using stealth, his name popped up with the red X over it. But when I hit "Enter" to see the battle report, I noticed it said he'd gained power and after leaving the "Army" menu, I was brutaly mauled by the now-undead captain who then got a promotion for killing me...2. My other issue comes from shield bearers. I'm at the point where if I have to kill anyone with my arrows or by sneaking, it's them. They're just to werid to fight against. I get "L-Shift" prompts above there heads before they attack but hitting it doesn't do anything. This makes them incredibly annoying to fight against as they drop me to nearly a third of my health when they hit.Other than that, the port is great! The graphics are excellent and very well-detailed, I get a stable 80-90 FPS with my 7970. The climbing/parcour aspect of the game works and isn't too weird (the wraith enhanced you with magic but you're not overpowered). On a side note: I would've liked to get to know Talion's family a bit more before they're killed. As it stands, the game starts with a 15-20 minute cutscene/tutorial on the basics of how to play and they use flashbacks for you to see moments you spent with your family but, honestly, I didn't really care when they died because I didn't get to know them. I would've prefered a more "assassin's creed 2" type of deal where we spent about an hour or two with the main character's family before they get killed.Other than those few issues, the game plays really well and is really enjoyable so far. I recommend it to anyone even if they're not a fan of the Lord Of The Rings or Hobbit movies/books.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Most squabble when it comes to its playstyle being similar to Batman: Arkham City, but I have to disagree.   While there are mission points and the like that are a call to that type of open-end game, Shadow of Mordor seems to keep it alive.   I've not progressed very far just yet, but I have to say that taking revenge on a captain that has killed you, is damnably fun.  I think I've only completed four missions thus far and had the misfortune of encountering a higher ranking captain.  A heavy strike from which was enough to send me to half-health.   It's ridiculously fun for me and I encourage others to try it out.  It also has a fun set of lore to find as well.

Game says it requires 1gb vram for low texture quality, 2gb for medium, 3gb for high, and 6gb for ultra. I have a gtx 690, which is only a 2gb card. But I have two 2 gb gpu's on one pcb so i figured why not bump the texture setting to high and see what happens.. Game runs great and most times stays at 60fps or above (except when it stutters on occasion.)Great game, I enjoy it so far. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2014
												One uruk killed me right at the start of the game and continued to kill me 3 times after, so I decided to track him down and kill him. Found him in the plains of Mordor and drained him because I needed some elf shot and it would kill him for good (or so I thought). So I play through a few more story missions and I come across him again, this time he's amassed a band of uruks and his face was so badly burnt. So after an epic battle I killed him once more but as per usual he kept coming back with his scarring getting worse and worse until it got to the point where he had to wrap a cloth around his head to hide the scarring, then on the 6th time he came back to life I chopped off his head and he was finally gone. For the rest of the game I played thinking that my old nemesis was dead and gone until it got to one of the final missions. That same stubborn uruk showed up again as one of the final bosses.This game is superb, the nemesis system is one of the best gameplay features that I have seen in a long time and will give you some pretty memorable moments. All the orcs have so many different personalities and traits that it never gets old watching uruk captain's rise, fall and betray each other in the ranks of Sauron's army. Even regular goons may get promoted to captains if they kill you in a fight which adds to the replayability of the game.Overall this game has been one of the best of 2014 by far despite it's somewhat weak and difficult to follow storyline, it's always fun to play and I would reccomend it to anyone.9.5/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												I wasn't expecting the game to be so entertaining. It's not that the story is the best thing ever; it's good, but not great. The gameplay is great, with the tools Talion slowly amasses feeling like toys that you're free to play with. The real gem is the Nemesis system, which lives up to the hype. All of the orcs have individual patterns of behavior, but they are also affected by their environment and fellow orcs. For example, executing a captain causes the orcs to scatter in terror, while causing a retreat actually engenders an ordered withdrawl with forces moving in an organized manner. Messing with the orcs is possible and fun. My favorite trick is Shadow Stepping into a captain with Vulnerability to Ranged and executing him on the spot just to watch his little orclings panic.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												This is Inglourious Basterds the video game, with a few small changes such as you are no longer in Germany you are in Mordor, and you won't be killing Nazis, you will be killing Orcs.Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor is an amazing game which I can't recommend enough, while the story is fairly simple the main focus of the game is killing Orcs in violently brutal but graceful ways, like a Ballet dancer with chainsaws attached to his/her arms.You play Lt. Aldo Talion, who goes through some emotional scarring early on which basicly fuels the fire for the Orc killing machine.  You become the terror of Mordor, stealthing or rampaging through Orc camps with devastating efficiency.It's also worth mentioning the Nemesis system, it's an incredible system which can make an Orc remember your encounter should he kill you or flee from a past battle.  Everytime an Orc kills you, he will remember and you can be sure he'll be a smug git about it, and in doing so you gain a little rivalry which is extremely satisfying when you take take sweet revenge.If you enjoy Assassin's Creed or the Batman Arkham games and really just want to kill things, then Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor is for you.(If you would like to see gameplay, I have a  video series on this game which you can check out on my  YouTube channel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												A great game with a unique concept to the FPS hack and slash genre. The fight sequences a fluid and reminds me a little of the Batman combat engine.The game has an indepth story line which lets you step into the shoes of Middle Earth ranger who comes back from the dead and finds himself also being bewitched by a ghost. The most unique thing about this game is creating and amassing an orc army at your disposal during fight sequences - this comes later in the game and is well worth the wait to get there.The leveling systems are two-fold. Character and weaponry or which you can also upgrade your weaponry from drop runes which you insert into the weapon allowing you certain benefits. Highly recommend this game to everyone... 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												What can I say? Finally we have a modern video game holding Lord Of The Rings IP, which is worth playing! This game is a must own for pretty much any gamer out there.I love the gameplay, It feels smooth and you really get into the character, regardless of the pretty all-out start of the story cinematic in the beginning. Combat is very similiar with AC and Batman franchise, so most of you will get in fast with the game. Combat is great, it's fun, it looks great and I love the variation in moves our character Talion holds. Also there are few approaches to combat and you can go for your own combat style and improve Talion alongside your style. It's great.Nemesis system is absolute killer and makes the true fun for the game. I love watching how Orc captains and warchiefs rise in ranks, fight each other. I love the fact that I can become a kingmaker and intervene a duel between captains, make one of them run away and spare his life, while I slay the other.Side missions are fun and I think the medium length is well-thought per mission.Exploring is fun, but I think there could be slight improvement in this regard, but this is just nit-picking.Final verdict: no severe bugs, lot things to do, nice features and all settings customisable to your liking. Must own game, buy it now when it is very cheap for the next 24hours!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												PROS:Good blend of Batman Arkham combat and Assassin's Creed open-world questing, nemesis system sets it apart from those games...perfect amount of content without feeling bloated/padded or consolidated too muchVery high quality graphics with good performance scaling (advanced options screen actually has explanations of what each adjustment does, which is a nice bonus), cinematics, sound design, voice acting...all around superb production valueCONS:No multi-gpu support (SLI/Crossfire) as of this review, 3 months after release which is pretty lame...highest texture quality requires 6GB(!!!) of VRAM on your primary card so multi-gpu support wouldn't help with that anyway...despite all this, game still ran just fine on my R9 290 with High quality textures, FXAA with motion blur @ 1920x1200, even during intense action so this is mainly a minor annoyanceINTENSE swings in mouse sensitivity/acceleration (particularly while stealthing/crouching) that is supposedly tied to framerates and sync with monitor Hz, possibly also with the motion blur...overall this game is pretty great for a console port but this seems to be one of the unavoidable compromises*possible spoiler* the last two boss fights with the Tower and the Black Hand are extremely disappointing and brief and this game uses very lazy QTE mechanics in all the parts that you are fully expecting to be the most difficultoverall this is going to make a lot of folks' Top 10 for 2014 lists and i feel it's well deserved, definitely worth whatever price it's being sold for

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												I have racked up 40 Hrs on the game and completed every single achievement. The only thing that I can say is that is is jaw-dropping. My PC is not the best when it comes to running games, but I can run this with all setttings at high, so compatibility is no issue. I can only say one thing: I WANT MORE!The good:This game is amazing graphically. The story blows your mind. I mean, like, wow. Also it has Gollum, which in itself earns merit. The game is immersive and pays homage to Tolkein's wonderful world. The executions are brutal and they never get old. Although people say the map is small, and I suppose it is compared to other open-world games, it certainly doesn't feel that way. I never found the map's size to be an issue for me. It is very much the perfect size for a game of this calibre. And the beasts... Whether it be riding into battle with a Caragour and hearing the enemies cower in fear, or watching them get eaten by Graugs, those beasts are deadly. They are just as formidable friendly as they are foe. Never gets old. The cherry on top for this game which really sold me was the Nemesis system. It is the first time I have played a game where you can get revenge on the exact piece of sh*t AI who killed you. No death is from a generic Uruk. if you are killed, you will be able to brand that son of a b*tch for death and hunt him down. There is something deeply satisfying when you revenge-kill an Uruk who killed you previously. It totally sold me. I fell in love with this game with just the Nemesis system. It deepens the game a great deal. This game should have been GOTY. When I saw the trailer I was seriously excited and hoped to hell that this would not disappoint. It surpassed my axpectations.The bad:I hate having to fill in this section because this is by far one of my favourite games. There are a few things wrong, however much i wish it were not so. First off, there is no New Game Plus mode. this is kinda disappointing because I really wanted to play this game again with all my OP abilities. The story is very short if you do not do side missions (of which there are loads!!!) so to maximise fun it is recommended that you do, otherwise the game would probably be over in 10 hrs or so. The Season Pass is a disappointment for me. If you don't intend to buy and DLC, ignore this. I got the Premium Edition for a steal of a deal of £24.24 on sale. MY VERDICT: get this game. Regardless of the price, I would have gladly paid full price for this having known what I know now. It is worth every penny. BUT: Do not get the Season Pass unless it is on sale. This is the most disappointing part of the game. So far, the Season Pass has yielded very little to offer. The most noteworthy is the Lord Of The Hunt DLC, but the Warband Missions get kind of tiring, despite adding a competetive edge to the game. I hope that the upcoming Bright Lord DLC will be just as good, if not better. If you still wish for DLC, I suggest that you buy Lord Of the Hunt (and maybe The Bright Lord too?) DLC separately and save yourself the money, but GET IT. It will not disappoint.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												Middle-Earth: Shadow of Mordor is one of the few games now a days that is worth every penny spent. The combat; fluid. The story telling; dymanic. But above all, it brings forth a sense of duty, and also a sense of anger. The game ocassionally makes you question if you are any different from the Uruks themselves, filled with anger, hate, and above all, striving for power. The game is very well done and is very playable even without a controller. Even not strong Lord of the Rings fans will find comfort in the fluid game dynamics, combat, and countless hours of things to do. You can spend the first 5 hours with out even completing the 1st mission. Make this an item on your next purchase list.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												I've only scratched the oozing, bubbling surface of this open world game and I forsee many hours being spent skulking through the ashlands of Mordor.  The combat is intuitive and fun, if not a little easy at times, and the climbing and running about the world are accomplished easily.  Your enemies have a lot of personality and someone took great care in developing each one into its own persona. The rune and stats upgrade screens are a little too small and unwieldy, as are a lot of the menu screens, which may be a result of the console port.It's almost like a nice meaty sandwich with high quality meats and cheese - stuffed between two pieces of generic bread.  The story cutscenes are beautiful, but you don't really have the connection with the characters and the plot just doesn't seem to stick.Outside of this, I see a future where much black Orc blood will be shed!
